IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thalamic circuits are dominated by two sources of inhibition that influence the type and quality of information that relay cells transmit from eye to brain. Here we use an interdisciplinary approach that combines diverse experimental techniques with theory and computation to explore how inhibition contributes to local and global feature processing in thalamus. Understanding how thalamic circuits operate is key to understanding sensory integration per se, and, moreover, serves studies of disorders such as amblyopia or the development of visual prosthetics by providing a blueprint for how healthy brains function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative This research project will use micro- and macro-scale anatomical and physiological brain imaging techniques to identify biological mechanisms of cognitive decline in people with multiple sclerosis (MS). We will explore the link between neuronal integrity and alterations in brain networks across different stages of MS. This research will provide insight into novel therapeutic targets to treat cognitive impairment in MS and, in addition, tools that can be used by clinicians to predict patients at risk for cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: A SYSTEMS THEORY APPROACH TO THE STUDY OF COLON AND LUNG CANCER HEALTH  DISPARITIES USING NOVEL DATA LINKAGES Project narrative/relevance African Americans and rural Americans are disproportionately affected by both cancer incidence and mortality with little progress made in narrowing the gap with their white or urban counterparts. With this application, we will combine unique data sources to create a population-based, racially, socio-economically, and geographically (urban versus rural) diverse cohort of men and women to examine targeted therapies, comorbidities, and multi-level contributors to survival disparities for colon and lung cancers. We will convene an advisory board of community leaders, organizations, and clinicians to identify multi-level and modifiable targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic kidney diseases such as Goodpasture's disease, Alport syndrome, and diabetic nephropathy damage the ultrafilter causing kidney failure. We study the molecular architecture and function of the collagen scaffolds that comprise the normal filter and which are damaged by these diseases. The knowledge gained provides a framework to develop new forms of therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative.  Cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD) is a leading cause of vascular dementia and stroke. We have previously identified a genetic risk factor associated with CSVD which then was confirmed in multiple different manifestations of the disease implicating polyamines as the potential explanation of the association. To prove it, we are measuring levels of the different forms of polyamines and looking at the brain imaging manifestations of CSVD. If positive, there are both dietary and pharmacologic interventions that may be used to reduce risk in the future. PHS 398/2590 (Rev. 06/09) Page Continuation Format Page

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many patients with gynecologic cancer experience treatment-related sexual health concerns but do not raise these concerns with their clinicians due to a lack of preparation for how to do so effectively. The objectives of the proposed study are to evaluate the efficacy of a patient-focused intervention designed to promote clinical communication about sexual health for patients with gynecologic cancer (Starting the Conversation – Gynecologic Cancer; STC-GC), to test intervention mediators, and to obtain qualitative data from patients and clinicians to contextualize and interpret quantitative findings of the trial. This study has public health relevance because enhancing gynecologic cancer patients’ communication about sexual health would directly impact clinical care and could improve patients’ sexual and psychological health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) carries an enormous human toll and is characterized by macrophage- overactivation that causes profound degradation of the aortic matrix accelerating rupture and mortality. We observed that within the AAA microenvironment, increased local tension activates Cdh11 which exerts strategic control of aortic macrophage reprograming capable of collapsing the aortic tissue. Our experiments will detail mechanisms connecting Cdh11 and pathologic macrophage function in AAA by using mice models of macrophage proliferation, lineage, plasticity and newly designed drug targeting Cdh11 coupled with state-of-the- art sequencing approaches in human samples to thoroughly delve into new treatment approaches urgently needed to treat individuals with AAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TANGO2 Deficiency Disorder (TDD) is a genetic condition associated with high mortality rates due to recalcitrant ventricular arrhythmias, unresponsive to standard antiarrhythmic therapy. Promising new data demonstrates B- vitamin supplementation can prevent and potentially treat arrhythmias in TDD, yet how B-vitamins impact the pathophysiology of TANGO2 Deficiency Disorder and the mechanism driving lethal ventricular arrhythmias remains unclear. This study proposes to assess B9, a component of B-vitamins, by combining clinical patient data, a mouse model, and patient-derived, induced pluripotent stem cells to investigate B9’s effectiveness in treating arrhythmias and to elucidate the mechanism of TDD-related arrhythmia development in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative It is estimated that approximately 300 million people are infected with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), which is a largely incurable and lifelong infection that is responsible for >800,000 deaths annually, primarily due to severe symptoms including cirrhosis and liver cancer. Curative therapies for HBV are desperately needed but the lack of clinically relevant and affordable animal models for HBV have hindered the development of new therapies. In this proposal we will use our recently developed and affordable model for HBV to develop and evaluate novel curative gene therapies that target the HBV virus for elimination in infected cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Having deciphered a clinical phenotype of impaired recovery in spinal cord injury (SCI) patients, we discover that a SCI-associated pneumonia (SCI-AP) induces propagated spinal injury manifesting as `infectious insult' – and with that, SCI-AP qualifies as causal, clinically relevant and targetable outcome-modifying factor causing injury/disrepair. Selecting a mechanistic approach supported by recent data from our lab, we will focus on one goal: Reveal novel targets to block or reverse SCI-AP-induced injury/disrepair. If successful, data from this grant proposal will inform the development of more effective non-antibiotic treatments for immune compromised SCI patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer is a leading cause of death in the U.S. and a major public health burden as one woman out of eight will receive a diagnosis in her lifetime. Large ‘omics’ studies that have been able to identify hundreds of breast cancer risk associated polymorphisms include women of mostly European ancestry even though preliminary evidence indicates that there is a clear benefit in studying genetically diverse samples. The goal of this study is to investigate the Latin American-specific genetic architecture of breast cancer overall and by distinct tumor subtypes, which are associated with differences in prognosis, and test predictive models that combine genetic and risk factor information accounting for variation by ancestry and geography.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Mutations in a gene called Lamin A and C, or LMNA is the most common single gene problem causing human lipodystrophy, a human disease characterized by fat loss and problems in glucose and lipid metabolism. Despite being discovered as a cause of familial partial lipodystrophy in 2001, the exact mechanisms leading to fat loss in patients with LMNA mutations have remained elusive. In this proposal, we will systematically evaluate the potential mechanisms that may cause fat loss in this condition, making use of our novel animal models as well as tissue, cells, and nuclei obtained from affected human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Adjuvant strategies to thrombolytic therapy are needed for the 275,000 patients that develop chronic deep vein thrombosis each year. In this renewal project, we will extend our work that combines image-guided histotripsy with thrombolytic drugs to engineer new instrumentation for customizable treatment zones based on the target pathology, address safety concerns, and develop personalized treatment schemes that counter changes in the composition of thrombus with age. Successful completion of these tasks will enable us to bridge the current gaps that limit deployment of histotripsy as an adjuvant to thrombolytic therapy into the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this research is to better understand the cellular mechanisms responsible for leaky blood vessels in the lung. While normally forming a tight barrier, during severe infections or inflammation the cells lining these vessels can form gaps which allow fluid to leak into the airspaces of the lung causing respiratory failure and often death, a process called acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). By studying the underlying mechanisms and regulation of this process we hope to identify possible targets for treatment of this condition.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Motor and non-motor impairments are linked to falls and a poor quality of life in individuals with Parkinson's Disease (PD). However, the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood, limiting the avenues for treatment. This proposal will use mobile brain imaging to precisely measure brain activity during a laboratory- based balance assessment. We will identify individual variations in impaired brain function and their relationship to the poorly understood perceptual-motor and cognitive-motor impairments responsible for poor balance in PD. The technique has the potential to advance more personalized diagnosis and treatment to reduce falls for individuals living with PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposal aims to investigate the interaction between tumors and host organisms to find new methods of treating cancer in the context of a ketogenic diet (KD), because KD induced reduction of tumor growth but shorter overall survival in two mouse models of cancer cachexia associated with interleukin-6 (IL-6). The mechanism of cancer cell ferroptosis and the host's inability to synthesize corticosterone during metabolic stress will be studied in the context of NADPH depletion secondary to KD-induced lipid peroxidation. The role of IL-6-induced anorexia and growth differentiation factor-15 (GDF-15)-induced anorexia as contributors to cachexia will also be examined, with the latter being elevated by oxidative stress in a KD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our incredibly diverse cell types are all produced from a single genome template, and it is thought that the three dimensional packaging of the genome within the nucleus determines cell type specific gene function. Here we use the fruit fly model to understand how the neural progenitor genome organized the mechanisms by which this organization changes over time to regulate genes in the neurons. Results will provide new insights into a fundamental question on how different neural identities are generated during development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative. While the components of key morphogen signaling pathways have been identified, a systems-level understanding of how signaling activity propagates and creates fate patterns is lacking. Here we take advantage of novel live cell reporters and human stem cell-based patterning systems to combine quantitative experiments with mathematical modeling to understand how the paradigmatic Nodal/Lefty pathway shapes cells fates in the early embryo. The results will be fundamental to understanding early embryonic development and provide a foundation for advances in preventing birth defects and in regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The core signaling mechanisms that regulate basic cellular functions, such as cell division, metabolic homeostasis, and subcellular structural organization, tend to be highly conserved in all eukaryotes, whereas diverse mechanisms of intercellular communication have evolved to support different morphologies and lifestyles of different organisms. Investigation of signaling mechanisms in plant model systems is not only important for agriculture, food security, and ecosystem sustainability but also can inform medical research because many plant signaling components are conserved in humans and Apicomplexa which includes parasites responsible for serious human diseases, such as malaria and toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During the previous grant period, we discovered how the human pathogen enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli responds to mechanical cues in its environment by subcellular compartmentalisation of the transcriptional regulator GrlA, and showed the mechanistic basis of GrlA shuttling between inner membrane and cytoplasm in resting versus mechanically stimulated cells. The experiments described in this application will determine how another key EHEC virulence factor, Shiga toxin, is regulated by mechanical cues, and how the toxin facilitates EHEC colonization by modulating gut motility and displacement of the endogenous microbiota. This work will reveal a new regulatory mechanism for Shiga toxin-converting phage, and provide new insights as to the role of the toxin during host colonization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Proper synthesis, folding, modification, assembly, and quality control of collagen, the most abundant protein in the human body, is essential for the structure and function of diverse tissues, including bone, skin, cartilage, tendon, and more. Defects in collagen production underlie diverse, currently incurable diseases. This proposal (1) uses a comprehensive suite of in vitro and in vivo approaches to elucidate molecular mechanisms of collagen production, both how they work well and how they go awry, and (2) tests new, small molecule- based strategies for ameliorating disease-causing collagen proteostasis defects in state-of-the-art 3D tissue model systems, culminating in advances in fundamental understanding and new therapeutic approaches for the collagenopathies.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is increasing with little advancement in treatment options for patients besides transplantation for end-stage disease. Our lab has identified that macrophage migration inhibitory factor (Mif) is a critical contributor to ALD pathophysiology. The current proposal will define the tissue-specific roles of the Mif receptor Cd74 in ALD progression and create novel interference therapeutics against this inflammatory axis in ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are a major driver for antibiotic prescriptions worldwide, with Pseudomonas aeruginosa causing approximately three million infections a year, primarily in older individuals. While this number matches the number of wound and respiratory infections caused by the pathogen, there is very limited investigation on how Pseudomonas establishes infection in the urinary tract. In this work, we propose to leverage our recently collected uropathogenic Pseudomonas isolates – which differ genomically from strains that cause respiratory or wound infections – to determine the pathogenic cascade of Pseudomonas in the bladder and to elucidate how age may influence the ability of this pathogen to persist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Animals exhibit a suite of behavioral changes known as sickness behaviors during infectious conditions. The purpose of this application is to elucidate the neural circuits in the brain impacted by sickness to alter behaviors. Successful completion of this application will provide new insights into the neuroimmune interactions adopted by animals to cope with infection and how such a strategy, when dysregulated, can potentially lead to neurological disorders whose causes are rooted in immune activation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project is to assess the impact of urban greenspaces on community health. For this assessment, we acquired health data from individuals living in a low-to-middle income neighborhoods in Louisville, KY before and after planting a large number of mature trees and shrubs in the area. We have also acquired data on air pollution, before and after the planting. We now plan to study the long-term impact of this intervention on community health and the levels of air pollution in the neighborhoods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a chronic inflammatory skin disease characterized by painful skin alterations in the skin-fold areas leading to low quality of life, with racial and sex disparities. However, the pathogenesis of HS and contributing factors to the disease disparities are poorly understood. The overall goal of this project is to define the genetic contributors to HS risk using whole-genome sequencing and functional genomics, which may uncover the pathogenesis of HS, leading to new therapeutic targets and treatments for HS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Tissue factor pathway inhibitor (TFPI) is a protein that prevents blood from clotting. This proposal will examine basic biochemical interactions between TFPI, other blood clotting proteins, and proteins in the extracellular matrix and how these interactions modulate disease development in animal model systems. The results will be important for developing new treatments for thrombotic and bleeding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed studies will determine if the nuclear hormone receptors which are highly expressed and regulated in the kidney, the estrogen related receptors (ERRs), play an important role in treating and preventing age- related kidney disease. We propose that: (1) decreased expression of ERRα or ERRγ accelerates age-related kidney diseases, whereas increased expression of ERRα or ERRγ slows age-related kidney disease (Specific Aim 1); (2) ERRs modulate age-related kidney disease by inhibiting the increased synthesis and accumulation of ceramides and glycosphingolipids (Specific Aim 2); (3) ERRs modulate age-related kidney disease by inhibiting proinflammatory immune cells (Specific Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The most basic function of skin is to protect tissue from the environment. This protection is due to a permeability barrier that is critically dependent on a type of fatty substance called ceramide. Many skin diseases are due to a loss of ceramide. This project is to discover how the correct kinds of ceramides are made to maintain skin barrier function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to US public health since cancer remains the leading cause of disease related death in childhood in the US. In addition, while approximately 80% of patients diagnosed with cancer today will be cured of their original disease, few of these survivors will have a normal lifespan and most will experience secondary diseases and disabilities as a result of the toxic cancer therapies they receive. The proposed research is highly relevant to the NIH mission, as it seeks to discover new scientific principles and develop new immunotherapies for the treatment of children’s cancers, which will also provide generalizable knowledge regarding optimal approaches to develop immunotherapies for low mutational burden cancers occurring in other populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Translating genomic discoveries into clinical practice is vital but riddled with challenges - slow adoption of guidelines, lack of diversity in studies, inadequate reimbursement policies, and more. By integrating world-class scientific expertise in genomics with success in learning healthcare system implementation and internationally recognized high quality coordination capability, Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC) will create a unified, genomics-enabled, learning healthcare system (gLHS) Network. We will facilitate project selection and optimization, establish a shared technical gLHS architecture, adapt and tailor to meet various local contexts, and build trust through authentic partner engagement enabling the next frontier in precision medicine by making genomics a more readily accessible component of routine care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Inner ear disorders, such as hearing loss and dizziness, are often caused by degeneration of the sensory cells and neurons that relay information to the brain. We have discovered a new way to produce human inner ear cells in a culture dish. In this study, we will iteratively redesign and reformat the inner ear cells to make them more useful for testing drug or gene therapies that could regenerate a patient’s inner ear after damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project narrative Gastrointestinal nematode parasites (aka Soil-transmitted helminths, hookworms, whipworms, roundworms) are amongst the most prevalent and disease-causing parasites on earth for humans and animals, with infection leading to malnutrition, adverse pregnancy outcomes, low worker productivity, and permanent growth stunting and cognitive impairment. Very few drugs are approved to treat them, and those that are used are prone to parasite resistance and have inadequate efficacy. To meet the WHO recommended Target Product Profile for new anthelmintics, we will increase Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) crystal (Cry) protein anthelmintic efficacy by developing effective fit for purpose formulations to improve gastric resistance and by employing two evolutionary strategies used in nature to improve Cry protein efficacy, namely (1) synergistic protein combinations and (2) synergistic swapping of domains between Cry proteins, with the eventual aim of performing safety studies of our lead Cry protein anthelmintic for clinical advancement.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 50% of children with developmental language disorder at school entry will exhibit persistent language disorder. The early family context of children reared in poverty may influence children's risk for persistent language disorder. We test the Family Stress Model for its applicability to linking early family context to risk for persistent language disorder among children with early language difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because sickle cell disease (SCD) is a life-threatening blood disorder that affects millions of people worldwide, causing debilitating effects from acute painful episodes to chronic organ dysfunction, limiting quality of life and expectancy. We have identified that complement activation can drive acute chest syndrome (ACS), a major complication of SCD with high morbidity and mortality. In this proposal, we will identify mechanisms and treatment options for ACS using a multi-faceted approach of animal models, microfluidics and human samples to predict, prevent and treat ACS in SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will uncover mechanisms underlying the func- tioning during acoustic communication learning of a key auditory processing stream between Core and second- ary auditory cortical fields. Elucidating the normal operation of this system for perception and learning of com- municative sounds in complex soundscapes will be important in implicating mechanisms that may fail in auditory processing disorders, social disorders with auditory dysfunctions, age-related hearing loss and temporal lobe strokes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Round 5 (R5) of the National Social Life, Health, and Aging Project (NSHAP) will continue its legacy as a nationally representative, longitudinal study of U.S. older adults focused on the links between social, cognitive, mental, and physical health trajectories. This fifth round will produce high-quality, longitudinal data that includes a fifth wave of data for Cohort 1, a third wave for Cohort 2, and a first wave for a new Cohort 3 (born 1966-80), as well as a restructured and refreshed sample which will provide better representation of Black and Hispanic older adults. R5 retains and expands measures of cognition and AD/ADRD, activity and sleep, polypharmacy, frailty, inflammation, and cardiovascular and metabolic risk, providing the scientific community, clinicians, policymakers, and the public with a valuable resource to examine the social determinants of health disparities within and between ethnoracial groups, across cohorts, and within dyads.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: ACJ injuries are quite common among young athletes engaged in contact sports. In cases where the injury is significant and cannot heal by itself, surgical repair is necessary. The focus of this project is to evaluate the efficacy of recent surgical techniques that more completely and less invasively reconstruct the ACJ's soft tissue. The goal is to determine if these techniques can provide optimal shoulder motion, strength, and soft-tissue health over time while minimizing surgical invasiveness. The outcomes of this research will be valuable in identifying the most effective treatment for ACJ injuries, highlighting the limitations of existing techniques, and suggesting ways to improve surgical methods in the future. Ultimately, this will lead to better patient care and recovery after ACJ injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Communication between nerve cells in the brain is largely dependent upon neurotransmitters, including dopamine, serotonin and norepinephrine, being secreted from one nerve cell and activating receptors on adjacent nerve cells. Many important therapeutic agents, including drugs for depression, anxiety and attention deficit conditions, target membrane protein transporters that remove, or ‘uptake,’ these neurotransmitters. The research in this grant is focused on understanding how these transporters work and how important therapeutic drugs, as well as illicit agents, bind to the transporters and modify their structure and activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed research investigates how hippocampal and frontoparietal function the human brain undergoes qualitative changes during adolescence, leading to improvements in memory and reasoning abilities during emerging adulthood. A growing body of empirical work has shown that difficulties with memory and reasoning in development are associated with poor academic outcomes, as well as with several mental health disorders with developmental onsets, including affective disorders and schizophrenia. Isolating the neural mechanisms that underlie changes in memory and reasoning ability during adolescence may thus help identify markers of atypical development and contribute to interventions that may improve both cognitive and academic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rates of cannabis misuse are rising among young people, underscoring a need to identify modifiable risk factors for cannabis misuse in this age group. Sleep appears to be just such a risk factor, but cannabis-sleep relationships remain poorly understood. This project will examine sleep and circadian rhythms during cannabis use and discontinuation to better understand sleep/circadian-related mechanisms contributing to cannabis misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The benefit of effective and less invasive therapies that can replace invasive surgical procedures and enhance treatment outcomes for glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) patients is significant. Biomaterial formulations providing steady and prolonged release over several months of highly effective tumor homing killer cells known as neural stem cells (NSCs), and the use of a non-invasive dosing method known as focused ultrasound (FUS) to deliver NSCs systemically and across the blood brain barrier (BBB) can potentially increase efficacy outcomes to GBM treatment regimen and transform the GBM treatment landscape. The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop and evaluate a new treatment modality that combines a biodegradable and highly tunable biomaterial scaffold and non-invasive FUS to enhance delivery of NSCs to tumor cells and to curb the treatment of GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Homeless adults have higher rates of disease, shorter life expectancies, and higher health care utilization compared to housed individuals, all of which are partially attributable to the disproportionately high rate of harmful alcohol use in this population. This project will test the efficacy of a novel smartphone-based just-in- time adaptive intervention specifically designed to work in concert with traditional shelter-based services to address problematic alcohol use in adults experiencing homelessness in a large-scale randomized controlled trial. If effective, this low-cost and highly scalable smartphone-based intervention could significantly improve drinking outcomes, quality of life, and overall health for this highly disadvantaged population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The liver is responsible for many tasks, from metabolizing nutrients to breaking down toxicants and foreign chemicals and displays a robust sex difference in its metabolic functions. Nuclear receptor CAR, a xenosensor, regulates many of these pathways and cross talks with ERα signaling. This proposal will investigate if and how CAR regulates metabolic processes in a sex-specific and spatiotemporal manner during liver injury and regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Approximately 70-80% of Asian Americans young adults report experiencing explicit racial discrimination in the past year (e.g., harassed, or experiencing unfair treatment due to race) highlighting that racial discrimination is a common and acutely harmful experience and a significant public health problem. This will be the first study to establish how explicit, internalized, vicarious, and cumulative exposures to racial discrimination are associated with trajectory classes of alcohol use and other drugs, mental health, and physical health over the course of 36 months among U.S.-born 18–19-year-old Filipino, Korean and Indian Americans. A deeper understanding of the potential distinct and transdiagnostic power of different types of racial discrimination on a myriad of prospective health problems will provide new theoretical insights regarding the etiological pathways and developmental course of alcohol use and other drugs, mental health disorders and physical health among three marginalized Asian Am. ethnic groups.

PHR: Chronic kidney disease affects approximately 10% of the world’s population and is marked by progressive fibrosis that leads to kidney failure. One of the main drivers of CKD progression are kidney cells that are injured but never fully recover from injury. This study is designed to investigate pathways that can trigger restoration of injured kidney cells to their healthy state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Only approximately 5 out of 100 people with glioblastoma—the most common type of cancer that starts in the brain—are alive 5 years after diagnosis; half of all patients survive just 12-14 months. We discovered the BRD8 protein as a new target that, when depleted, could prolong survival in nearly three quarters of these deadly cancer cases: those without mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor. The project’s goal is to determine how BRD8 loss revives p53 and shuts down glioblastoma, thereby paving the way for more successful therapies for people with this devastating malignancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though POTS is common in adolescence we do not understand its cause. Since it often comes on after a trauma or infection and is often associated with chronic pain disorders like migraine or fibromyalgia, we believe the cause could lie in a part of the brain responsible for meeting the major threats of life (called the periaqueductal gray or PAG) that never gets properly reset after the threat passed. We will evaluate this theory by comparing brain connections in adolescents with POTS with those for adolescents without POTS who get a moderate to severe infection that gets better, to see if we can find evidence that the PAG is responsible for both POTS and the associated chronic pain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Overall The Mni Sota Center for Climate Change and Health will build multidisciplinary research capacity related to climate change and health as experienced by American Indian and rural communities through the innovative use of data resources and authentic engagement with communities. The goal of the Mni Sota (the Dakota word for ‘where the waters reflect the sky’) center is to be a leading research center that will characterize health impacts related to climate change and translate findings to create practical and actionable measures for climate change adaptation with a specific focus on American Indian and rural communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This Upper Midwest focused research core will evaluate the impact of extreme weather conditions on marginalized and disparate populations in this region and coordinate with the Mni Sota Center for Climate Change and Health to ensure culturally responsive information sharing. We will develop a new extreme weather database of heat, cold, air quality, and compound extreme events focused on the Upper Midwest and working with the Minnesota Electronic Health Records consortium, we will evaluate emerging extreme weather risks for high disparity populations including American Indians, rural residents, and individuals prescribed ‘climate sensitive’ medications. Our findings will provide powerful insight into extreme weather risks for at-risk populations in Minnesota and develop the critical partnerships with communities and healthcare providers to expand climate and health research capacity in this region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clopidogrel is a widely prescribed anti-platelet drug used to treat coronary heart disease (CAD) with known genetic variants that effect drug response. However, no study has looked comprehensively at the contributions of other multi-omic datatypes on drug response in non-European populations. The contributions of social determinants of health (SDoH) to the health outcomes of underrepresented populations with chronic conditions like CAD and who experience health disparities are also largely uncharacterized. Our study will fill these gaps with a cohort of Caribbean Hispanic clopidogrel patients and healthy controls with multi-omic data and with an evaluation of individual SDoH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative End-stage kidney disease patients on hemodialysis experience debilitating fatigue, pain and depression, which are associated with poor health-related quality of life, increased hospitalizations and mortality. With this proposal, we will enhance our successful Technology Assisted Stepped Collaborative Care (TĀCcare) intervention for symptom management, and test effectiveness and implementation of TĀCcare 2.0 facilitated by dialysis staff in a real-world setting. If successful, this study will provide transformative evidence and a blueprint to dialysis clinics and policy makers for an integrated, scalable intervention for improving symptom burden and meaningfully changing clinical care for patients on hemodialysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A hallmark of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a dense extracellular stroma that reduces mass transport and inhibits immune cell infiltration into the tumor. Systemically delivered stromal targeting therapies have shown promise at extending patients’ lives; however, the clinically effective doses result in potentially fatal side effects. Our goal is to advance a local drug delivery platform for intratumoral delivery of stromal targeting therapies to improve mass transport into the tumors, providing a window of opportunity to deliver systemic chemotherapy with greater effectiveness and improve immune cell infiltration into the tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Although immunotherapy has become the first line of therapy in advanced patients with lung cancer, less than half of all eligible patients respond to immunotherapy. In this grant, we will uncover intratumoral microbial and immunological predictors that distinguish responders from non-responders, with the goal of identifying new targets for more effective immunotherapies. In clinical practice, these predictors could help optimize patient selection for treatment with immunotherapy and facilitate the development of precision immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Intra-abdominal infections (IAI) with fungi and bacteria concurrently result in worsened outcomes as compared to monomicrobial or bacterial co-infection, although the reasons are not fully understood. Our previous work to recapitulate IAI in a murine model using the fungus Candida albicans and bacterium Staphylococcus aureus as model organisms has identified Candida-induced bacterial toxin production as a key driver of pathological inflammatory responses and lethality. The major goal of this work is to delineate the host and microbial mechanisms involved in promoting lethality and altering protective trained innate immunity in order to develop better therapeutic interventions to prevent the high mortality observed during fungal-bacterial IAI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) is a debilitating condition that occurs in up to 87% of children treated with chemotherapy and often persists in long-term childhood cancer survivors. CIPN is particularly challenging to identify in young children because there are no validated instruments to measure CIPN in children less than five years old, even though 40% of children at risk for CIPN are in this age group, and early intervention can improve their symptoms. The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop a patient-centered clinician-guided instrument to screen for CIPN in young children and collect preliminary data to inform future implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strategies to improve interdisciplinary communication that are responsive to needs in low resource settings are needed to improve childhood cancer globally. This project identifies determinants of communication in low resource settings prior to co-developing and testing interventions with staff from these impacted settings. When completed, this study will produce evidence informed, multilevel interventions to improve team communication during patient deterioration, advancing the science of multidisciplinary communication during cancer care, and ultimately improving survival for children with cancer globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of antibiotics in the first year of life has been recognized as a strong, consistent, and modifiable risk factor for the development of asthma in childhood in numerous individual studies and several meta-analyses. The goals of this proposal are 1) to determine the age when infants are most susceptible to the harmful consequences of antibiotics on childhood asthma risk, 2) to examine microbial pathways through which infant antibiotic exposure could lead to childhood asthma, and 3) to identify early-life upper respiratory tract and gut bacterial species, patterns, and/or products that could increase the resilience of these 2 microbial communities and be protective for childhood asthma onset after infant antibiotic exposure. By identifying a critical window of opportunity to intervene, the microbial pathways to target, and candidate probiotics and/or bacterial products, the ultimate goal of the planned studies is to inform the design of microbiome-based therapeutics that can help deliver antibiotics safely during early life and reduce the burden of childhood asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Greater than 75% of the human genome is transcribed, yet only 2% of genomic sequence is transcribed into protein coding RNA transcripts. Estimates suggest 50-90% of disease-causing mutations are located within noncoding sequences, suggesting non-protein coding RNA transcripts significantly contribute to disease pathogenesis. Upon completion, our study will provide insights into the mechanisms by which noncoding RNA transcripts regulate retinal development and visual function, including providing insights into the prevalence and function of transcription factors binding to RNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Children’s Interstitial and Diffuse Lung Diseases (chILD) pose significant burdens on thousands of children across the U.S., yet for most, the genes causing chILD have not yet been identified. This project aims to define genetic landscape of chILD to inform the development of more specific and biologically rational therapies for these disorders. Our approach combines in situ transcriptomic profiling, whole exome-sequencing, and network-based analytical approaches to map novel chILD-causing genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to understand programmed cell death/survival in mouse models of retinal degeneration and to identify cellular pathways that promote cell survival. Living-color reporters named CaspBiosensors will be used to identify cells that will eventually die (vulnerable) and other cells that are reverse their death signal (resilient). The cellular and molecular features of these vulnerable/resilient cells will be investigated to inform the development of neuroprotection therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will focus on the development of novel technology for ultra-fast, high-resolution, and noncontact quantification of corneal biomechanical properties in 3D. The development of such a technique would significantly advance our understanding of corneal disorders, enable the development of personalized clinical therapies and interventions, and improve outcomes of current surgical and therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: A proliferation of wearable devices and machine learning approaches has led to exciting advances in automated assessment of sleep, physical activity, and sedentary behavior in real-world environments. These methods, however, have been predominantly developed and validated with adults and older children, and they do not readily transfer to assessment of infant functioning in these key health domains. We aim to fill this gap by (a) leveraging high-density multimodal data collected from a wearable device designed specifically for infants and (b) developing deep learning algorithms to detect infant sleep/wake states, physical activity/sedentary behavior, and household soundscapes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this proposal is to create and calibrate visual activities in virtual reality that will measure how well people with poor eyesight can use their vision, by estimating the difficulty of each activity in a large group of individuals with different levels of vision loss. They will perform these activities while wearing a head- mounted display and using vision alone, but also when enriching the activity with sound and/or touch. We will choose the activities on the basis of patients’ ratings of what is important and difficult for them due to vision loss, and compare participants’ performance of some of the activities in virtual reality the real world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because it will provide critical data on the pathways between disclosure and helping receipt for one’s own self-directed violence (SDV) as well as helping after exposure to SDV by family or peers. Importantly, this study will also identify how one’s own SDV combined with exposure to SDV may be differentially impacting the helping behaviors and the impact of such behaviors over time for sexual and gender minority as well as racial/ethnic minority populations, information key to designing more helpful suicide prevention strategies that bridge two threads of prevention (increasing protective factors for both at-risk groups and those exposed who can be active gatekeepers). As a result, we would expect decreased morbidity from SDV, improved quality of life for SDV youth and their friends and families, and a widespread reduction in medical costs associated with SDV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE A significant fraction of cases of neurodevelopmental disorders (NDD) are caused by coding mutations that prematurely terminate the translation of specific RNAs into proteins. However, protein production can also be disrupted by mutations in the untranslated regions (UTRs) of RNAs. We propose to detect and analyze new NDD mutations by bringing to bear a unique set of tools specifically designed to study translational regulation by UTRs, extending the utility of ongoing efforts to sequence the genomes of tens of thousands of NDD cases across the US and the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffusion MRI (dMRI) has contributed immensely to our understanding of the white matter structure at large-to- medium spatial scales, and more recently towards smaller structures, particularly in the cortical and subcortical regions, as submillimeter dMRI is starting to become more feasible. Nonetheless, further increase in resolution is required to move dMRI to the mesoscopic scale, to improve sensitivity to small but important brain microstructural features and provide improved capability for many current clinical and neuroscientific investigations and open doors to entirely new ones. In this proposal, we aim to develop imaging technologies to allow mesoscale dMRI and extend our development to enable mesoscale joint diffusion-relaxometry MRI with rich information, to improve tractography’s robustness and enhance capability to extract detailed microstructural information. Optimized protocols will be developed for high-end clinical 3T MRIs to enable wide deployment of our technology, and on high-performance head-only 3T MRIs to enable neuroscientific explorations at the limit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: We will define how the conserved Bicaudal-C RNA binding protein selects mRNA substrates and regulates their expression to control critical cell-fate decisions in a model vertebrate. Bicc1 is highly conserved in all vertebrates, including humans, where it essential for normal development as well as the function of organ systems in adults, but little is known about the molecular mechanisms that define Bicc1 functions. Because a molecular understanding of Bicc1 is fundamental to advancing several biomedically relevant research areas, including our understanding of complex diseases that affect a substantial fraction of the population, the proposed research is highly relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE In this project, we propose to develop a technique to dynamically image the lung using 129Xe MRI during free- breathing; in addition to enabling a more physiologically accurate assessment of lung function compared to current imaging techniques performed during breath-hold, this method will be feasible in patient populations that have thus far been inaccessible to functional lung imaging with polarized gas due to poor breath-hold tolerance, such as young children, those with end-stage lung disease, etc. Finally, we will establish the repeatability and sensitivity of this technique in both healthy subjects and at-risk smokers / early COPD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Programmable genome modification using the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing system has enormous therapeutic potential for rescuing gene function in individuals bearing mutations that cause inherited diseases like Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD); yet, introduction of bacterial Cas9 protein into mammals can trigger an immune response, which may pose a barrier to the use of this system for human gene therapy. This project will investigate how the immune response to Cas9 affects gene editing in a mouse model of DMD, by assaying differences in the relative rates of therapeutic gene modifications, as well as potentially deleterious mutations, in mice with intact or disrupted immune systems. Results from this work will aid evaluation of the efficiency, durability and safety of in vivo gene editing for DMD, and inform the design of future clinical approaches that utilize CRISPR-Cas9.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Bone fractures in the elderly are a major public health issue due to their high morbidity, mortality and healthcare costs, which need new therapy. Aging is often associated with cellular senescence, a stage when cell stopping growth and producing harmful factors to the body. We found a sub-group of senescent cells that are detrimental to fracture healing in aged mice. In this application, we will investigate how these detrimental senescent cells work and if specific removal of detrimental senescent cells can be a new treatment for old patients suffering from bone fracture.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Significance: Excessive alcohol consumption is the third-leading preventable cause of death in the United States. A promising alcohol use biomarker is increasingly being used as a laboratory test biomarker of recent alcohol use in forensic or legal or family court matters. The proposed study will improve upon the clinical utility of this alcohol use biomarker to better identify problematic drinking and lay the foundation for future work identifying the appropriate application of alcohol-use biomarkers in prevention and treatment programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Upon successful completion of our aims, we expect our contributions will provide a novel tool for accurate long- term breast cancer risk assessment among Black women, extensive multi-site validation data and a complementary deployment/dissemination framework to enable further evaluations in research settings. Given that current long-term breast cancer risk models have limited applicability and/or low accuracy among Black women, our novel engineering approach to breast cancer risk assessment meets a critical need and, has the potential to advance personalized risk assessment for Black women. This, in turn, will reduce the number of breast cancers that are diagnosed at a later and more aggressive stage among Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shear stress is a blood flow-associated frictional force that regulates many vascular functions such as inflammation response, vascular permeability, and leukocyte adhesion, all of which are key factors in atherosclerosis. Both clinical and basic data demonstrate that failure in the clearance of dying cells from the body (defective efferocytosis) is linked to atherosclerosis-related events. How blood flow patterns affect efferocytosis in endothelial cells, the cells that line arteries, is largely unknown. Upon conclusion of this study, we will understand the role of blood flow patterns-related defective efferocytosis in endothelial cells, and this discovery will stimulate a new avenue in the design of drugs that treat atherosclerosis by enhancing efferocytosis in endothelial cells or introducing helical flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The underlying autoimmune mechanisms which result in loss of body fat in patients with acquired generalized lipodystrophies (AGL) and acquired partial lipodystrophies (APL) remain largely unknown. Thus, the main aim of this proposal is to identify additional antigens expressed in body fat tissue, such as recently discovered perilipin-1 (PLIN1), against which patients with AGL and APL develop autoantibodies and to determine their function in adipocyte biology. The other aims are to determine how these autoantibodies cause loss of body fat and insulin resistance and metabolic derangements using the mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The perception of noxious thermal stimuli is often coupled to pain sensation as a protective mechanism, however, aberrant temperature sensation can lead to neuropathic pain (e.g., in peripheral nerve injury; multiple sclerosis; fibromyalgia; stroke; and chemotherapeutic-induced peripheral neuropathy) where patients experience pain due to cold hypersensitivity. By uncovering basic biophysical, cellular, and molecular mechanisms of noxious cold perception, we develop critical insights into neural integration of painful/nociceptive stimuli providing potential routes for understanding and treating neurological disease when this process is disrupted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Of the 1 million people in the US that will develop myocardial infarction (MI) this year 25-50% will be susceptible to sudden death due to malignant arrhythmia over their lifetime. Many strategies are available to mitigate the risk of arrhythmia, and mortality; however, the underlying factors that attenuate individual risks are poorly informed by currently available data. The proposed prospective observational study will define the longitudinal association of reperfusion injury after percutaneous intervention for MI with intra-myocardial fat deposition, negative cardiac remodeling, and malignant arrhythmia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of this project is to determine the structures of cytochrome c oxidase (CcO) by using two state-of-the- art technologies: serial femtosecond X-ray crystallography and single particle cryogenic electron microscopy. The outcome derived from this project will yield important knowledge allowing us to comprehend how the oxygen reaction catalyzed by CcO is coupled to proton translocation and how the activity of CcO is regulated by cellular effectors. This research is relevant to the mission of NIH as it will provide a structural framework to guide the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting related human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive alcohol consumption among college students continues to be a serious public health concern, associated with a wide range of negative consequences. Development of efficacious intervention approaches remains a priority for NIAAA. The present research proposes to evaluate a telehealth version of the Brief Alcohol Screening and Intervention for College Students (BASICS) intervention for heavy-drinking and mandated college students, which has the potential to retain the strengths of in-person interventions relative to static feedback, and can be disseminated in locations where in-person interventions are not feasible. If effective, this intervention approach will provide evidence for the efficacy of a low-cost intervention paradigm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: People with normal hearing are typically able to recognize, understand and localize sounds of interest, even when they are embedded in mixtures of other sounds, but these abilities are often compromised in listeners with hearing disorders. The proposed research will enrich the understanding of how information in the ear gives rise to auditory behavior and how impairments in the ear alter behavior. The results will likely provide insight into the basis of listening difficulties, potentially leading to improved remediation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite advances in the treatment of cardiovascular disease, therapies that directly target the heart are lacking. The proposed research uses newly discovered lipid nanoparticles with unprecedented targeting to the heart to deliver agents that can remodel the microtubule network - a scaffolding within the cardiomyocyte that can lead to impaired heart contraction. We will test the lipid nanoparticle therapies in two clinically relevant models of heart failure, as well as in human heart samples, supportive of lipid nanoparticles as a general method for targeting therapy to the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Restoring coordinated, rapid neuronal signaling is a goal of myelin repair therapies in diseases such as multiple sclerosis, where myelin sheath loss leads to disability. Here we combine innovative 3-D myelinating cell cultures and in vivo analysis to identify developmental mechanisms that establish myelin sheath properties expected to enable precise neuronal signaling. Results from this work will reveal fundamental cellular and molecular mechanisms as a step towards the goal of devising strategies to restore myelin for fidelity of neuronal signaling in neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibroids are the most common pelvic tumors in women of reproductive age, incurring significant health care costs and morbidity, and are two to three times as common among Black women compared to White women. This study will seek to identify factors that explain the differences in fibroid incidence between Black and White women. The identification of how established fibroid risk factors, psychosocial factors, environmental factors, and structural racism contribute to the racial disparity in fibroid incidence could lay the groundwork for identifying strategies that would reduce fibroid incidence, particularly among Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research has a strong public health need because the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the top cause of lower respiratory tract infections among young children and older adults in the US and worldwide. RSV RNA synthesis machinery remains a high priority among non-segmented negative-sense (NNS) RNA viruses, and we seek to understand the molecular mechanism by elucidating the atomic details of the interaction surfaces and catalytic domains. The proposed research meets the NIH’s mission of reducing illness and disability caused by RSV and related NNS RNA viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Breast cancer arises from breast epithelial cells that gather pro-tumorigenic mutations leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation and tumor initiation. Knowledge of how tumor initiation can be regulated by the cellular microenvironment will enable us to specifically interfere with the function of tumor-initiating cells to stop tumor growth and potentially recurrence of breast cancer. In this renewal, we will explore the emergence precancer-associated fibroblasts (preCAFs) and define their role in reshaping the breast immune microenvironment in the pre-malignant breast of BRCA1 mutation carriers. This may ultimately lead to the development of novel therapeutic approaches for primary cancer prevention and to treat patients suffering from breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The upper urinary tract exhibits peristaltic contractions that propel wastes from the kidney to the bladder. Defects in upper urinary tract peristalsis, such as vesicoureteral reflux, are prevalent and associated with a high morbidity. In this proposal, we will define the signaling mechanisms that underlie upper urinary tract peristalsis defects, as well as identify the potential of drugs to treat these defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood cancer survivors are a growing cohort of individuals with both modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors for premature cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. This phase IIb randomized trial will test whether time-restricted eating can be deployed as a feasible, sustainable, risk-reducing measure to reduce weight and cardiometabolic risk in radiation-exposed childhood cancer survivors with overweight/obesity. This intervention may provide an important, scalable tool to combat the obesity epidemic and survivor-specific cardiometabolic risk and thereby improve the longitudinal health of survivors of childhood cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is a huge global health problem with 254 million cases per year and more than 617,000 deaths annually. The study will provide preclinical compounds for further development as anti-malarial therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide risk is high in middle-aged and older adults, and especially in those who have been recently hospitalized for suicidal ideation or behavior. The goal of this project is to evaluate the predictive association of emotion reactivity and cognitive reappraisal with suicidal ideation in middle-aged and older adults (40-90 years old) who have been discharged from a suicide-related hospitalization. Understanding this relationship may help identify suicide risk factors and subgroups of patients at high suicide risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Electrophysiology is essential in developing novel therapeutics against cardiovascular diseases, the leading cause of death worldwide. This proposal introduces a novel nanophotonic device to wirelessly perform electrophysiological studies of cardiac models in vitro with unprecedented resolution and long-term stability. This technological development is projected to impact fundamental and translational cardiac research significantly and, in the long term, contribute to relieving the social and economic burden of cardiovascular disorders on society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The mechanism causing depression and anxiety in the menopause transition is surprisingly unknown, precluding prevention, treatment and cure. This naturalistic longitudinal study of women who choose to undergo surgical menopause will test a novel mechanism in which follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and acyl-ghrelin produce an inflammatory state involving autonomic signaling that underpins depressive and anxiety symptoms. Burgeoning knowledge has expanded the actions of these two hormones beyond their well-known roles in reproduction and feeding into aging, enhancing the plausibility that our hypothesis could impact the health of women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Binge alcohol drinking is a major risk factor for neuropsychiatric diseases including alcohol use disorder, and women are more likely to develop these diseases with a shorter history of alcohol consumption and suffer greater negative effects of binge drinking. The research proposed here will characterize the mechanisms by which the sex hormone estrogen dynamically controls alcohol drinking behavior in female mice through rapid modulation of critical brain circuits in real time. This work may identify novel targets for intervention and prevention of excessive alcohol drinking, especially in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing evidence suggests that cerebellar dysfunction is a key contributor to the pathogenesis of cognitive, communication, motor, and behavioral co-morbidities observed in neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs), but the mechanistic insight to this relationship is still nascent. The proposed research will leverage parallel approaches in humans and mouse models of EBF3-related NDDs to provide insights into the molecular and cellular role of the COE-transcription factor EBF3 in cerebellar development and define the mechanisms of cerebellar inhibitory neuronal dysfunction in NDDs. The unique findings will have broad implications for advancing both cerebellar neuroscience and our understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebellar inhibitory neuronal dysfunction in NDD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to elucidate the molecular mechanism of arrestin-1 binding to rhodopsin, design arrestin-1 mutants that compensate for defects of rhodopsin phosphorylation in vivo, and identify novel interaction partners of arrestin-1 in rod photoreceptors. To this end, we propose to use direct binding assay with phosphorylated and unphosphorylated light-activated and dark rhodopsin, in vivo electroretinography in mice, ex vivo single cell recordings of rod photoreceptors, and in vivo proximity labeling with subsequent mass-spectrometry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The clinical management of extensive bone injuries in humans continues to present a significant challenge. By studying new models of natural large-scale bone regeneration, we have identified a specific subpopulation of cells that is sensitive to injury and coordinates repair. In this proposal, we examine the molecular mechanisms that control these cells, with the long-term goal to develop therapeutic approaches that could heal large and difficult bone injuries in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic adaptation is essential to survival, and metabolic imaging either by itself or in combination with genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics can provide a holistic understanding of how cells adapt under varying physiological and pathological microenvironments as well as serve as a predictive marker of treatment success. The goal of this proposal is to develop a portable and versatile optical imaging platform called the CapCell to characterize the metabolism of subpopulations of cells with different phenotypes and the relationship of these cells with the local microvasculature. We will use this technology to elucidate how metabolic endpoints can inform on the growth and invasion of tumor cells into adjacent host tissue, elucidate how diverse types of therapeutics inhibit the downstream efforts of tumor-promoting oncogenes, and identify biomarkers that can inform the management of cancer therapy in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health. The spatial organization of DNA repair establishes the balance between normal repair, a tumor suppressor mechanism, and pathological repair, yielding oncogenic chromosome rearrangements. Elucidating how DNA repair is organized 3D following DNA damage will help understand the modality of action of cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Glaucoma is a leading cause of irreversible blindness associated with elevated intraocular pressure and increased glial cell reactivity that contribute to retinal ganglion cell (RGC) death. Here, using a newly developed model of ocular hypertension and novel viral vectors, we will test the role of compartmented signaling in astrocyte and Muller glial reactivity before, during, and after glaucoma onset, assaying for effects on RGC survival and microglial/macrophage infiltration, and explore the transcriptional and (epi)genomic mechanisms of neurotoxic and protective astrocyte reactivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative We plan to build on the successes of teplizumab in delaying the development of Type 1 diabetes and its approval as the first therapy for treating Type 1 diabetes since insulin. We aim to identify mechanisms of operational tolerance in responders to increase their frequency and duration of response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This proposal describes a new approach to synthesize bacteria-targeted radiotracers for positron emission tomography (PET) via a one-step reaction using an enzyme and [18F]FDG, the most common tracer used in nuclear medicine. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will address critical remaining questions around Food is Medicine programs (FIM), including assessing the health, equity, and cost impacts of varying FIM program design options, including key elements of dose ($/mo), food groups, duration, and disease targets; 2) assessing intersections of FIM with other levels of healthcare interventions including (a) coordinated food insecurity screening and SNAP enrollment, and (b) new clinical drug treatments; 3) investigating the administrative and legal feasibility of pathways for scaling FIM. This project also aims to disseminate top findings around FIM to relevant scientific, healthcare, legislative, agency, and advocacy stakeholders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. Microbial derived non-ribosomal peptide and polyketide secondary metabolites play critical roles in the clinic, and their biosynthetic pathways hold great promise for development of new therapeutic molecules. However, we still lack a full understanding of the molecular mechanisms responsible for non- ribosomal peptide and polyketide secondary metabolites biosynthesis, particularly related to the role of protein- protein interactions in directing biosynthesis. Leveraging an advanced series of molecular traps, our team combines structural biology with novel state-locking methods to explore the discrete interactions, dynamics, reactivities and catalytic mechanisms that enable natural product production and use them to enable synthetic biology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project is motivated by two significant overarching issues: 1) Across children with reading disability there is substantial variability in pre-to-post intervention gains in reading, with many children showing minimal improvement; and 2) Despite substantial efforts, factors that might explain these variable outcomes remain elusive and prediction at the individual level is not yet possible. Through Community Engaged Research (CER), this project will utilize a novel in-school cognitive neuroscience approach and state-of-the-art analytic methods to establish trajectories of response to intervention among RD readers and identify reliable, generalizable predictors of response.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: PACIFIC INSTITUTE FOR RES AND EVALUATION
PHR: Project Narrative Compared to their cisgender peers, Transgender or Gender Diverse (TGD) people—individuals with gender identities that differ from their sex assigned at birth—are impacted by an extraordinarily high prevalence of negative mental and physical health outcomes and have major unmet social needs due to structural factors, including systematic societal, political, and economic marginalization, medical pathologization, and violence. Using a structural competency framework that considers the external forces shaping health outcomes at levels above individual interaction, this study will implement and evaluate a TGD-specific adaptation of the Critical Time Intervention (CTI), an evidence-based case management program, for TGD people, and develop implementation strategies to facilitate its uptake in under-resourced health and human service systems. This theory-driven, mixed-methods research will produce data targeting the structural factors responsible for the well-documented access barriers and excessive morbidity and mortality faced by TGD people.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing Structurally Competent Critical Time Intervention for Transgender and Gender-Diverse Patients

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A major problem in treating human cancer is development of resistance to therapy that occurs following most treatments including radiation, chemo-, targeted, and immuno-therapies. We will use our novel analytical tools to compare how drug resistance develops at the single cell level in human cancer and in chemically induced mouse cancer by studying thousands of individual malignant cells at molecular resolution. This may ultimately lead to biomarkers of cancer drug resistance or targets to prevent development of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Executive functions, the goal-directed processes that support flexible adaptation of behavior in response to changing circumstances, develop dramatically during childhood, predict important life outcomes, and are impaired in many clinical disorders. Many studies and intervention attempts have focused on children’s capacity to engage executive functions, but children adaptively coordinate whether or not to engage executive functions based on a variety of factors beyond capacity, and these choices shape future engagement of executive functions. This project thus investigates how executive functions are adaptively coordinated across development to match environmental demands, how these adaptations can be harnessed during sensitive time periods to develop effective interventions, and how these adaptations lead to cascading effects that are important to healthy development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Functional loss of the repressor protein REST in the myometrium leads to aberrant expression of its target genes and altered ovarian steroid hormone response in UL. Similarly, widespread occurrence of MED12 mutation promotes UL pathogenesis dependent on estrogen – progesterone receptor pathways. The project will establish a mechanistic relationship between the loss of REST, MED12 mutation and altered hormone sensitivity in uterine fibroids using in vitro methods and novel in vivo models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Degeneration of enteric neurons can lead to intestinal motility disorders as seen in diabetes, aging, slow transit constipation, Hirschsprung’s disease and Western diet intake. In this proposal, using our model of Western diet induced neuronal loss, we will examine the mechanism of how saturated fatty acids lead to damage of enteric neurons with a focus on the role of iron and mitochondrial dysfucntion. Experiments outlined in this proposal may also lead to new therapeutic targets for treating the altered gastrointestinal motility in humans with a Western diet intake as well as in aging and diseases such as diabetes and slow transit constipation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research has important implications for diagnosis and management of ischemic heart disease and will impact health care by improving the reliability and accuracy of noninvasive imaging for evaluation of blood flow to the heart. This project will develop and validate novel deep learning-integrated techniques to significantly reduce variation in quantitative indices. It will yield a more accurate approach for detection of obstructive and non-obstructive coronary artery disease and patient risk stratification, and identification of irreversible scar in patients with heart disease referred for potential revascularization.
