IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Rheumatoid Arthritis is ranked among the highest of all chronic diseases for its effect on health-related quality of life, directly affecting both the professional and personal lives of patients. Persistence of symptoms requires patients to remain on expensive biological disease-modifying drugs for a prolonged time. The goal of the research proposed in this application is to gain insights into the role of Set binding protein 1 (Setbp1) in the persistence of disease symptoms in rheumatoid arthritis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Nearly half of all EGFR-mutant lung cancer patients develop brain metastasis, a severe complication that significantly shortens their survival. We identified S100A9 as a novel mediator of brain metastasis in EGFR- mutant lung cancer. This project proposes to identify potentially targetable up- and down-stream mechanisms of S100A9-mediated brain metastasis for the design of more effective treatments for lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will provide whole genome sequencing (8,100), Alzheimer's disease (AD) plasma biomarkers (7,500), and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk biomarker data (9,000) on African and African American individuals ascertained as part of the READD-ADSP U19. We will also collect longitudinal clinical and plasma biomarker data by recontacting and performing follow-up visits after ~4 years with cognitively intact and mild cognitively impaired individuals from this cohort. Analysis of this data will allow identification of rare genetic variants contributing to AD risk and protection and include biomarker and CVD markers in these models. This will add to this invaluable resource for the Alzheimer's disease (AD) research community to enhance efforts to discover targets for AD diagnosis, prevention, and treatment that apply to individuals of all ancestral backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is among the most common and costly public health problems worldwide. While cigarette smoke is the predominant risk factor for the development of COPD, repeated infections contribute to persistent inflammation and progression of the disease. Our research proposal focuses on the role of lung macrophages in propagating chronic inflammation in patients with COPD exacerbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Prostate cancer is a commonly diagnosed cancer in American men that is largely treatable until it metastasizes and develops treatment resistance and neuroendocrine transdifferentiation (NET). We will use the unique models we have generated to understand the epigenetic mechanisms underlying PCa NET. Our results might identify potential therapeutic targets that control the tipping point of NET and also discover epigenetic biomarkers at the early phase of NET to predict disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our research has unveiled a novel class of tinyRNAs, shorter than 17 nucleotides, with unique functional characteristics distinct from traditional microRNAs. These tinyRNAs remain shrouded in mystery, as their intricate molecular mechanisms have yet to be fully unraveled. With our robust preliminary data as a foundation, our study promises to shed light on the roles of these tinyRNAs, holding immense potential for the advancement of RNAi therapeutics, while enhancing the comprehension of the molecular underpinnings in Argonaute mutation- associated neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Given that distant metastases occur in 10%-50% of patients with surgically resected lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD), there remains an unmet need to understand the tumor genomics that drive the biology of metastases and to develop innovative adjuvant therapies that could decrease the risk of metastases and improve survival. SMARCA4 is one of the most frequently mutated genes in LUAD, and altered SMARCA4 promotes metastasis through ROR2/inactive GSK3β signaling pathway. The goals of this research project are to elucidate the mechanisms through which altered SMARCA4 regulates transcription and promotes metastasis of LUAD and to identify way(s) to specifically target this altered gene, decrease development of metastases, and, ultimately, save lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone marrow transplantation (BMT) is the only curative treatment for many patients with blood diseases, but this potential cure is often limited by severe gastrointestinal symptoms that can prove fatal. To better understand these devastating complications, understand how they relate to other disease settings, and develop new treatments, we will lead a comprehensive interdisciplinary study of how the epidermal growth factor receptor and its activators impact the immune system and the stem cell compartment maintaining the intestines after BMT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The focus of this research is to define the molecular determinants of memory of inflammation in the pancreas. Our proposal utilizes mouse models to establish that inflammatory memory in acinar cells features the AP-1 transcription factors and their binding partners; can be reversed through targeting of MAPK signaling upstream of AP-1 or AP-1 itself; and is driven by the effect of the cytokine IL-33 on acinar cells. These findings will drive our mechanistic understanding of inflammatory memory as a key target to ameliorate the sequelae of long-term consequences of inflammation in human disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Altered microbiota drive mucosal inflammation and clinical relapses in patients with Crohn’s Disease (CD). We will complete the first studies of the prebiotic human milk oligosaccharide, 2’-fucosyllactose (2’-FL), for enhancing beneficial microbiota and associated metabolites in CD patients. These studies will have a high impact in the field by providing critical phase I/IIa safety and efficacy data in support of a phase III randomized-controlled trial to test the efficacy of 2’-FL in directly modulating beneficial microbiota and thereby enhancing sustained clinical remission and mucosal healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the previous funding period, we have successfully demonstrated the feasibility of high-density optical tomographic scanning of breast lesions using a fiber-less, portable, and translation-friendly instrument design. We have also developed a computational framework to efficiently analyze such high-density datasets that were previously challenging. By further enhancing optical spatial sampling density by measuring both amplitude and phase of modulated light at extended wavelengths, combined with innovations in reconstruction techniques, our next generation multi-modal breast imager is poised to further enhance breast cancer detection and clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Drugs of the mTOR inhibitor class hold great promise for healthy life extension. We will compare two mTOR inhibitors, rapamycin and everolimus, for safety, tolerability, and biological effects to determine the best drug, dose, and dosing regimen for use in healthy aging older persons. In addition, we will test various biomarkers that could be used in testing the effectiveness of mTOR inhibitors in future clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Abnormal tumor vascular networks in primary and metastatic liver cancers regulate treatment response; there are currently no tools to characterize their complex attributes longitudinally and non-invasively at bedside for diagnosis, treatment response prediction or continuous feedback to personalize treatment regimens. Here, we propose to introduce, evaluate and translate a 3D DCE-US analysis framework that utilizes the interconnected nature of voxels to capture complex vascular properties in cancer and beyond. Guided by a clinical roadmap to predict or guide patient-specific treatment responses in real-time, our approach will provide new decision support to indirectly reduce morbidities and costs in patients that don’t respond to treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE  In human and animal cells, DNA is condensed in a nucleoprotein complex termed chromatin that is essential for the maintenance of genome integrity and regulation of cellular functions. The goal of this project is to understand the chromatin structure in sperm cells and the function of protein factors that mediate its assembly and remodeling. Our work will help to design methods of diagnosis and treatment of human conditions that involve defects in sperm chromatin metabolism, such as infertility, as well as novel approaches to contraception.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Child maltreatment, a significant public health problem that affects millions of youth each year, often evades successful intervention due to negative views of maltreated youths’ abilities to provide accurate and detailed reports about prior negative experiences. Evidence suggests that maltreated youth may actually remember stressful experiences quite well, better than non- maltreated youth do. Our proposed research will provide a rigorous test of this possibility, focusing on both how well maltreated youth remember stressful experiences and on mediators of their memory, and, in doing so, will offer crucial insight that can improve interventions aimed at reducing long-term harm caused by maltreatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Mitral valve prolapse is a common valvulopathy affecting 2-3%; while it is often benign, a subset of patients with MVP may develop arrhythmias, including sudden cardiac death. There are currently no good risk assessment tools for the infrequent but devasting consequence of sudden cardiac death. This project will utilize cardiac magnetic resonance to 1) study patients with mitral valve prolapse to characterize morphologic features associated with arrhythmic risk; 2) develop and validate a blood biomarker screening strategy to identify patients who may benefit from cardiac magnetic resonance imaging; 3) form a large multicenter observational registry to develop a risk prediction model for sudden cardiac death in patients with mitral valve prolapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a new type of cancer vaccine that uses advanced genetic messages to target hard-to-treat malignancies like pancreatic cancer. Proposed studies will fine-tune the vaccine's composition, safety measures, and delivery in conventional and human immune system-engineered lab mice. By exploring how the new vaccines augment the efficacy of existent and emerging cell-based immunotherapies and tumor- targeted drugs, this work lays the foundation for future treatments that could be more effective and safer for pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Up to 80% of breast cancer survivors experience chemotherapy-induced neuropathy that impairs quality of life and increases fall risk long into survivorship, yet treatment options for neuropathy remain limited. The successful treatment will target neurophysiologic mechanisms for restoring function while addressing patient-reported symptoms and participation in treatment. Toward this end, we propose to study a noninvasive, social sensorimotor intervention – Adapted Argentine Tango – which targets motor control restoration, symptom alleviation, and treatment participation in concert.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative Emotions are important for virtually every aspect of health and disease, but we do not yet have ways of measuring brain states related to specific emotions, and how these brain states are impacted by contextual factors. This project builds on recent breakthroughs in measuring human brain activity using pattern recognition, and uses these tools to define and validate emotional brain states in ways that can aid in the diagnosis, prevention and treatment of multiple brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastatic colorectal cancer harboring a BRAF mutation is associated with poor prognosis and limited treatment options, leading to approximately 75,000 deaths worldwide each year. Building upon our prior success profiling patient-derived tumor samples with an innovative kinase-activity mapping technology, now we seek to identify and target the key stress response programs that enable BRAF mutated colorectal cancer cells to adapt and survive under therapeutic pressure. Our long-term goal is to improve the survival of patients via tailored strategies to prevent drug resistance, restore therapeutic response, or trigger tumor cell elimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Learning-induced myelin remodeling has emerged as a novel form of CNS plasticity with broad potential importance in learning, memory, and diseases like multiple sclerosis. The precise role of myelin remodeling in learning remains unclear, largely due to the absence of tools to experimentally perturb sheath dynamics. We propose an interdisciplinary, collaborative project to determine the role of oligodendrocyte calcium signaling in myelin remodeling, then to leverage this mechanistic insight to determine the roles of calcium-dependent myelin remodeling in learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Tissue-level processes of substantial medical relevance rely on proper regulation of gene expression patterns, established by signaling networks. However, the complexity of the dynamics, feedback regulation, and protein- protein interactions limit our understanding of these networks. In this proposal, our approach is to synergistically use quantitative experiments in live cells and predictive mechanistic modeling to overcome these roadblocks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE To address the unmet therapeutic need for antibody mediated rejection, we aim to develop and apply a drug repurposing pipeline to antibody mediated rejection (ABMR) expression profiles in kidney transplant recipients, to query publicly available drug-gene expression databases and to identify single and combination drug repurposing candidates for ABMR (Aim 1). We will further determine the mechanism of action of promising drugs or drug combinations in human cells and ABMR tissues, ex vivo (Aim 2). Further validation of efficacy for ABMR treatment will be tested in vivo, in a pre-clinical rodent model of ABMR (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Effective therapies for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) have remained elusive and new research avenues are needed. Candidate interventions with potential impact on AD are emerging from geroscience, including the use of compounds that increase healthspan and longevity. This project aims to understand the therapeutic potential of the protective mitochondrial-derived peptide MOTS-c against APOE genotype- and AD-related impairments, knowledge that could be rapidly translated into approaches to prevent and treat AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research holds significant public health relevance due to the pervasive and concerning environmental exposure to microplastics. Colorectal cancer is a disease associated with substantial morbidity and mortality, and effective treatments are currently lacking. The outcomes of this research will provide a fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying colon tumor development following exposure to microplastics. This, in turn, will pave the way for the development of innovative strategies for preventing and treating the harmful effects of microplastics. Therefore, this proposal aligns with the NIH's objective to establish research strategies for disease prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We have identified a highly specific tumor cell surface antigen that is not expressed by any other normal tissue except for the placenta. We have also identified a human monoclonal antibody that binds to this tumor-specific antigen with high affinity and specificity. We propose to leverage this exquisite target specificity to develop a bispecific antibody with one arm targeting tumor and the other engaging the T cell with an optimized affinity to achieve highly potent and specific tumor cell killing without causing excessive cytokine release, and translate this novel immunotherapeutic to clinical trials in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified thousands of genetic loci associated with human traits but have largely ignored the contribution of complex genetic variants such as repeats. This project leverages our frameworks for incorporating analysis of repetitive regions of the genome into GWAS and high- throughput experimental techniques to characterize the role of repeats in a wide range of human phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The mission of the University of Washington (UW) Research and Engagement on Adaptation for Climate and Health (REACH) Center is to leverage implementation science in support of implementing evidence-based health adaptation at scale. The REACH Center will also advance several other innovations, including a novel climate and health decision support tool (the Climate and Health Risk Tool, or CHaRT), a new climate and health implementation science curriculum, a new interdisciplinary planetary health curriculum at the UW School of Medicine, a suite of pilot climate and health intervention activities in communities in the Pacific Northwest, and community engagement activities in support of the research project and the climate and health interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine how educational experiences affect long-term cognitive health leveraging quasi- experimental variation in the content or quality of education in the 1950s-60s due to the National Defense Education Act's provision of K-12 and college resources to improve education in science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and foreign language. It will also examine heterogeneity in impacts by sex, race, geography, childhood socioeconomic status and genetic predisposition for cognitive decline, which is important given large variability in cognitive impairment as well as in the content and quality of education across place, race, or socio- economic status. This study will have a high impact because it will create new data on educational experiences linkable to existing, but rarely combined, surveys to address one of today's costliest health concerns – Alzheimer's disease and related dementia, and because it will provide the first causal evidence of how educational experiences impact cognitive function, with a particular focus on quantitative coursework - where racial and SES gaps mirror those for dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The threat of climate change and urgency to transition away from fossil fuels are broadly recognized. The proposed Health-First Climate Action Research Center will establish the nation’s first Climate Change and Health Research Center dedicated to investigating the potential health benefits of various policy and practice initiatives related to the transformation of energy and transportation systems made necessary by the threat of climate change. Grounded in community-engagement and innovative yet rigorous science, this Center will seek practical, actionable, and evidence-based solutions to optimize health and equity benefits as the nation’s energy transformation advances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Epilepsies contribute to over a quarter of the disability burden of neurological disorders with cognitive deficits impacting quality of life. Studies proposed here will identify fundamental mechanisms of memory processing in the hippocampal dentate gyrus, a circuit heavily impacted in temporal lobe epilepsies, and how they are altered by adaptive and maladaptive circuit changes in epilepsy. The studies will address key knowledge gaps relevant to the 2021 AES/NINDS Epilepsy Research Benchmarks priority area of understanding mechanisms of neuropsychiatric comorbidities in epilepsy and have broader relevance to mechanisms of memory decline in ageing and neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis is a debilitating disease caused by autoreactive immune responses that lead to demyelination and results in loss of neurologic function. Currently available medications address the inflammatory component of the disease but do not prevent progressive degeneration of neurons. This study will develop a new multi- component, multi-functional, nanotherapeutic with improved targeting efficiency and therapeutic function for MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The primary goal of the present proposal is to use a rigorous multi-method approach to determine how and when adverse provider conditions (e.g., burnout, illness, concerns about own health, and inflammation) lead to lower quality of care, especially for patients from racial and ethnic minorit ized groups. The proposed research points to potential and novel sources of bias that have time-dependent opportunities for intervention, distinct from (but complementary to) traditional approa ches to implicit bias training. Moreover, the proposed research will provide additional, novel evidence supporting the importance of addressing system-level issues of inadequate staffing and provider burnout.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The intestinal epithelium is central to obesity-related interorgan communication networks, as it can sense die- tary and internal metabolic inputs, and communicate to affect the activity of distal tissues including the adipose tissue, or fat. Here, we will use mice in which all proteins that are secreted from the intestine are labeled, in order to define both how obesity influences secretion of proteins from the intestine, and how the target subcu- taneous and visceral white adipose tissues are impacted by altered interorgan signaling mediated by intestine- secreted proteins. In the future, the identified secreted proteins could become next-generation therapeutics to improve lipid metabolism and energy expenditure in obesity to improve medical practice and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hormetic stress leads to organismal benefits in many organisms, including via induction of the cell-recycling process of autophagy. However, it remains unclear how autophagy is induced after hormetic stress and whether autophagy is sustained to manifest long-term organismal benefits. Since autophagy and stress- response hormesis are evolutionarily conserved, the proposed research to investigate how hormetic stress regulates autophagy is relevant to human health and may prove important for developing strategies to protect against human age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Pediatric radiation-induced gliomas (RIG) are understudied, uniformly fatal brain cancers that arise as a result of therapeutic cranial radiation given for other childhood cancers. We have established key molecular features that differentiate these tumors from other pediatric high-grade gliomas, as well as a set of novel patient-derived models. In this project, we will use these resources to advance understanding of germline risk factors for RIG, oncogenesis, and translatable treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will determine the underlying mechanisms of how estrogen receptor α improves right heart function in pulmonary hypertension, a progressive cardiopulmonary disease that is caused by thickening of the blood vessels of the lung and that leads to premature death from right heart failure. No cure for pulmonary hypertension is available, and no specific therapies for right heart failure exist. The proposed work is relevant to the mission of the NHLBI, since it will lead to the development of novel treatments for both male and female patients with right heart failure from pulmonary hypertension or other cardiopulmonary diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The proposed study investigates how cerebral aneurysm treatment outcome can be predicted through computer simulations. Typical simulations do not account for clotting factors in the blood, which are important in determining which treatments succeed and which fail. We will incorporate these aspects into computer simulations and validate them with an animal model of cerebral aneurysms for cerebral aneurysm treatment outcome prediction. This project has an impact on public health by improving the prevention of hemorrhagic stroke from aneurysm rupture and improving treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal aims to study a novel protein, EndoU, that binds and cleaves cellular RNAs and is associated with many epithelial cancer types. EndoU is unique among its class of RNA-binding proteins and RNA endonucleases in that its cleavage activity is activated by calcium ions, an important signaling molecule in the cell, suggesting that it functions in the cellular response to this signal. Our study will provide a thorough understanding of EndoU function at the cellular and molecular levels, and enable further studies of its role in squamous epithelium and placental tissues, as well as its role in cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over half a million U.S. patients have implantable pacemakers, with the prevalence of this procedure rising from 0.4 per 1,000 among persons ages 18-64 to 26 per 1,000 among those ages 75 or order. Despite advancements in implantable cardiac pacemaker technology over the past 5 decades, many implants, including leadless pacemakers, are still associated with lead-related complications. To ameliorate these limitations, we seek to develop the smallest (2 mm x 10 mm), lightweight (5 mg), and flexible bioelectronics that can be navigated in the tortuous cardiovascular anatomy for implantation into the anterior cardiac vein to stimulate electrical conduction and myocardial contraction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The pre-clinical studies outlined in this proposal have the potential to elucidate the role of endothelial cells and the blood vascular system in normal thymus function and during regeneration in ways that have not been previously possible through use of novel imaging methods and techniques for direct thymus evaluation. These techniques could be applied to a whole range of studies related to adaptive immunity including graft vs. host disease, age-related loss of thymic function, and cancer. The knowledge gained in this proposal may enable the development of improved therapies for treatment of hematologic malignancies and other cytotoxic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insomnia and related symptoms (e.g., fatigue, distress, pain) that worsen insomnia are common, distressing, and persistent for patients in the hospital receiving high-dose chemotherapy for life-threatening hematologic cancer. Insomnia and symptom management during and following intensive inpatient treatment is urgently needed for this high-risk cancer population and represents a key NIH/NCI initiative; yet, this is a neglected area of research as there are limited insomnia and symptom management protocols that comprehensively address the challenging treatment course (i.e., inpatient, outpatient) and symptom demands (e.g., insomnia, fatigue, distress, pain) faced by hematologic cancer patients. A pilot randomized controlled trial will assess the feasibility, acceptability, engagement, and outcome patterns of a mindfulness-based insomnia and symptom management intervention bridging inpatient and outpatient settings to improve cancer morbidity in a vulnerable yet understudied cancer population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative At the height of the 2015-2016 epidemic in Brazil, there were an estimated 50 cases of CZS per 1000 live births (1:200), equal to the incidence of all other birth defects combined. Longitudinal studies of babies born to ZIKV- infected mothers have reported that motor deficits, cognitive defects, and learning retardation may appear later in life, even if the babies were asymptomatic at birth. This project aims to develop a ZIKV vaccine that provides effective protection against transplacental transmission of ZIKV.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  East Africa (EA) has, historically, contributed minimally to the conditions that exacerbate climate change (CC), yet the region is one of the most vulnerable to the effects of CC and related extreme weather events (EWEs), and this has implications for vulnerable communities' health and well-being in the region. The goal of the Anga Center for Climate Justice, Health Equity, and Community Well-being is to improve climate justice, health equity, and community well-being by exploring climate-related health and well-being and interventions to strengthen them through building transdisciplinary research capacity and fostering sustained community engagement and empowerment in climate vulnerable communities and marginalized populations. The Center will bring funding for CC and health research directly into a region that has been historically underfinanced and expected to experience worse health impacts from CC and expands capabilities of climate vulnerable communities to be engaged with, guide, and co-produce CC and health research, climate adaptive strategies, and interventions that minimize vulnerability to CC and improve overall health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Over the past decades, healthcare systems face significant challenges to meet the needs of an aging population due to progressive debility, functional decline and chronic diseases development. While there is a growing appreciation of the potential impact of mTOR inhibitors on slowing aging processes, preventing chronic disease and prolonging healthy lifespan, a major challenge in developing clinical trials to establish the clinical efficacy of mTOR inhibitors is the absence of pharmacokinetics (PK) and pharmacodynamics (PD) data in older adults. The proposed study will provide the foundation for future clinical trials assessing the role of mTOR inhibitors on aging related indications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy has revolutionized cancer treatment, though a significant proportion of tumors are refractory to treatment or ultimately acquire resistance. Therefore, there is an unmet clinical need to develop new immunomodulatory drugs that can enhance the efficacy of immunotherapy in cancer treatment. A potent and selective SUV39H1 inhibitor could lead to a safe and effective therapeutic approach to augment immunotherapy responses, as well as promote stand-alone antitumor responses, through the unique mechanism of induced viral mimicry, undoubtedly leading to a significant reduction in disease mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: 3D imaging is rapidly replacing 2D planar images in radiology. We aim to create a model with radiologist-like vision that learns to best search and scroll through 3D volumes. The model can be used to identify inefficiencies in radiologists' search/scroll strategies and mitigate search errors, and as a tool to evaluate and optimize the quality of 3D medical imaging technology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This VHA Career Development Award will ensure Dr. Hayes’s expertise in translating knowledge gained from electronic health record (EHR) data and predictive analytics (e.g., predicting the future probability of an outcome for individuals) into interventions that increase Veterans’ retention in medication treatment for opioid use disorder (MOUD; e.g., buprenorphine). His specific training areas span the spectrum of learning advanced methods for working with EHR data, how to develop computer-based tools, and how to test the effectiveness of new interventions. Dr. Hayes will apply this new knowledge to (a) develop a mathematical model that will continuously assess Veterans’ risk of discontinuing MOUD, (b) create a computer-delivered clinical tool that provides clinicians with information (i.e., patient-specific likelihood risk, patient-specific risk factors for discontinuing MOUD, and treatment guidelines, when indicated) on Veterans’ risk of discontinuing MOUD, and (c) test the feasibility/acceptability of the clinical tool among VHA providers who are prescribing buprenorphine.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Over the past two decades, an increasing number of Veterans have used VA maternity benefits for their pregnancy care. As part of the VA maternity care benefit, Veterans are provided a maternity care coordinator (MCC) to aid in their navigation of health care services both inside and outside of the VA during their pregnancies. While the MCC program offers support to women during pregnancy, racial and ethnic disparities remain in delivery outcomes and in pregnancy, labor, and delivery support among Veterans. This study examines the impact of the social determinants of health among Veterans’ of color enrolled in VA maternity care and who also had a cesarean delivery. We will use these findings to inform a pilot intervention that seeks to enhance the MCC model with doula services in effort to provide continuous pregnancy support for Veterans at the greatest risk for cesarean delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High cholesterol is a cardinal risk factor for cardiovascular disease, the leading cause of death worldwide. Inhibition of Angiopoietin-like protein 3 (ANGPTL3) has emerged as a therapeutic target for lowering cholesterol, especially among patients with the underdiagnosed and undertreated condition familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), but this protein’s role in modulating low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL) metabolism is incompletely understood. The proposed studies aim to describe the effects of total ANGPTL3 deficiency on hepatic lipid regulation and lipoprotein assembly, thereby delineating the mechanisms by which drugs inhibiting ANGPTL3 lower LDL independently of the LDL receptor (LDLR).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Suicide is a national public health problem that disproportionately affects Veterans. However, the toll associated with suicide goes way beyond the death of an individual. This study addresses the problems that it is unknown how many Veterans need intervention following exposure to suicide, what types of problems should be addressed and what intervention approaches might be most beneficial. The primary objective of this study is to describe the health and functional outcomes of suicide exposure among a cohort of Veterans at particularly high risk for suicide and of priority for VA suicide prevention strategies – post-9/11 Veterans transitioning to civilian life. Our second objective is to elucidate the reasons some Veterans develop persistent problems following suicide exposure while others do not. This study starts with quantitative (which is the priority of the study) followed by qualitative data collection and analysis to explain and expand the quantitative findings. Findings can inform strategies to support Veterans affected by a suicide loss.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Lack of social connection—especially loneliness—is a common and powerful contributor to suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, functional decline, and even death. The COVID-19 pandemic and its long aftermath amplify risk for loneliness, health problems, and suicide as well as other causes of mortality. A population of particular concern is older adults and patients with medical or psychiatric problems who have limited engagement in treatment. Caring Contacts is an evidence-based suicide prevention intervention that can potentially help. In this project, we will conduct a clinical trial of an adaptation of Caring Contacts tailored to older Veterans who miss their VA healthcare appointments. This project will help advance scientific understanding of how, and in what ways, Caring Contacts works. It will also evaluate a timely, pragmatic, low-cost, and scalable intervention with applicability to post-pandemic treatment engagement and future disasters.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Over 40% of Veterans have obesity, a condition associated with multiple comorbidities and high healthcare costs. While lifestyle interventions addressing dietary change and physical activity produce clinically significant weight loss, many individuals experience weight regain due to decreased adherence to these changes. In this two-arm, randomized trial, Veterans with obesity and a cohabitating adult support person will be randomized to participate in a virtual weight loss intervention based on the VA’s MOVE! program with or without their support person. Those who participate with their partner will learn and practice communication and support skills. We predict that the dyadic intervention will result in greater weight loss, improved social support, and enhanced quality of life at 72 weeks compared to the patient-focused intervention. If effective, the support intervention will contribute to the identification and implementation of successful, evidence-based approaches to reduce the prevalence of obesity and associated comorbidities among Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Pain is a pervasive condition that affects millions of people worldwide. Spinal projection neurons in the superficial laminae of the dorsal horn transmit the ascending pain signal from the spinal cord into the brain; however, the circuitry and functions of output neurons remain incompletely understood. In this proposal, I will characterize the anatomy, functional response properties, and behavioral role of spinal projection neurons to examine their specific roles in nociception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Hispanic/Latino/a persons with multiple sclerosis (H-pwMS) have worse disease trajectories and outcomes and increased mortality compared to their non-Hispanic counterparts. This project seeks to understand what and how healthcare related social determinants of health and medical comorbidities impact critical MS-related outcomes, namely accelerated brain aging and disability, in adult H-pwMS. Such knowledge will lay the foundation for culturally sensitive interventions and healthcare policy changes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This study examines two novel ways to improve functioning and recovery among Veterans with serious mental illness (SMI). It will assess the effectiveness of established psychosocial interventions based on cognitive- behavioral therapy (CBT) and stand-alone social skills training (SST) when delivered by Peer Specialists— Veterans with SMI trained to use their own experience and recovery to help other Veterans with SMI. The project will compare outcomes of Veterans with SMI receiving one of three treatments: Cognitive Behavioral Social Skills Training-Peer (CBSST-Peer), stand-alone Social Skills Training-Peer (SST-Peer), or a peer-led, manualized goal setting group. This work is responsive to national calls for Veterans with SMI to receive support that is evidence-based, improves functioning (not just symptoms), and is tailored to individual needs. If successful, CBSST or SST could be adopted by the 1100 Peer Specialists working in VA, greatly increasing the delivery of evidence-based services to these Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Post 9/11 Veterans who enroll in VA health care frequently present with suicidal ideation and/or recent suicidal behavior. Most of these Veterans are not screened that day, and their risk goes undetected. Studies show that screening for suicide risk, and associated mental health factors, can lead to early detection and referral to effective treatment thereby decreasing suicide risk. Many studies also show that technology can improve screening efforts. Building off 7 years of prior work, in this trial we will evaluate an innovative VHA technology, eScreening, to improve rate and speed of suicide risk screening and referral to mental health care compared to current screening methods used by transition care managers. This study will also evaluate a strategy designed to help programs implement eScreening in new sites. The results of the study could help identify best practices for screening in suicide prevention for Post-9/11Veterans enrolling in VHA and provide information on how best to implement technology-based screening into clinical care programs.

PHR: Project Narrative Social behavior deficits are common features of myriad psychiatric illnesses known to have roots in early development, including autism, schizophrenia and anxiety. Yet, there is little understanding of the ontogeny of social behavior in typically developing individuals. The proposedstudies are aimed towards dissecting the neural circuitry supporting flexible social behavior in typical and perturbed development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. This R01 study will advance our understanding of the neurobiological impact of early life stress and its impact on risk of psychopathology during the neurodevelopmentally sensitive period of early childhood. Our neurobiological and developmental model will help identify biological profiles that signal risk during a period of heightened brain plasticity and will ultimately guide novel treatment approaches aimed at intervening on early biological changes before they translate into behaviors and psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among those who initiate use of alcohol and other substances in early- to mid-adolescence, lifetime rates of alcohol and drug use disorders are 1.3 to 3 times the national average. Concurrently, adolescence is also a critical period for the development of executive control and the brain networks supporting it; a protracted process with a large window of susceptibility to influences by the environment surrounding the teen. Given the importance of executive control systems to successfully avoid high risk-seeking and uncontrolled substance use, it is crucial to understand how the neural trajectory of executive control and environmental disparities play a role in the observed individual differences in substance use initiation and escalation among adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Early detection of young people at clinical high risk for psychosis offers a critical opportunity for early intervention to improve the course of illness, and perhaps even prevent onset entirely. Current interview- based methods for psychosis risk detection lack specificity, and are only available in a handful of research centers in the United States. The proposed study aims to improve accessibility and broaden impact of high risk screening by testing brief computerized measures, ultimately able to be administered on the internet, and to improve prediction by focusing on tasks specific to underlying mechanisms driving emerging psychotic symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A-to-I RNA editing is a very prevalent type of RNA modification in human cells. An increasing number of A-to-I editing sites is being identified in various organisms, but mostly having unknown functional roles or regulatory mechanisms. The proposed research aims to develop and apply bioinformatic and experimental approaches to study the function and regulation of RNA editing in human brain, providing a basis for future studies on how RNA editing may contribute to human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative We propose developing a new center at Brown University named “Climate, Health, and Aging Innovation and Research Solutions for Communities (CHAIRS-C)". The theme of this center is to study how climate-related exposures such as heat and air pollution impact the health of older adults. Working in partnership with community groups and governmental organizations, we will form transdisciplinary collaborative teams to develop evidence and actionable solutions to promote healthy aging for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is an incurable, progressive disease that impacts approximately six million Americans and has a five-year mortality of fifty percent, with a disproportionate burden among underserved populations. For patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, evidence-based, guideline-endorsed prescription therapies improve quality of life and reduce mortality but are often not prescribed. Bringing together key stakeholders, this project aims to design the components of a multilevel implementation intervention to equitably increase the prescription of evidence-based, guideline-recommended medical therapies for patients admitted to the hospital with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Veterans Health Administration (VA) will join a network of other genomics-enabled learning health systems to conduct network-wide implementation projects promoting the uptake of evidence-based genomic medicine interventions. Projects will include pharmacogenomic testing to optimize pharmacotherapy, germline testing to inform cancer treatment, use of electronic medical records to identify patients with undiagnosed genetic diseases, or others selected by the network. These projects will determine the best strategies for implementing genomic medicine across the nation’s health systems, including in medically underserved areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Early detection of young people at clinical high risk for psychosis offers a critical opportunity for early intervention to improve the course of illness, and perhaps even prevent onset entirely. Current interview-based methods for psychosis risk detection lack specificity, and are only available in a handful of research centers in the United States. The proposed study aims to improve accessibility and broaden impact of high risk screening by testing brief computerized measures, ultimately able to be administered on the internet, and to improve prediction by focusing on tasks specific to underlying mechanisms driving emerging psychotic symptoms.

(UNIITE) Narrative: Primary immunodeficiency diseases/Inborn Errors of Immunity (PIDs/IEIs) cause significant morbidity and mortality, yet they are under-recognized leading to suboptimal patient outcomes. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Infants that are born prematurely, before 37 weeks of pregnancy, are likely to have more health problems than those carried to term, including serious problems that affect the brain, lungs, vision, and hearing. Progesterone is a natural hormone that is involved in maintaining healthy pregnancies, and progesterone supplementation is the gold standard of treatment for women who are at high risk for premature birth. This project aims to develop an intravaginal ring device to supply bioidentical progesterone to the cervix and vaginal epithelia of at-risk women, to prevent preterm birth and improve neonatal outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The “brain-eating amoeba” Naegleria fowleri can migrate through narrow channels in the skull and within brain tissue, causing a rare but often-fatal form of encephalitis. While cell migration has been described in extensive detail in animal cells, Naegleria diverged from this lineage over a billion years ago—before plant and animal lineages diverged—and it is therefore unknown whether mechanisms underlying animal cell motility are conserved in Naegleria. The goals of this application are to define the molecular basis of Naegleria’s cell migration in environments that mimic the brain, thereby providing a foundation to understand how Naegleria and similar pathogens cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (AD/ADRD) are a major public health concern, costing over $321 Billion and affecting more than 6.5 million individuals in the United States alone, and these numbers will continue to grow with our aging population. The exact causes of AD/ADRD are unknown, although an important component involves dysfunction of regulatory brain cells, called inhibitory interneurons, and results in over-excitation and abnormal activity in brain circuits that serve memory and cognition. In our planned research, we aim to define the causes for inhibitory interneuron dysfunction and find ways to reverse this problem, advancing the mission of the NIH to decrease illness, reduce disability, and prolong life for AD/ADRD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastomas rank among the most lethal of human cancers with only palliation from current therapies, suggesting that novel therapies are needed. The proposed studies will investigate how aging promotes glioblastoma growth. To translate these findings into potential cancer therapies, combinations of drugs targeting these connections will be tested against glioblastomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SCN3A neurodevelopmental disorder is a devastating condition caused by mutation of the gene SCN3A (which encodes the sodium channel subunit Nav1.3) and is defined by treatment-resistant epilepsy, severe/profound intellectual disability, and malformation of cortical development, the latter being a surprising consequence of dysfunction of an ion channel. The objective of this proposal, which employs cutting-edge tools and innovative technical approaches in newly-generated advanced model systems, is to investigate the pathogenic mechanisms that underlie epilepsy and brain malformation in SCN3A neurodevelopmental disorder. The long- term objective of this research is to (1) understand the normal role of Nav1.3 in the function of developing neurons and (2) advance from preclinical models to mechanistically oriented treatments or preventative therapies in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorder (SUD) is characterize by recurrent drug-taking behavior that often resembles the renewal-induced relapse as the subjects are re-exposed to the original drug context, after a successful extinction-based treatment. Unfortunately, conventional extinction therapy and its adjunct medications have shown limited success in the clinic, perhaps due to a lack of understanding of the molecular mechanisms governing the transfer of the learned extinction memories from clinical to drug-associated contexts. Thus, my training plan is focused on understanding the impact of extinction-based therapy on reprogramming drug-associated memories, phenotypes and genome-wide transcriptional codes following extinction success, renewal-induced relapse, withdrawal and decision-making processes in a rodent model of cocaine self-administration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it is now possible to rapidly and efficiently characterize our genetic makeup to guide our health and healthcare, the routine use of our genetics in clinical care – what is known as “genomic medicine” – remains limited. In this project, the University of Utah (UU) and its Genomics Learning in the Utah Ecosystem (GLUE) Center will contribute to the establishment of a Genomics-Enabled Learning Health Systems Network that aims to spark the much wider implementation of genomic medicine, including for using our genetic makeup to identify what medications are likely to be most safe and effective to use; providing a chatbot-facilitated approach to enable widespread education and mail-in testing for genetic conditions that significantly increase our risk of common and potentially preventable diseases such as cancer and heart disease; and automatically identifying critically ill newborns who may benefit from genetic testing that identifies treatable causes for their life-threatening conditions. Ultimately, the UU GLUE Center aims to collaborate with like-minded peers across the nation to discover and disseminate the most effective and fair strategies for enabling genomic medicine at scale to improve health and healthcare in the United States and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) is the pre-cancerous and age-related expansion of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) often caused by acquired mutations in leukemia driver genes. While CH research has focused on risk of developing blood cancers such as acute myeloid leukemia (AML), having CH also increases the risk of inflammatory diseases. This project utilizes large genomic and clinical datasets to define CH-associated inflammatory disease outcomes, model risk of inflammatory comorbidity in CH and explore the use of hypomethylating agents as a therapeutic strategy to alleviate inflammation disease burden in CH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Elevated mental health problems have been documented in children of divorced families – over 8.1 million in the US – and in their parents. While behavioral parent training interventions, including digital interventions, have demonstrated success to reduce children's mental health problems, they have shown weaker effects in divorced parents with elevated psychological distress, and digital fully self-administered interventions have shown no effects to reduce the distress of divorced parents. By developing digital mindfulness training components and adding them to an existing evidence-based parenting intervention, as a combined, web- based, self-administered intervention, this project has great potential to maximize its reach and impact, reducing mental health problems in high-risk divorced families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The anesthetic ketamine is efficacious as a fast-acting antidepressant in patients with treatment refractory major depression, but its potential for long-term antidepressant use is limited by its abuse potential and capacity to produce dissociative effects. Ketamine is rapidly metabolized to a number of biologically active metabolites that are pharmacologically distinct from ketamine, including (2R,6R)-hydroxynorketamine, which in preclinical models, shares ketamine’s therapeutic effects without its side effects. We propose to utilize preclinical models including electrophysiological characterization of brain synapse function to further determine the relevant antidepressant- and side-effect profiles of ketamine’s hydroxynorketamine metabolites, which will lead to important mechanistic insights relevant to the development of next generation fast-acting antidepressants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This R35 application aims to harness the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) pathway and dendritic cell biology to restore and boost immune defense against cancer. We will focus on immune engineering of the molecular and cellular underpinnings of STING signaling by nanotechnology. Through our bench- to-clinic and back-to-bench approach, our goal is to identify and overcome existing biological and technological barriers impeding clinical progress, and ultimately apply these insights to establish a successful STING-targeted therapy in cancer patients unresponsive to current treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ADHD is a common and debilitating disorder that contributes to increased chance of deleterious risky behaviors that emerge or exacerbate in adolescence, leading to long-term negative outcomes such as addiction or incarceration. This supplement requests funds to complete MRI data collection for the parent grant, which consists of a comprehensive, longitudinal, multilevel (neural, behavioral, clinical) and multimodal (functional MRI, diffusion MRI) study in youth with ADHD across the transition to adolescence. By incorporating innovative brain network analytic tools and sophisticated longitudinal modeling techniques, this research will characterize developmental trajectories and identify childhood features that contribute to increased risk for negative outcomes in adolescence, leading to biomarker development for earlier detection of risk and more targeted treatment models for ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL  The mission of the Research and Engagement for Action on Climate and Health (REACH) Center is to bridge big data to climate solutions that advance health and environmental justice. Specifically, the Center leverages the power of novel geospatial datasets and research co-generation with governmental and non- governmental partners to research health and equity impacts of climate change mitigation and adaptation actions from local to global scales. Our ideal location in the National Capital Region, hosted at the only school of public health in Washington, DC, gives us unique opportunities to collaborate with the national-scale policy community, including the federal government and a plethora of civil society organizations engaged in climate and health policy development.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Climate change disproportionately affects individuals and communities experiencing social and environmental vulnerabilities and discrimination. There is a critical need for evidence-based solutions to reduce the impacts of the warming climate on marginalized communities to enable timely, effective, and impactful interventions. We propose to establish the Center for Climate: Equitable and Accessible Research-based Testing for Health (C- EARTH) to catalyze transdisciplinary research approaches involving individual- and policy-level solutions to address multiple climate risks to human health in high-risk and marginalized communities around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will collect data on the feasibility, acceptability, efficacy, and target engagement of a personalized treatment for eating disorders. The proposed research has significant public health relevance, as it will directly lead to a highly accessible and deployable personalized treatment that can improve treatment response rates and decrease the high societal burden associated with eating disorders. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s strategic aim 3.3b, as it will lead to the creation of a personalized treatment consistent with NIH’s precision treatment initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We previously that the neurotrophic factor BDNF in corticostriatal circuitry plays an important role in keeping alcohol drinking in moderation and that malfunction of BDNF and its receptor TrkB signaling promotes excessive and compulsive alcohol use. We recently generated data to suggest that malfunctioning of BDNF in the ventral hippocampus (vHP) promoted anxiogenesis, social anxiety and alcohol preference over social interaction. This proposal is aimed to examine the hypothesis that acutely alcohol activates BDNF/TrkB signaling in the vHP which promotes anxiolysis and social interaction whereas malfunctioning of BDNF/TrkB signaling in the vHP promotes anxiogenesis, social anxiety and alcohol preference vs. social interaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current approach to treatment of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)—a common, costly, and highly morbid infection—is inflexible and impersonal. The present approach increases side-effect risk, promotes drug- resistant infections, and under-treats many patients. This project aims to surmount barriers to personalizing VAP antibiotic treatment durations by identifying lung biomarkers that reliably identify cure of infection and creating novel VAP trial outcomes that inform bedside care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: At least 85% of colorectal cancer (CRC), the 2nd most frequent cause of cancer deaths worldwide, is due to microsatellite stable (MSS) CRC, which does not respond to immune checkpoint blockade (ICB), in contrast to microsatellite unstable (MSI-H), in which durable remissions are achieved with ICB. By combing single-cell RNA- sequencing (scRNA-seq), regional whole exome sequencing (WES), spatial transcriptomics (ST) and MxIF to enumerate consensus cell states and to project tumor programs and microenvironmental features onto progression pseudotime, we have identified an immune-exclusion IEX score in MSS CRC that consists of DDR1, TGFBi and DPEP1, which are markedly upregulated in plasma-derived small extracellullar vesicles (sEVs) and supermeres of CRC patients compared to healthy controls, and for which inhibitors are developed or being developed. In this R35 renewal, we propose to explore mechanisms by which these proteins promote tumorigenesis, develop them as liquid biomarkers, and introduce novel strategies to introduce inhibitors to them in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis and cannabis-derived products are reported to be commonly used as sleep aids, yet little is known about the chronic effects of cannabis use on circadian rhythms and sleep architecture, or risk for developing cannabis use disorder (CUD). This proposal will use a rodent model and human postmortem brain tissue to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the bidirectional relationship between circadian rhythms and cannabis use. A better understanding of these relationships will not only provide insights into the neurobiology of cannabis use, but also the identification of novel therapeutic targets and treatment strategies for both CUD and sleep disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The improving Health and Housing Outcomes through a Simulation and Economic (iHOUSE) Model is an agent-based model simulating the dynamic processes contributing to HIV incidence, overdose , and life expectancy among people along the housing and homelessness continuum of care in Denver, CO and San Francisco, CA. The project will use a Group Model Building process to engage community stakeholders in the scientific process and inform the structure of the model. The iHOUSE Model will be used to investigate potential combinations of HIV and substance use service delivery programs that are most beneficial for improving health outcomes at various steps in the housing continuum, how those compare to a housing- centered strategies, and their effectiveness at reducing racial/ethnic health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Biliary atresia and primary sclerosing cholangitis are conditions that can progress to end-stage liver disease requiring liver transplantation to avoid death in approximately 50% of affected children, as effective treatments aimed at the underlying etiology do not exist. Liver transplantation requires significant public health resources including the generosity of donors, complex multi-disciplinary medical research teams, and significant amounts of finances to be successful. Additional research is needed to understand pathophysiology and treatment targets for these diseases, to minimize the progression to liver transplantation or death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE Climate change greatly increases the risk that new viral diseases will spillover from animals into people, and it greatly increases the spread of diseases carried by ticks or mosquitoes to new areas. Preventing the outbreak of disease before it occurs is the best way to protect the public’s health. Working in both South Africa and New York State with vulnerable rural communities who are most at risk, we propose to integrate social, biological and climate data into models that can predict when outbreaks occur, so that we can design interventions to prevent them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Drug abuse is an enormous public health challenge; human genetics studies have identified a significant genetic contribution to the risk of developing drug abuse. Rodent genetic studies are vital to understanding the molecular genetic basis of drug abuse, but are hampered by an incomplete catalogue of potentially causative genetic variants. In this project, we will examine two important but understudied sources of genetic variation: structural variants and tandem repeats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing technologies to diagnose people with abnormal bleeding. Once such technologies have been developed, there is the potential to better define origins of disease and responses to drugs. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to seeking fundamental knowledge about the nature of living systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with HIV (PWH) use cannabis more than the general population, but its potential beneficial/negative effects on the brain have not been investigated. Here, we will determine whether cannabis has beneficial or negative effects on cognitive functions strongly linked to HIV risk behaviors in PWH compared with healthy participants. We will then utilize an animal model of HIV to determine the directionality of effects of acute and chronic administration, withdrawal from such cannabinoid treatments, as well as effects of antiretroviral therapy using consistent behavioral tests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Interrogating the cholinergic basis of opioid use disorder Here, we propose to develop, characterize, and deploy a comprehensive toolset focused on opioid neuropharmacology. We will test the hypothesis that μORs on cholinergic interneurons mediate harmful effects of opioids, independent of therapeutic analgesic effects. The proposed technologies will offer the unprecedented opportunity to establish causal behavioral roles of opioid neuropharmaceuticals mediated by defined cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The proposed research will investigate the impact of THC on extracellular vesicle signaling in the brain and periphery. It is predicted that extracellular vesicles will contain differential profiles of cargo in response to varying THC exposures and in the presence of nicotine co-exposure. By providing fundamental insights into novel extracellular mechanisms with THC, findings from these studies may thereby identify biomarkers and targets for the development of efficacious therapeutics to treat dependence in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Adolescents in residential substance use treatment have high risk of relapse after discharge, but it is extremely difficult to engage these adolescents and their parents in continuing care. This study aims to improve the outcomes of adolescents following discharge from residential substance use treatment by offering their parents a novel technology-assisted intervention. Technology-assisted interventions have the potential for marked public health impact by extending the reach, duration, and scalability of evidence-based care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most young adult (<30 years old) people who inject drugs (PWID) –who are the group at greatest risk for hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection—do not initiate available curative therapy. Building on our extensive foundation of dyadic research and dyadic behavior change theories, we developed the Partner Navigation Intervention a two-session injecting partnership intervention to enhance dyadic capacity for HCV treatment initiation for young adult PWID. The proposed study is a randomized controlled study (RCT) to assess the efficacy and mechanism of action of the first behavioral intervention to increase HCV treatment initiation among young adult PWID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Established smoking cessation medications effectively treat withdrawal symptoms but do little to address the powerful influence that cues and contexts have on smoking behavior. Across both basic and clinical research, β-adrenergic medications have demonstrated potential to reduce these influences by disrupting the key cognitive processes that unfold when smoking cues and contexts are encountered. This project will use neuroimaging to determine the effects of these medications on brain responses to smoking cues and contexts in human cigarette smokers, providing vital information on the mechanisms responsible for their effect and informing further treatment development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because our ability to diagnose and treat drug abuse and addiction is critically dependent on fundamental understanding of brain networks altered by drugs of abuse and associated signaling pathways. The research described in this proposal will establish a new system to study how cannabinoid signaling impacts intact brains at cellular resolution that culminate in affecting elemental motivated behavior. If successful, it will pave a way to uncover principles of neural circuit development and dynamics, bridge a critical gap between molecules and systems impact associated with drugs of abuse, and shape policy and treatment strategies for drug abuse disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioids cause many changes in the brain, some of which underlie substance use disorder, but most of which merely reflect exposure to drug, including benefits such as pain relief. Identifying the neural substrates underlying the pathologic side effects of opioid use, and disentangling them from the beneficial effects of opioid drugs in particular, will be critical for intervening in the opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A necessary step in the development of improved OUD therapeutics is to understand the architecture and function of endogenous opioid receptor-expressing neural circuits in the brain. Despite extensive research, how these circuits maintain cellular dependence and drive brain-wide maladaptive plasticity across different stages of the addiction cycle is unclear. To address these gaps, we will map the global cell-type identity, shifting connectivity, and ensemble activity of the opioidergic networks throughout various stages of addiction. Our team-driven project will create an integrated, rapidly searchable database to be mined by other researchers to accelerate the pace of OUD research and future development of new OUD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research under this grant is aimed to decode a biochemical pathway all cells use under starvation conditions, which is frequently deregulated in cancer. This starvation pathway contains a gene called LKB1 that is mutated in about 20% of lung cancers, for which there are limited effective treatment options available. By studying normal functions of the starvation pathway in growth limitation and metabolic preservation, new therapeutic targets for treating this common form of lung cancer will be identified and experimentally tested.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Childhood glaucoma is an important cause of pediatric blindness worldwide, and particularly in countries such as India where many affected patients may be undiagnosed and treatment options are limited. Genetic testing while potentially useful, currently can only detect molecular diagnoses in 20% of childhood glaucoma cases worldwide. This project will complete large-scale genetic profiling of childhood glaucoma in India to improve genetic testing through discovery of novel genetic causality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The research team will work with providers, staff, management and patients at Cherokee Nation Health Services to culturally adapt and evaluate Counseling for Harm Reduction and Retention in MAT with Cherokee Nation (CHaRRM-CN). In the short-term, this project is positioned to make a strong, individual-level impact by increasing MAT retention, reducing substance-related harm and illicit opioid use, and increasing Native enculturation. This project may have a broader impact on public health by reducing substance-related harm and associated strain on publicly funded services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Arrhythmias are a major cause of US mortality with ventricular fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and atrial fibrillation resulting in 430,000 annual deaths. Although catheter ablation is a proven treatment option, as reinforced by the HRS/EHRA/ECAS/APHRS/SOLAECE Expert Consensus Statement, control of ablation catheters can be complex, resulting in imprecise and unreliable heart-wall contact leading to an increased likelihood of injury and arrhythmia recurrence. UNandUP (short for “Unmet Needs and Underserved Populations”) is developing an affordable angiosuite compatible platform which uses low magnetic fields to overcome prior limitations related to electrophysiology catheter navigational accuracy, stability, and applied forces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Young people living with HIV in adolescence through emerging adulthood (ages 16-28 years) have the lowest rates of regular engagement in HIV care and adherence to HIV medications of any age group, with Black and Latinx individuals experiencing the greatest barriers to favorable HIV health outcomes. To provide a detailed understanding of the factors that promote or impede HIV management in this group, we will follow Black and Latinx youth/emerging adults living with HIV, half with optimal HIV health outcomes at enrollment (undetectable HIV viral load) and half without, for 18 months. Participants will engage in structured assessments, in-depth qualitative interviews, real-time ecological momentary assessments in two-week bursts, and biological tests (HIV viral load tests, drug tests), and a Youth Advisory Board comprised of youth living with HIV will help interpret findings in order to inform new policies, health care service practices, and interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults who survive a non-fatal firearm injury risk revictimization and the adoption of protective firearm-related behaviors in adulthood. Due to the perpetuating use of firearms in communities, it is imperative to understand the long-term impact of injury to psychosocial and behavioral health. We will identify risk and protective factors for repeat victimization and increased firearm-related behaviors, and, through mixed methods, we will explore the characteristics of latent patient subgroups that will provide the foundation for developing hospital-based violence intervention programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The NASH CRN's mission is to transform scientific discoveries from laboratory, clinical, and population studies into clinical applications to reduce the incidence and improve clinical outcomes in metabolic dysfunction- associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD). The consortium is dedicated to completing two ongoing studies and utilizing existing data and biosamples for further scientific advancements. The Duke/Lurie Children's Memorial site will focus on accelerated senescence in both adult and pediatric MASLD, translating experimental findings into practical applications for future clinical interventions and preventive measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance As the proportion of older adults in the population continues to expand, magnifying the relative impact of their decisions, it is increasingly imperative to better understand changes in decision making across the life span before and throughout all stages of significant cognitive impairment related to Alzheimers Disease and related dementias. Increasing interdisciplinary research combining psychology, neuroscience/neurology, medicine, and economics has tremendous potential for increasing translation of science for real-world impact to better understand and alleviate the burden of Alzheimers Disease and related dementias. The long-term goal of this network is to conduct integrative and multidisciplinary research that contributes directly to interventions aimed at improving health and well being in the daily lives of aging adults.
