IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Equity and Climate Opportunities for Health (ECO-Health) Center at the University of California will generate rigorous scientific evidence about how climate change leads to poor health outcomes within communities that are heavily impacted by structural injustices. The Center will also partner with these communities to use this evidence to co-develop and co-implement climate adaptation interventions that improve health and reduce health inequities. Ultimately, the ECO-Health Center will help generate equitable solutions that build resilience to the health risks of climate change in California communities and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) is the leading cause of death in patients with refractory epilepsy and thus a major public health problem. Seizures may impair arousal to important stimuli, such as CO2, to contribute to SUDEP. Understanding mechanisms for impairment of CO2-arousal in relevant animal models will importantly inform risk stratification and prophylactic strategies against this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: To reduce harm related to high-risk alcohol use and negative consequences among young adults, researchers and preventionists have targeted normative misperceptions regarding the drinking behaviors of other young adults (i.e., norm-correcting interventions). The proposed project will develop and pilot test an innovative paradigm for leveraging social norms within brief interventions that entails user customization of which (and how many) normative referent groups they receive feedback for (e.g., drinking norms for sexual minoritized peers) so that the content is meaningful and engaging to all users, including historically marginalized groups. With proof-of-concept support that this novel intervention paradigm is feasible (i.e., acceptability, engagement, interest), efficacious relative to the standard PNF and attention-matched control conditions, and equitable for historically marginalized groups, this R34 project is anticipated to propel a line of research that could yield paradigm-enhancing discoveries pertaining to norms-based alcohol interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and its more severe form, non-alcoholic steatohepatitis are now termed metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease/steatohepatitis to focus on the underlying causal mechanisms. In this term-limited renewal, we will complete the ongoing prospective cohort studies (database) in children and adults (to define the natural course of NAFLD), and the vitamin E dosing study (VEDS) to identify the lowest effective therapeutic dose of vitamin E for NASH. Additionally, we will utilize existing multimodal data repositories to identify novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets for severity of NAFLD and sarcopenia using integrated multiomics analyses of clinical, genetic, transcriptomic, proteomic, histological, and imaging data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The findings reported in Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) are increasingly used to develop Polygenic Scores (PGS) to predict phenotypes and disease risk. Non-Europeans are severely underrepresented in GWAS data, and European-derived PGS have poor predictive performance when used to predict phenotypes of individuals of non-European ancestry. In this project, we will develop novel Transfer Learning algorithms to develop PGS for ancestries underrepresented in GWAS data that will leverage the large sample size available for Europeans and the diversity of the recently developed All of Us program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Genomic medicine has long been recognized as having the potential to improve population health, but it has not become routine, equitably distributed healthcare. Rigorous evaluations of how genomic medicine interventions are implemented across diverse healthcare settings are necessary to realize the population health potential of genomic medicine. We propose to contribute our expertise in genomic medicine, implementation science and learning health systems as a Clinical Site in the Network of Genomics-Enabled Learning Health Systems, advancing the goal of improving population health by making genomic medicine routine across all healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) affects one in three adults in North America and rates of liver-, cardiovascular-, and cancer- related complications on the rise. The NASH CRN has made landmark contributions to the field, but knowledge gaps remain. In this funding cycle, the CRN will complete longitudinal follow-up of adult and pediatric participants and the vitamin E dosing finding study and leverage the available clinical, histologic, radiologic, social, contextual, genetic, proteomic, and metabolomic data to better understand disease progression, improve diagnostic and prognostic precision and ultimately, improve the outcomes of persons with MASLD.

PHR: Project Narrative Climate change is a fundamental threat to human health and well-being. While its effects are already being felt, the effects of climate change are expected to intensify over the coming decades. The overall goal of this exploratory grant is to develop a climate change and health research center to explore the dynamics between health and climate change-driven exposures to heat, pathogenic microbes, and environmental toxicants, and to develop novel interventions that promote resiliency in vulnerable populations.

PHR: Project Narrative: The importance of mechanosensitive channels to human health is underscored by the association of many disease states with compromised mechanosensation, including atrial fibrillation, muscular degeneration, arrhythmias, polycystic kidney disease, and numerous neural diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: TRANSCEND-Overall  Overall Narrative The TRANSCEND CTR is a center for training and research in clinical and translational research (applied research to prevent or treat disease) in North Dakota. TRANSCEND is an acronym for Translational Science Engaging North Dakota. It employs innovative programs that combine clinicians, basic biomedical researchers, and infrastructure in North Dakota universities and hospitals to do impactful research on diseases that disproportionately affect people in North Dakota. TRANSCEND is an academic/clinical/community partnership in which different communities, including minority communities, are involved directly in the planning, performing, and utilization of research findings. Its overall goal is to increase the size of the research workforce whose skills can improve the health of people in North Dakota and the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorder is the consequence of altered neural circuit function and is an epidemic that causes an extraordinary amount of death and human suffering. This proposal seeks to determine the activity dynamics and causal function of subpopulations of lateral hypothalamic area neurons throughout the development and expression of motivation for opioids. At the conclusion of this proposal, we will gain deeper insight into the spatiotemporal dynamics during motivation for opioids that will inform future research into targeted therapeutics for treating opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia proposes to continue our participation in the ChiLDReN consortium, a group of pediatric centers working together to study rare pediatric liver diseases. These diseases are important causes of suffering and death in children, but they are so rare that only by collaborating can we hope to improve outcomes for these children. The ChiLDReN study protocols involve collection of longitudinal data and biospecimens that can be leveraged for new discoveries of biomarkers and genetic etiology of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Clonal hematopoeisis (CH) is a premalignant condition that is strongly associated with aging, inflammation, cardiovascular disease and mortality from all causes. The three proteins most frequently mutated in CH are TET2, DNMT3A and ASXL1. We will test the hypothesis that mutations in all three proteins are linked to reduced levels of two epigenetic marks, DNA and H3K9 methylation. We will also test the hypothesis that a fourth protein, OGT, links TET2 and ASXL1. Our studies will illuminate the mechanistically elusive connections between DNA and H3K9 methylation, cancer, inflammation and aging, and will improve our understanding of heterochromatin, a compartment of the genome that is very poorly understood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This R41 proposes to develop a prototype mobile health (mHealth) app, R-Assist, by a cross-disciplinary small business and academic team. R-Assist will be the first mHealth product designed specifically for individuals with co-occurring opioid use and mental health disorders (COD) during the vulnerable time of leaving jail and transitioning to the community to provide on-demand, 24/7 support to improve COD symptoms and recovery, and address social determinant of health needs. App feature development will be guided by the self- determination theory, and it will undergo initial field testing using an agile iterative design followed by an open pilot with clients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to create two short format, introductory, modular, Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (miniCUREs) based on computational genomics and data science (CGDS) content (RNA-seq and the human microbiome) using the NIH cloud computing platform AnVIL. The AnVIL-based miniCUREs will be piloted at 5 institutions, including two Hispanic Serving Institutions and one Tribal College prior to public release, to allow for evaluation and revision. The miniCUREs can then be used by everyone from 2 year colleges to Master’s programs to improve student’s knowledge and experience in research of CGDS topics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Our goal is to better understand the emergence of adolescent substance use behaviors by testing the hypothesis that music engagement is associated with less substance use initiation and less frequent substance use. There is already evidence that music engagement interventions are effective for individuals with substance use disorders, and there are multiple reasons to expect these beneficial effects could extend to substance initiation in adolescence. By integrating state-of-the art genetic and longitudinal approaches that address key confounds, this work will quantify these potentially protective associations and provide critical groundwork for translational and intervention efforts targeted at supporting high-risk individuals before the onset of problematic substance use.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Pancreatic cancer is a deadly cancer with increasing incidence for which no systematic efforts to reduce diagnostic delays exist. Our preliminary work shows that 40% of Veterans with pancreatic cancer experience diagnostic delays of  90 days and 40% experience missed opportunities to initiate or complete their diagnostic evaluation in a timely manner. Opportunities for more timely diagnosis of pancreatic cancer are possible in the VA, and the work put forth in this proposal tries to identify and transform these opportunities into decision support tools. In this project, we will: (1) identify potential missed opportunities for pancreatic cancer diagnosis; (2) develop electronic trigger (e-trigger) tools aimed at identifying high-risk patients with potential missed opportunities for pancreatic cancer diagnosis; and (3) assess local stakeholders’ views of facilitators and barriers to implementation of e-triggers for future application in clinical practice. These aims will be aligned with career development and training activities including formal coursework and a structured mentorship plan.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: There are about 40,000 Veterans experiencing homelessness, and another 300,000 at risk. Their health is generally poor, and their lives are shortened by 10 to 20 years. This project seeks to improve homeless Veterans' access to healthcare services and treatments. To do this, it is important to better understand Veterans' transitions into homelessness, or from one unstable situation to the next, such as from cohabiting with family or a friend to living in a homeless shelter. The knowledge of these transitions, especially from the perspective of the individuals experiencing them – such as their in-the-moment emotions, behaviors, and geographic movements, could inform interventions that prevent Veterans' rapid deterioration in housing or in health. This study examines the usefulness of smartphones to collect information from Veterans in near real- time as the transitions are occurring. It will lead to new programs for Veterans at risk of or experiencing homelessness to assist them before housing instability worsens, and before health crises occur.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Rates of sexually transmitted infection (STI), especially gonorrhea and chlamydia, have increased dramatically over the past decade. However, screening remains suboptimal. Women are more vulnerable to the effects of STIs than men and are disproportionately affected by STIs. Several factors put women Veterans at higher risk for STIs as compared with both non-Veteran women and male Veterans. Few studies have examined the epidemiology of STIs in women Veterans and none has assessed health system responses to STIs or examined patterns of STI screening among women Veterans. To establish an appropriate and effective prevention plan, it is necessary to understand the current landscape of STI screening in VA. This study will assess and explore practice-, provider-, and patient-level correlates and barriers/facilitators to gonorrhea and chlamydia screening in VA women’s health. This information will be used to develop and pilot a clinical decision support tool to improve gonorrhea and chlamydia screening for women Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Cognitive processing therapy (CPT) and prolonged exposure therapy (PE) were widely disseminated as recommended posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) treatments. However, post-9/11 Veterans with PTSD rarely initiate CPT or PE, especially as an initial treatment. Little research has explored the combinations and sequences of psychosocial and medication treatments that Veterans receive (“treatment sequences”). One common and understudied treatment sequence begins with stabilization treatment, which is designed to prepare Veterans for CPT or PE. There is a significant research gap in understanding how treatment sequence affects initiation of CPT or PE. The proposed research is an innovative, mixed-methods approach to assessing the impact of variability in treatment sequence, including stabilization treatment, on initiation of CPT or PE and applying this knowledge by developing a health services intervention that facilitates timely transition to CPT or PE. Research aims can improve PTSD treatment by increasing initiation of and reducing disparities in CPT/PE.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the most common cause of death in Veterans. CVD-related deaths are over twice as likely in patients with comorbid alcohol misuse, due in part to alcohol misuse directly exacerbating several modifiable factors that lead to CVD. 9-32% of all Veterans are in this high-risk, preventable population of comorbid alcohol misuse and elevated, modifiable CVD risk. No treatments have targeted this population. Current VA/DoD treatment guidelines for comorbid alcohol misuse in primary care are ineffective. Because alcohol misuse is often a recurrent problem, and the dominant driver of treatment recommendations, timely treatment of these Veterans’ CVD risk in conjunction with alcohol misuse treatment in may be critical for developing clinical traction with CVD risk. This research is highly relevant to Veteran health, VHA priorities, and HSR&D priorities because the combined intervention targets and telehealth approaches address critical gaps in treatment timeliness and access for this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Sarah L. Krein, PhD, RN is an active and productive health services and nurse researcher. She uses her clinical knowledge and research expertise to conduct and collaborate on studies to improve healthcare safety, quality, and effectiveness as well as Veteran health outcomes. She also works with clinician and non-clinician scientists who are beginning their research careers, assisting them in learning new research skills and supporting them as they move on to leading their own research studies. The support provided by the VA senior research career scientist award will allow her to continue to use her research expertise and experience to continue conducting research that improves VA healthcare delivery and patient safety, educate new researchers, work with local, national and international collaborators and contribute to activities that support the VA research, education and care delivery missions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Adolescence is an “age of risk” for the emergence of major depressive disorder (MD), a major public health problem. Using an innovative biobehavioral high-risk approach with a prospective longitudinal design, this application will examine bidirectional relationships between peripheral inflammation and multimodal reward function and their joint prediction of first onset of MD and increases in depression symptoms, particularly anhedonia. It will provide critical tools for identifying vulnerabilities to MD, integrate two separate research traditions to increase our understanding of specific etiological pathways underlying MD, and facilitate development of behavioral and biological interventions for ameliorating reward processing and inflammatory abnormalities that contribute to MD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Administrative Supplement application is to establish a fully reliable learning management system (LMS) and the corresponding research database needed to fulfill the aims of our current 5-year randomized controlled trial to determine how best to sustain knowledge about child abuse and its reporting. This LMS and research database (which will include research data dashboards, analytic functionality, and multiple reporting modalities) will support iLookOut's evidence-based mandated reporter training and follow-up interactive micro-learning course about how to protect at-risk children and support them and their families. In so doing, this supplement also will help ensure continued nationwide delivery of iLookOut programs to Head Start through the end of the grant period (anticipated to be July 31, 2027).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preteen suicide is a growing public health crisis, and the substantially greater risk for suicidal thoughts and behaviors reported among sexual and gender minority (SGM) preteens is concerning. Consistent with NIMH programmatic priorities, this project will deploy an innovative mixed-methods approach incorporating advisory board and expert feedback, measurement development, and longitudinal data collection and analysis to study risk and protective factors for suicide in SGM preteens. Given the disproportionate risk for suicide among SGM preteens and the dearth of prospective research involving this high-risk population, this project represents a novel scientific advancement to inform suicide prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to the public health because the incidence of Crohn’s disease (CD) is on the rise, represents a major cost measured by both patient quality of life and economic burden. Genome-wide association studies have identified >100 susceptibility loci for CD, and functional studies to determine the role of these susceptibility genes are needed to develop new therapies. We propose to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which LRRK2 (a recently identified CD susceptibility gene) affects gut innate immunity, and how additional CD-relevant gene-environment interaction can activate LRRK2 kinase.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is growing evidence linking age-related hearing loss (ARHL) with cognitive impairment and the increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. Recent research demonstrated an association between the severity of hearing loss and disability in routine daily activities. The goal of this study is to understand the effect of cochlear implants and hearing aids using real-world data documenting daily performance in study subjects’ natural environments to prevent the onset of cognitive impairment, or progression from mild cognitive impairment to dementia in people with ARHL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our overall goal is to uncover the etiology of prostate cancer racial disparities for African American prostate cancer patients. We expect that the rDNA clock will become a valuable surveillance marker to assess risk of early onset prostate cancer African American cancer patients, and the research proposed here will provide evidence to support the wider application of the rDNA clock as a biomarker to monitor the risk of age-associated disease in this unique population of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  An increase in the concentration of reactive oxygen species has been thought to be a mechanism promoting development of the biology of aging for over half a century, however, technical limitations have until recently substantially limited investigation of this hypothesis. This proposal will develop preliminary findings that identified specific targets of reactive oxygen species which influence aging phenotypes through post-translational regulation of proteins by cysteine oxidation. Upon completion, this study will establish mechanism(s) and produce resources outlining how reactive oxygen species influence the biology of aging which can leveraged to develop new strategies to promote healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Focal cortical dysplasia (FCD) is a common cortical malformation associated with medically refractory epilepsy and most frequently caused by variants in subunits of the GATOR1 complex (a negative regulator of mTOR): DEPDC5, NPRL3, and NPRL2. The least studied of these variants is NPRL2 and in this proposal we aim to define the pathophysiological consequences of Nprl2 KO in vivo and in vitro. Using a mouse model of FCD we will define the morphological and functional changes that occur due to Nprl2 KO-induced mTOR pathway hyperactivation as well as investigate the transcriptomic changes that occur downstream of mTORC1 that may produce MCD and seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of objective, clinically relevant brain-based biomarkers of social engagement hinders our ability to test novel interventions and treatments to improve functioning in autistic children. The proposed study will test how several promising measures of brain activity in young, autistic children relate to core features such as social attention, social interaction with caregivers, and standardized clinical assessments of social communication functioning. Results from this study will give us tools to better understand heterogeneity in autism as well as more effectively evaluate response to therapies and treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The R21 project collects and analyzes high-frequency data on within-year changes in debt holdings and self-reported health. Short-term fluctuations in debt may be an independent determinant of poor health that is currently missing from our understanding of how financial standing impacts health inequalities. Our proposed study will be the first to capture within-year debt fluctuations and evaluate their relationship to generalized stress, anxiety, and depression; findings will inform policies to support the health and well-being of lower-income populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Cholestatic liver diseases are a significant source of morbidity and mortality in infants and children. Because these diseases are rare, a multicenter collaborative network such as the Childhood Liver Disease Research Network is necessary to accumulate a sufficient cohort to understand the causes, natural histories of rare liver diseases and develop new therapies to treat them. The proposed Clinical Center will continue to enroll and longitudinally follow eligible participants and contribute biospecimens and relevant data. These studies will broaden the scientific understanding of the etiology, natural history, and biology of liver disease, improve therapy for these disorders, and further the aims of the Childhood Liver Disease Research Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Pathological activation of intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) is implicated in exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but the mechanisms that suppresses IEL activation during intestinal inflammation remain unknown. I discovered the novel regulatory roles of Aiolos, a transcription factor encoded by Ikzf3, in IEL activation, and this project will investigate how Aiolos-deficient IELs modulate host responses to gut inflammation. This proposed project could advance our understanding of the pathogenesis of IBD and may eventually identify novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There are currently limited treatment options for improving endothelial dysfunction in vascular diseases, a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. Activated Protein C (APC) is a promising therapeutic that promotes multiple cytoprotective effects including stabilization of endothelial barriers, anti-inflammatory responses and anti-apoptotic activities. The proposed research is important because it will advance the status of APC by understanding the mechanism by which APC activation of protease-activated receptor-1 promotes endothelial cytoprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Complex human diseases have both environmental and genetic contributors. While many independent genetic associations have been identified, missing is our understanding of how environmental exposures modify these associations. We propose here to use APOL1-mediated kidney disease as a model and eventual framework to identify these “second hits” that distinguish true at-risk patients from APOL1 renal risk variant carriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synthetic opioids like fentanyl have surpassed prescription and other illicit opioids as the primary substances used by people with opioid use disorder (OUD) and are the leading causes of fatal opioid overdose. The most common complaints of patients with OUD are disruptions to sleep and circadian rhythms, speculated to contribute to craving and relapse to opioids. Our proposal will dissect the intricate roles of circadian rhythms in key neuronal subpopulations of the striatum crucial in the regulation of opioid craving and relapse, providing new targets for the development of more effective OUD treatments.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-acquired pneumonia is a leading cause of hospitalization for children; these children are often treated with intravenous antibiotics despite emerging evidence that oral antibiotics are safe and effective. Oral antibiotics offer many benefits compared to intravenous treatment including decreased intravenous-related harms, improved patient experience by decreasing children’s pain and anxiety, and decreased hospital length of stay, resource utilization, and costs. The proposed research aims to develop and test a set of implementation strategies to increase the use of oral (and reduce intravenous) antibiotics and improve patient outcomes, which aligns with AHRQ’s aims to accelerate the spread of evidence-based practices and help healthcare systems and frontline clinicians deliver high-quality, safe, and high-value care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing antibiotic stewardship to improve the care of children hospitalized with pneumonia

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Research into the genetic factors influencing the functioning of the human intestine contributes to fundamental knowledge about the intricate physiology of living systems. By unraveling the drivers of development of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), this research enhances understanding of how intestinal physiology and function are regulated to maintain homeostasis. In the long term, it paves the way for precise therapies that could significantly improve the well-being, longevity, and quality of life for individuals with IBD, addressing a major health concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 1 million Americans aged 20 years or older are diagnosed with heart failure and cardiomyopathy annually. The current method of identifying the cause of cardiomyopathy involves assessing the presence of coronary artery disease, which is flawed and may not always accurately identify the underlying cause of myocardial disease. By testing the hypothesis that a myocardial approach using cardiac magnetic resonance imaging is superior to a coronary approach, our work could lead to improved recognition of the cause of cardiomyopathy and consequently, better clinical outcomes through appropriate cause-specific treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diseases in children that impair the liver’s ability to secrete bile (e.g. biliary atresia) are the leading indication for liver transplantation in childhood. Multi-centered prospective investigations are essential to improve the health of children afflicted by these disorders. The clinical center at Baylor College of Medicine and Texas Children’s Hospital is ideally suited to participate in these prospective investigations and proposes investigations to improve outcomes in biliary atresia and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Dentists are a leading prescriber of opioids to young people, which have a particularly high risk of misusing opioids, developing a substance use disorder, or overdosing. Efforts to reduce dental opioid prescribing commonly use single interventions, do not specifically target young people, and are performed primarily in academic settings. This large study will test whether a bundled intervention of academic detailing, patient education, and non-opioid blister packs for distribution reduces opioid prescriptions to adolescents and young adults after tooth extraction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent technology developments have made it possible to measure biomarkers for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) in blood with high accuracy, allowing for minimally invasive detection of disease pathology for early diagnosis and to follow change over time. Collection of venous blood through phlebotomy is, however, still a medical procedure performed by trained staff requiring scheduled in-person visits in clinic, or more rarely at- home, followed by sample processing in a timely manner. We will investigate and validate the use of dried blood spots (DBS), which can be collected at home by study participants themselves and be sent to the lab by mail, to measure blood-based biomarkers of AD and determine the intra-individual short-term stability of biomarkers in repeated DBS samples to provide a baseline for incorporation in clinical trials as well as in longitudinal and epidemiological observational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to remain a member of the Childhood Liver Disease Research Network (ChiLDReN) and to be a key contributor to the strong research infrastructure that enables translational science and clinical trials in children with biliary atresia, cholestatic syndromes, mitochondrial hepatopathies, and primary sclerosing cholangitis. We propose to investigate the role of the TNF superfamily member TWEAK in progression of biliary fibrosis and to determine the short-term efficacy and safety of treatment with systemic FXR agonist in pediatric PSC. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Heavy episodic drinking (HED) in the early postpartum period is a critical public health problem that can interfere with a mother’s ability to care for her baby, and is associated with increased risk for child abuse and neglect and poor long-term child health and developmental outcomes. Postpartum mothers are often not connected to formal service systems, and often do not receive needed help for HED due to the stigma associated with substance use in mothers and fears of child protective services involvement if they disclose alcohol use to a professional. The proposed R34 will develop and test an innovative approach to reaching postpartum mothers to address HED that combines synchronous and asynchronous texting with a professional with automated messaging to deliver evidence-based brief interventions through an existing helpline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Sepsis affects millions and kills hundreds of thousands of Americans annually. Currently, no therapy exists to stabilize the deleterious response of the host to invasive infection. In this application, we propose to conduct research on a molecular pathway that appears to be highly promising for enabling clinicians to individualize treatment decisions in the intensive care unit. This project proposes new ways of understanding genetic risk factors in the Tie2 pathway and their influence on the wide spectrum of sepsis manifestations in order to move our community closer to the promise of personalized medicine in the intensive care unit.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Targeting tissue-specific genes is a challenging task due to their critical role in maintaining tissue homeostasis and physiology, but it can also offer an opportunity to achieve effective and safer therapeutic interventions. We propose to discern tissue-specific genes functionality and targetability in dieases by assessing their utility in biological networks. Thus, the purpose of this proposal is to increase the clinical utility of NIH Common Funds datasets by constructing a Common Fund Gene Utility Compendium and facilitate the discovery of druggable tissue-specific genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this project is to develop an open-source electromagnetic simulation suite for radiofrequency coil design and modeling in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Novel computational electromagnetics methods will be developed and combined with optimization routines and tensor decompositions to allow efﬁcient simula- tions of realistic MRI setups for brain and body imaging at any operating frequency. The proposed suite will be used for the rational design, optimization, assessment, and construction of a novel coil array for prostate imaging at 7T MRI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Many people with opioid use disorder have great difficulty accessing treatment, and telemedicine for opioid use disorder (“tele-OUD”) is one potential solution. The federal government, states, and health plans have implemented new policies to encourage greater tele-OUD use. PHR: NOFO: RFA-HG-23-002 Title: Developing an Innovative Genomic Data Science Curriculum: Interdisciplinary Modules for Undergraduate Education Project Narrative This project will increase participation in genomic data science research by community college Black and Latino/a/x students, who are historically underrepresented in this field. The hallmark of this project is that students will be able to contribute to the field of health disparities while learning highly marketable skills in genomic data science, including R coding and cloud computing, while building their knowledge in genomics. Ultimately, this project gives students a real-life, multidisciplinary lens through which to find their fit in contributing to better health outcomes for the communities in which they live and work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite optimization of intensive multi-agent chemotherapy regimens, infants with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), most often characterized by chromosomal rearrangements involving KMT2A (KMT2A-R), have aggressive disease and dismal outcomes. Chimeric antigen receptor T cells targeting CD19 (CD19CART) have demonstrated unprecedented efficacy in children with relapsed or refractory pediatric ALL; however, many CD19CART-treated patients will experience ALL relapse after initial response. This study aims to improve immunotherapeutic treatment of KMT2A-R ALL by investigating rational combinatorial therapeutic approaches with CD19CART and small molecule inhibitors that target key biologic vulnerabilities of this high-risk pediatric leukemia subtype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative TMJ diseases affect approximately 10% of adults in the United States alone. Osteophytes, referred to as fibrocartilage-capped bony spurs, are one of the radiographic hallmarks of TMJ degenerative disease, causing skeletal deformities, chronic pain, and limited condylar movement. This project aims to clarify further the mechanisms of osteophyte pathogenesis and to test specific therapeutic treatments to prevent the formation of TMJ osteophytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Suicide among Black preteens has reached epidemic proportions and is a tremendous public health concern. Here, we propose to study the epidemiology and course of preteen suicidal ideation and behaviors (SIB), as well as individual-specific and contextual risk and protective factors associated with this course, over 4 years in a sample of ~ 1,000 urban, economically disadvantaged Black youth. Findings from the current study may inform etiological models of SIB in this vulnerable population and yield actionable knowledge regarding developmentally- and culturally relevant intervention targets to curb SIB among Black preteens.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This project will identify patient-prioritized, equity-informative measures of health care quality in primary care and incorporate them into existing quality improvement (QI) dashboards. Furthermore, identified priority measures will inform the community-engaged design of interventions to decrease racial and ethnic health inequity. The goal is to generate QI metrics meaningful to both patients and providers useful to inform and measure health equity improvement strategies in primary care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A patient-informed approach to measuring and mitigating inequity in primary care

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE: The lack of validated pediatric risk prediction tools for emergency medical services (EMS) is a significant problem, resulting in under-triage (where children with urgent medical needs are left at the scene) and over-triage (where children with no urgent resource needs are taken by ambulance to an emergency department). This mentored career development award seeks to address this problem by identifying patient factors associated with under-triage, then refining and pilot testing the Pediatric Observation Priority Score (POPS) for use in EMS agencies. Validating a pediatric risk prediction tool for EMS use would enable EMS agencies to develop evidence-based and patient-centered alternative dispositions (including treatment in place) that are safe and efficient.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving risk prediction for children seeking emergency medical services (EMS) care with non-emergent complaints

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance): A promising strategy to improve survival from out-of- hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) – a major cause of death in the US and around the world – is to advance beyond our current “one-size-fits-all” resuscitation protocol governing administration of shock, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and medication treatments, and to instead align treatment with the dynamic and heterogeneous physiology that characterizes OHCA. This proposal seeks to advance such a strategy of precision medicine by applying deep learning (data-driven artificial intelligence) methods to analyze the real-time OHCA electrocardiogram during CPR and determine the patient’s time-sensitive physiology, estimate the physiologic effects of treatment, and evaluate the clinical implications of these algorithms which predict mechanistic (return of organized rhythm) and clinical (spontaneous pulse and survival) outcomes. Taken together, the research has the potential to transform OHCA resuscitation from a static, fixed approach to a dynamic, individualized strategy that leverages real-time understanding of patient physiology to guide treatment and ultimately improve OHCA outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  Suicide is the second leading cause of death in youth aged 10-12, with recent years showing a rise in suicidal thoughts and behaviors, particularly in girls. This research represents one of the initial efforts to identify risk trajectories and mechanisms specific to preteen suicide in girls. Findings will aid in linking distal risk factors such as childhood threat exposure (i.e., abuse) and potential proximal risk factors including maladaptive social motivation and advanced pubertal timing to inform developmental pathways to suicide risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The NLRP3 inflammasome is a key regulator of immune responses to pathogens but also contributes to inflammatory pathology in many chronic diseases. This proposal seeks to elucidate key aspects of inflammasome assembly and regulation. It is hoped that the insights provided will lead to new therapeutic approaches for treating chronic inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE. Inclusions of the transactive DNA binding protein 43 (TDP-43) are present in an overwhelming majority of elderly individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD). These co-occurring diseases lead to dementia, functional decline, and brain changes in the elderly—a population that is steadily rising worldwide. The current study will address this major public health challenge by investigating the underling neurobiological signatures and mechanistic contributions of TDP-43 in AD, with the long-term goal of contributing to the development of targeted interventions for dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative Critical to polio eradication efforts is development of new vaccines that stimulate effective mucosal immunity in the gut to control viral shedding and eliminate environmental reservoirs of poliovirus (PV). This project will provide critical information to better understand the immunologic and microbiologic factors impacting development of effective mucosal immunity to PV. It will also assess the effect of a novel mucosal adjuvant (dmLT) on systemic and mucosal immune responses to Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccines (IPV). The goal of these investigations is to guide future studies directed at harnessing immune-microbiota interactions to enhance mucosal immune responses to polio vaccines and other enteric pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project provides a comprehensive study of the many social and structural factors leading to racial/ethnic differences in HIV transmission and substance use among young men who have sex with men and transgender women (YMSM-TW). Using complex social network modeling and in-depth network surveys of 2700 racially diverse YMSM-TW across five US cities, it will offer a thorough account of how structural forces shape opportunity and risk through population-level differences in connections to people and places. Strengthened by a robust plan for community engagement, this work will help produce tangible targets for public health interventions and transform understanding on drivers of disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease (SCD) results in premature aging and early mortality, with physiologic measures of aging comparable to unaffected African-American individuals 20-30 years older, and mean life expectancy of affected adults of only 58 years. We hypothesize that causes of death are related to SCD severity of accumulating organ damage and that these associations may be attributed to multi-omic risk factors. We will study multiomic markers of early mortality versus successful aging, using the data and biological samples available from our own sickle cell disease study population of ~600 individuals as well as those of other study cohorts (total >4000) deposited in the NHLBI TOPMed biodata repository.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is the most common inherited cause of autism spectrum disorder, and patients suffer from complex behavioral and intellectual deficits. The disease is thought to be driven by local DNA methylation of FMR1, yet we recently found Megabase-scale domains of heterochromatin encompassing long synaptic genes in FXS patient-derived cells and brain tissue. Here, using cutting-edge single-cell genomics, imaging, computational analyses, and genome engineering, we propose to dissect the cause-and-effect relationship between 3D genome misfolding, inter-chromosomal interactions, Megabase-scale heterochromatin domains, and transcriptional silencing in human models of FXS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Non-learned defensive behaviors are necessary for survival, like fleeing or freezing in the face of threat. Whether these response change in response to acute and chronic stress is not currently known. Here, we will test whether stress alters behavioral responses to threats and examine the brain signals responsible for such changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The genetics underlying inflammatory bowel disease are intricate, with many susceptibility loci lacking known functions. Our objective is to identify and characterize a significant portion of these loci that share a common feature. This research will assign functions to numerous susceptibility loci and predict their collective risk in specific patients, paving the way for a personalized medicine approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will comprehensively assess the contribution of early menopause (natural and surgical) to overall risk and Black-White disparities in AD/ADRD diagnoses (adjudicated-AD/ADRD) and development (cognitive decline and neuroimaging markers of AD/ADRD) by harmonizing data from 25,051 women (30% Black) in three cohorts spanning midlife to older age. This project will elucidate unique midlife targets for AD/ADRD prevention in women, explicating the importance of maintenance of reproductive organs and reproductive aging’s role in women’s, especially Black women’s, long-term health.

PHR: Project Narrative This application is for the continued participation of the Saint Louis University Clinical Center in the NASH Clinical Research Network (NASH CRN) during its final 3 years. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The federal agencies and professional organizations have mounted a significant effort to address an increasingly recognized public health problem, Early Childhood Caries (ECC), among the underserved population. A better understanding of the biological factors related to this pediatric oral health disparity is urgently needed.  Leveraging an archived underserved birth cohort, our multidisciplinary team proposes using cutting- edge metagenomic sequencing and analysis tool, combined with a high-dimensional statistical machine learning approach, to examine the early-life oral microbiome development and identify its multilevel determinant and association to ECC. ECC risk factors revealed via prediction models could be used as targets for ECC early prediction and prevention specifically suitable for underserved racial minority children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE The proposed research, training and mentoring are relevant to public health as they address the need for scholars of differing perspectives and disciplinary backgrounds to address multilayered problems that arise in the care of people with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. The new research outlined in this proposal pertains to several recognized problems in dementia caregiving, such as caregiver burden, ethical concerns about how surrogate decisions reflect patients’ own values, and insufficient enrollment in clinical trials. The training and mentoring program will facilitate the training of new leaders in patient-oriented research across neurology, neuroscience, geriatrics, palliative care and bioethics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Currently 1.5 billion people worldwide suffer from chronic pain. In the parent grant, we propose to optimize epigenetic modulators to achieve analgesia with high specificity and efficacy without addictive properties in a long-lasting manner. This supplement will contribute to the optimization of the delivery of the therapy to improve tissue-specificity and decrease manufacturing costs, which will translate to a more affordable therapy for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will aid in developing a non-invasive, remote, and easily deployable tool to screen patients for opioid use, facilitating clinicians in diagnosing and treating opioid use disorder. The deployment of this tool will improve patient care by making diagnosis and treatment more accessible, accelerating the process, reducing costs, and reducing patients’ discomfort via non-invasive screening. Through identifying acoustic biomarkers associated with opioid use, this research will contribute to the scientific community’s understanding of opioids’ effects on voice production.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As fathers are increasingly more involved in child rearing and play a critical role in child development, it is important to understand the relationship between paternal preconception factors and the wellbeing of the next generation. The proposed study will examine the relationships between fathers’ adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), fathers’ behavioral health, fathering practices, and in turn offspring wellbeing. By also exploring the within parent dyad experience of ACEs on offspring wellbeing, findings from the proposed study can be used to inform trauma-informed family interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Evaporative dry eye disease is a common ophthalmic condition that is caused by decreased stability of the tear film, usually due to abnormalities in the tear film lipid composition and/or secretion. This proposal will investigate the mechanisms that govern tear film stability and modulate them with a novel, targeted therapeutic nonpolar lipid found in the tear film of the rabbit. Additionally, this proposal will investigate the effect of this targeted therapeutic on tear film lipid composition and secretion and the effect of the rabbit lipid on ocular surface health in an animal model of evaporative dry eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Yersinia pestis, the etiologic agent of the plague, has refined mechanisms to manipulate the host immune response and suppress inflammation. This project will define the impact of disrupting extracellular vesicle trafficking and illustrate how this manipulation contributes to disease pathogenesis. Understanding these mechanisms of immune subversion is essential for the development of novel targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Constriction of arterial blood vessels due to atherosclerosis is a leading cause of death worldwide, but current treatment is limited because administering clot-lysing drug entails a high risk of bleeding when distributed throughout the body. Using the fact that stenotic vessels exhibit abnormally high shear stress, we propose to develop shear stress-responsive synthetic cells as a targeted drug delivery system that can selectively release drugs in constricted blood vessels. This work will allow a deeper understanding of a mechanosensitive protein employed in this system to enable its broader use in the future and will contribute to expanding the application boundary of the synthetic cell in the biomedicine field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The outreach goal of the proposed research project is to develop a new combination of targeted drug delivery and immunotherapy for the treatment of advanced pancreatic cancer. Our innovative designs of tumor penetrating and immune modulating theranostic nanoparticles, coupled with a novel nanoparticle PD-L1 inhibitor (Nano-iPD-L1), enable efficient delivery of chemotherapy drugs and immunotherapy agents into stroma-rich pancreatic cancer tissues to destroy drug resistant tumor cells, modulate an immunosuppressive microenvironment into a pro-immune environment, and generate strong immune responses. Results of this translational research project have the potential for the development of a targeted and image-guided cancer therapy that significantly enhances therapeutic efficacy, and activates tumor specific immune response, and improves survival of pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Never in mitosis A-related kinase (NEK) family of protein kinases is an important, yet understudied, kinase family that has recently been implicated in a variety of disorders, including numerous cancers, ciliopathies, chronic inflammatory diseases, and neuronal disorders. The lack of reliable tools to study NEK function has made it difficult to determine the specific role(s) that NEK family members play in the etiology and progression of these diseases. In the proposed project, we will use a generalizable, family-based strategy to develop a suite of tools, including high quality chemical probes, that will be made freely available to the biomedical researcher community and enable researchers to build a firm understanding of how these understudied kinases contribute to health and disease and validate new druggable targets for cancer drug discovery.
PI_NAMEs: BUROW, MATTHEW E.;DREWRY, DAVID HAROLD (contact);NEWMAN, ROBERT HOWARD

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research to study germline CDH1 variants and obesity in Hispanic/Latino gastric cancer patients is relevant to public health because it may lead to the first discovery of a molecular cause for gastric cancer health disparities experienced by these patients. The expected results could guide genetic testing criteria and lifestyle recommendations that enable the prevention or early detection of gastric cancer. Thus, the proposal is relevant to the NIH's mission to reduce illness and lengthen life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Award supports the career development of Garrett T. Wasp, MD, MPH, a medical oncologist at Dartmouth Cancer Center whose long-term career goal is to become a leading investigator in health services and communication research focused on promoting high-quality and goal-concordant cancer care. The training and mentoring plan is designed to provide knowledge and skills in designing and leading clinical trials, behavioral intervention development and testing, implementation science, and professional development. The research component follows a user-centered design process and Behavior Change Wheel intervention development framework to systematically develop and evaluate an interactive visual aid (VIS) for use by patients with advanced cancer, their caregivers, and clinicians to approach decisions to stop cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is the leading cause of acute viral hepatitis worldwide and a significant risk factor for solid organ transplant patients who become chronically infected by HEV. Generating new therapeutics to combat chronic HEV infection requires delivery of virucidal molecules to primary sites of HEV replication. This project will assess efficacy of HEV genome targeting CRISPR therapies and apply a new technology to enhance delivery of HEV genome targeting CRISPR therapies to liver cells, thereby providing new insights on candidate therapies.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Title: Improving dog vaccinations: a development and feasibility study to pave the way for effective, synchronized dog vaccination campaigns in Africa Despite dog-mediated human rabies can be eliminated through mass dog vaccinations, dog vaccinations have not been scaled-up in Africa, whereby, pilot campaigns conducted through a standard centralized team-led delivery have sometimes failed to achieve the required (70%) level of coverage that is necessary to interrupt rabies transmission. There is a lack of practical and evidence-based methods for scaling-up dog vaccinations to support global target set for elimination of human deaths by 2030, therefore, I will conduct implementation trial of synchronized mass dog vaccinations supported by mass media, to answer key questions related to the coverage, cost per dog vaccinated, and human health impacts of synchronized vaccination campaigns versus team-led delivery. I anticipate that this study will lay ground for future scale up of mass dog vaccination in East Africa and potentially other settings in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the importance of early diagnosis, genetic and molecular mechanisms of esophageal squamous cell cancer (ESCC) initiation remain elusive. The proposed research will elucidate the dual role, both autonomous and non-autonomous, of preneoplastic cells in driving ESCC development, which is expected to establish a novel foundation to develop new types of ESCC detection and treatment. Therefore, this study is related to public health and to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for ultimately protecting health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of modern women are exposed to reduced light quality from extended time spent indoors, employment requiring nighttime work, and nighttime technology use, leading to numerous health risks, including reproductive deficits. This basic science proposal will validate a diurnal rodent model to elucidate both individual and combined contributions of photoperiod- and light intensity-driven adaptations in the female reproductive axis. This work will determine the impact of light quality on trace element and neuroendocrine mechanisms modulating fertility and in vitro fertilization success.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unlike in adults, febrile urinary tract infection in children can be a silent and dangerous condition because it is challenging to diagnose with potential risk of progression to severe infection and permanent loss of kidney function. This proposal seeks to minimize the risk by implementing a practical, validated machine-learning algorithm to promptly identify unsafe anatomy before injury occurs. The result of this proposed machine- learning implementation is expected to open the horizon and be scaled to other institutions, ultimately facilitating interactive improvements in the algorithm and decision support suitable for wide adoption in diverse contexts.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Machine-learning prediction model for personalized urinary tract infection care in children

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Focal cortical dysplasia (FCD) is a common cortical malformation associated with medically refractory epilepsy and most frequently caused by variants in subunits of the GATOR1 complex (a negative regulator of mTOR): DEPDC5, NPRL3, and NPRL2. The least studied of these variants is NPRL2 and in this proposal we aim to define the pathophysiological consequences of Nprl2 KO in vivo and in vitro. Using a mouse model of FCD we will define the morphological and functional changes that occur due to Nprl2 KO-induced mTOR pathway hyperactivation as well as investigate the transcriptomic changes that occur downstream of mTORC1 that may produce MCD and seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells require their actin cytoskeleton to divide, move, and communicate with their environment. This project will reveal novel mechanisms of how actin monomers, the basic subunit the actin cytoskeleton, control the assembly and organization of actin structures in the cell. Deciphering these fundamental mechanisms could explain why defects in monomer regulation are associated with human diseases such as neurodegeneration, inflammatory disorders, cardiac disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the first hours of development, the embryo undergoes rapid cycles of DNA replication followed by high-level transcription of sets of genes required for subsequent developmental processes. We will test the hypothesis that pioneer transcription factors like Zelda in Drosophila play a dual role, first to mark origins of DNA replication, then at those same sites, transcriptional activation. Our findings will have broad implications for pioneer factors in coordinating developmental events in more complex organisms.

PROJECT_TITLE: Pioneer factor activity in transcription and DNA replication

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral small vessel disease is a major public health challenge and responsible for ~30% of strokes and at least 40% of dementia cases. This application will characterize cerebral microvascular pulsatility using two advanced MRI techniques on widely accessible 3T MRI, which may be a sensitive vascular marker of cSVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has stated that antimicrobial resistant infections claim more than 35,000 lives each year in the United States and increase the risks of organ transplants and cancer treatments. As antimicrobial resistance continues to spread, developing new antimicrobials is important to maintain effective treatments against antibiotic resistant bacteria. This project aims to understand how organisms naturally synthesize a newly discovered class of antimicrobials to advance future development and manufacturing efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to prepare the candidate with the skills to successfully run a lab at the forefront of single-cell cross-modality translation. These tools will help us understand cellular processes such as cell differentiation during embryonic development and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurons can communicate with each other via electrical and chemical signals, as well as membrane-bound packets called extracellular vesicles. These vesicles carry cargo that can contribute to normal brain function, but in neurological disorders including Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s Diseases, they can also spread toxic proteins throughout the brain. Our research will help us understand how extracellular vesicles are packaged, released and spread in the nervous system, and may identify new strategies to treat a wide variety of neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The clinical sepsis syndrome occurs due to an overwhelming inflammatory response to an infection, and requires aggressive treatment. Sepsis is beset with very high mortality due to vasoplegia, a physiologic condition in which blood vessels do not work and fail to perfuse vital organs such as the lung. Using a robust porcine model of fecal peritonitis (fecal clot with ischemia-reperfusion injury) to recapitulate human disease, the proposed research will quantify physiologic impairment in vascular smooth muscle and endothelial cells, and explore concomitant dysregulation of “off-signaling” of harmful intracellular events as a putative mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: We will use a type 1 hybrid study to evaluate efficacy and implementation/adoption considerations for MI- CHANCE, a peer-led motivational interviewing (MI) intervention to promote uptake of drug checking services (DCS) and safer drug use behaviors among people who use drugs (PWUD) to reduce incidence of overdose (OD) in San Diego County. Through our two-arm randomized controlled trial, we hypothesize that PWUD who receive MI-CHANCE will be more likely to use DCS and experience significantly lower rates of OD relative to a control group over 30 months of follow-up; we will use qualitative methods to explore local implementation experiences and potential adoption by other SSPs across the country. Our bilingual/bicultural intervention will leverage the infrastructure of an ongoing cohort of PWUD, involves a collaborative team including local harm reduction community and government partners and is designed to be both practical and scalable.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rising prevalence of mental illness and its significant contribution to maternal morbidity and mortality necessitate the development of feasible, scalable, and effective interventions. This proposal is a first step towards addressing this problem by focusing on reducing the risk of severe maternal morbidity (SMM), which precedes most maternal deaths, in people with mental illness. In addition to elucidating the complex pathways underlying the association between mental illness and SMM, this proposal will also pilot an intervention to treat psychobiological aspects of mental illness with the goals of reducing SMM on a larger scale and driving innovative and impactful research in maternal and child health for years to come.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rapid progressive forms of Alzheimer disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD) account for most cases of rapid progressive dementia in older patients, yet the factors that contribute to these extreme clinical phenotypes are unknown. The Biomarkers and Rates of Progression in Dementia (Bio-RaPID) study will enroll, evaluate, genetically characterize, and prospectively apply multimodal (imaging and biofluid) biomarkers to decipher the patient- and disease-specific factors that associate with rapid progressive AD/ADRD; these data will be compared with findings in patients with typical progressive AD/ADRD enrolled in Alzheimer Disease Research Center studies. Findings in prospectively evaluated patients will be validated through expansive proteomic analyses in cerebrospinal fluid from an independent cohort of patients with autopsy-confirmed rapid progressive AD/ADRD and results extended to identify biomarkers and disease-modifying targets for AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inadequate medication adherence is common in adolescents with eosinophilic esophagitis - a chronic inflammatory condition of the esophagus - and leads to poor health outcomes and increased healthcare spending. This proposal seeks to conduct pilot testing of a new medication adherence intervention for adolescents with eosinophilic esophagitis and measure the impact of dupilumab (a newly approved biologic therapy for eosinophilic esophagitis) on nonadherent adolescents. Results of this proposal have widespread applicability to all adolescents with chronic diseases for whom medication nonadherence remains an important public health concern.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Insufficient human milk production is a major cause of mothers stopping to breastfeed early, having major consequences on maternal and infant health. Leveraging the applicant's expertise in molecular biology and clinical dietetics, this study aims to understand the physiological regulation of milk production, including the functional characterization of novel milk production associated gene, C6orf15, assessment of optimal breast pumping protocols, and investigation of molecular mechanisms underlying increased milk production. The research combines clinical and molecular approaches, with the potential to significantly improve the diagnosis and treatment of insufficient milk production, ultimately benefiting both mothers and infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health significance of GAPcare II is immense as it proposes a multidisciplinary care coordination program that addresses the Healthy People 2020 goals of preventing and reducing injuries and enhancing life independence among older adults. This project is directly responsive to NIA’s “Strategic Directions for Research on Aging”, section B5: Identify, analyze, and track changing patterns of disability and mortality for older adults and better understand factors contributing to these patterns. Dr. Goldberg’s technology-assisted fall prevention intervention could provide a model of care to reduce subsequent falls in high-risk emergency department seniors and supports the further training of Dr. Goldberg to become a leader in geriatric emergency care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Integration of reproduction and metabolism is necessary for species survival. This proposal aims to further our understanding of the integration of energy homeostasis with reproductive function, and determine the mechanism(s) by which the melanocortin 3 receptor (MC3R) is involved in integrating information about metabolic state with development and control of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Identifying and understanding the role of MC3R in reproductive neuroendocrinology may lead to therapeutic approaches and preventative strategies for treating reproductive disorders, such as PCOS, and delayed reproductive maturation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Heart failure is a major, common, and costly public health problem in the United States, and despite the existence of several proven, guideline-recommended medications to reduce mortality and hospitalization, many patients are not prescribed or do not fill these medications. This study aims to quantify the impact of restrictive drug coverage policies, such as copayment and prior authorization, on gaps and inequities in prescribing, adherence, and outcomes for patients with heart failure. Our findings could inform policy-makers, health systems, and clinicians on ways to improve care and reduce inequities for patients with heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop an innovative analytical toolbox designed to address multifaceted statistical challenges inherent in the analysis of real-world data. Utilizing this toolbox to analyze Medicare data will yield insights into the identification of high-risk subgroups and hospital-level factors partially driving poor post- fracture recovery trajectories for older adults living with ADRD. Consequently, these findings will enhance predictive capabilities for multivariate and multilevel outcomes, enabling the development of personalized caregiving strategies for new patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The persistence of neural stem cells in isolated niches of the adult brain offers a potentially unique source of plasticity and regeneration. Understanding how neural stem cells contribute to adult brain plasticity is critical to determining the health-relevance of these cell populations. The proposed experiments will dissect the functional role of neural stem cell secreted proteins in modulating the physiology and behavioral function of the adult hippocampus, a brain region which mediates essential memory and affect functions which are impaired in numerous brain diseases and injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to maintain relevant information necessary to make decisions and continuously update our autobiographies as we amass experience from childhood into adulthood depends on the medial temporal lobe and prefrontal cortex. By measuring electrical activity directly from the human brain, the proposed research will determine the mechanisms by which these regions interact to form and maintain memories in real time, and identify sources of developmental variability in these mechanisms from childhood into adulthood. The outcomes will increase understanding of how the brain implements normal memory and how brain circuits may go awry in disordered behavior, laying the foundation for translational work aimed at improving memory in populations suffering from disease or injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative COVID-19 vaccines are unable to prevent widespread infection with new viral variants, as even the updated vaccine tends to boost pre-existing antibodies to old strains instead of causing new antibodies to form against current strains. We designed a vaccine that causes antibodies to form to only one area on the virus: a weak spot that is identical in all strains. We will test and optimize this vaccine in mice, with the ultimate goal of using it in humans as a more effective booster vaccine against all viral strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative By implementing the developed approaches, the research team aims to attain increased accuracy in identifying knees with a high risk of incident frequent knee pain in specific locations, along with the MRI-defined determinants associated with these knee pain patterns. It is expected that the proposed studies will provide timely information that can help identify patients who would be most likely to benefit from pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic interventions to prevent or slow the progression of knee osteoarthritis in clinical trials. The objectives of this proposal can thus potentially reduce the public health impact of knee osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This ambitious experimental and theoretical collaboration will investigate how internal states (such as task engagement) influence decision-making, and identify the underlying neural mechanisms. The proposed work will produce an integrated, circuit-level model that explains decision behavior and neural activity in healthy and autism model mice, which show a reduced ability to make decisions that take changing expectations into account. Decision-making is also impaired in addiction and schizophrenia, so a deeper understanding of brainwide decision-making circuitry may contribute to future research on ways to treat or mitigate these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Invasive fungal infection caused by Aspergillus fumigatus is a leading cause of death for patients with lowered immune systems. Despite this high mortality, the fundamental mechanism of how A. fumigatus grows and invades the host tissue is not understood and this knowledge is critical to improving therapeutic treatment. Hyphal growth is crucial for A. fumigatus invasive disease and the proposed research will define the mechanism of how the critical PKA signaling pathway interacts with autophagy related proteins to regulate fungal invasive growth and disease.
