IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major mechanism of immunotherapeutic resistance is immune suppression and major cell types that drive immune suppression are myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs), which compromise anti-cancer immunity. We identified a targeted metabolic vulnerability in MDSCs rendering them less suppressive, thus, raising tumor susceptibility to novel immunotherapy regimens. Here, we are investigating strategies to optimize this therapeutic paradigm in solid cancer models and the underlying immune mechanisms, which will have important translational implications in cancer patients with high MDSC burden.

ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: NARRATIVE There are a variety of motor deficits following stroke which present growing challenges to healthcare. Therapeutic practice with physical devices remains an exciting frontier for the recovery of function, but a critical question is precisely how such devices should be programmed. Here we investigate differences in outcomes using models that describe how a person responds to error during practice, and we evaluate how well these models can prescribe the best therapeutic training.

PHR: Voltage-gated calcium ion channels are the gatekeepers that sit at the junction of the peripheral and central nervous systems. Our research is focused on the importance of these channels in normal and abnormal pain. We hope to generate new strategies to mitigate some forms of chronic pain experienced by millions of people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Influenza-associated secondary pneumococcal infections are dreaded complications that cause serious illnesses and significantly contribute to Influenza related mortality. Highly endocytic Microfold cells arise in the lower respiratory epithelium during the resolving phase of Influenza linked inflammation when susceptibility to secondary pneumococcal pneumonia is highest. This proposal will unravel the pathologic role of lung Microfold cells as entry portals for pneumococcal invasion and will have the potential to develop novel therapeutic avenues for targeting virus-associated secondary infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chlamydia species infect a wide range of mammalian hosts and deploy an array of anti-host proteins to promote the ability to cause disease. While many of these proteins are conserved across species, some have diverged and are likely to contribute to species-specific differences in infection. This proposal contains work designed to characterize a group of those variable proteins and elucidate specific contributions to chlamydial disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite eﬀorts to increase diversity and inclusion, opportunities in data-driven genomics research are still unequally oﬀered to people with visual impairments. I will identify barriers to accessing genomics data and visualization resources through comprehensive evaluations and will implement novel tools by designing accessible representations, interactions, and interfaces that will complement screen reader and magniﬁer assistive technologies. The developed tools will not only help content creators to eﬃciently and accurately create accessible visualizations but also enable current and prospective genomics students, researchers, and clinicians with visual impairments to access, interpret, and analyze genomics data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The care and treatment of patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRDs) are significant burdens to the American healthcare system. Without greater insight into the molecular causes of dementia, the development of disease-modifying treatments to halt or cure disease will remain out of reach. Lewy Body Dementia is the second most common form of neurodegenerative dementia, and the goal of this proposal is to apply new genetic information to dissect the early events that drive the mixed pathology associated with its most significant genetic risk factor and explore a potential mitigating factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many patients with acute ischemic stroke are ineligible for currently available standard treatments (clot-busting medication or mechanical removal of clot), and many are non-responders, resulting in low rate of excellent outcomes, which necessitates development of novel therapies. We propose a new treatment in which a weak electrical current will be applied via scalp electrodes to increase collateral blood flow to the brain and rescue the brain tissue at risk of injury. In this study, we primarily aim to find an optimal dose of this therapy that is both adequately safe and effective on imaging marker of brain tissue rescue.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The challenging eating behaviors of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) are highly prevalent and are associated with serious negative health consequences. Parents face challenges with these behaviors which results in parent anxiety and family burden. This study will use novel methods, during mealtime in the child's home, to understand multiple factors that may be contributing to these behaviors, so that we can begin to develop treatment approaches to improve the health and well-being of children with ASD and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Behavioral economic and financial incentive-based are promising means to sustain gains from Coordinated Specialty Care (CSC) after patients leave this short-term treatment. However, they face two obstacles in this setting: (1) frequent loss of contact in care transition and (2) concerns about the ethical acceptability of these interventions. This K23 will design and test these interventions in the post-CSC period while leveraging (1) text messaging and emerging mHealth apps to increase continued contact as patients leave CSC and (2) participatory, ethically informed research design to ensure that there is high acceptability of the interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Center for Clinical & Translational Research at the University of South Carolina (CLINTRUSC) draws on the many strengths that exist in the Schools and Colleges of the University of South Carolina (USC) to create a Clinical & Translational Research Center that will address a long-standing deficiency in meaningful disparities- focused, clinic-based research. The CLINTRUSC will provide, for the first time at USC, a cohesive infrastructure to quickly deploy clinical/translational research projects within the Midlands regions of South Carolina to 1) Develop a Cohesive Clinical and Translational Research Hub at USC and in the Midlands and 2) Integrate and Coordinate this Hub with Existing Health Systems and Partners. Using existing infrastructure and creating new Advisory Boards, Committees, and Core resources to support Pilot and Developmental Projects and the professional development of individuals dedicated to addressing health disparities CLINTRUSC will work in the spirit of community-based participatory research (CBPR) to advance public health and improve clinical outcomes in a region badly in need of this resource.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. opioid overdose crisis continues to escalate with over 80,000 Americans dying from an opioid overdose in 2021 alone. There is a critical public health need to develop effective interventions to prevent and treat opioid use disorder and ensure that evidence-based interventions actually reach and benefit patients, and in an equitable manner. This K02 Independent Scientist Award will provide the PI with protected time from clinical duties in support of an intensive period of research career enhancement to acquire additional skills, training, and experience in implementation science approaches to address primary prevention and treatment of opioid use disorder from the emergency department.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The overarching objective of this K24 Renewal proposal is to leverage the increased protected research time afforded by the K24 award to ensure intensive mentorship of promising surgeon-scientists, sustain ongoing mentorship of surgeons within my clinical trials network, allow the completion of comparative effectiveness exploratory analyses, and develop a clinical trial master protocol. This proposal aims to strengthen my mentorship capabilities and generate novel avenues for my mentees to succeed in bolstering their independent research careers. Specifically, mentees will 1) explore clinically important research questions using high-quality data from the PREP-IT trials; 2) have immediate access to an established trial infrastructure for new ideas supported by a master protocol; and 3) develop original research ideas to be continued in their independent research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure (HF) without gross weakening of the heart pump (HF with preserved ejection fraction; HFpEF) disproportionately burdens older adults and has no effective therapy, and risk is particularly high when pulmonary vascular pressure is elevated. This project will use novel image processing approaches to measure anatomic remodeling of the pulmonary vasculature and determine its association with risk of developing HFpEF. Establishing pulmonary vascular remodeling, measurable on a routinely performed non-invasive imaging test (non-contrast chest CT), as a novel HFpEF risk factor will enable innovative strategies to prevent the morbidity, mortality, and cost associated with HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain after traumatic brain injury (TBI) exerts a steep toll on Veterans and civilians alike, and one of the major obstacles to developing effective therapies for these patients is a critical knowledge gap in understanding the underlying pathophysiology of TBI-related pain. Emerging data have suggested that dysfunction of the brainstem pain regulatory system in the rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) is involved in chronic pain after TBI. This project aims to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the plasticity of the brainstem RVM pain-facilitating circuit following TBI, and how this circuit contributes to chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Growing evidence suggests we can create privacy-respecting health datasets that are larger, more diverse, and more widely available through the integration of synthetic data produced by generative AI. However, it is currently unknown how best to appraise synthetic health data generation for the factors on which researchers need to trust (e.g., reliability of the data generated) and refine such technology to support equitable healthcare research and applications. This project will create a set of computational methods, realized in open-source software, to enable systematic evaluation of and multi-institutional development of synthetic health data, as well as the development of a fairness-aware medical AI pipeline through the integration of such data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The biosynthesis of complex sugars is fundamental to bacterial survival and to the interactions between bacterial pathogens and symbionts and their human hosts. The proposed studies will uncover how a superfamily of enzymes, which is only found in bacteria, acts at bacterial membranes to carry out an initial, critical step in complex sugar assembly. Application of chemical biology, biochemistry, structural biology, and bioinformatics approaches will provide the community a deep understanding of the structures and functions in the enzyme superfamily and its roles in the interactions between both beneficial and injurious bacteria and their human hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wildfires and human activities are leading to massive deforestation worldwide. Deforestation, as a sudden or expansive change, produces stress reactions that are highly associated with tobacco and alcohol use, yet the relationship has not been comprehensively studied. This proposed research examines how deforestation types and complex patterns over time relate to tobacco and alcohol use to inform future climate and health policies and reduce attributable population-level health burdens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Over 1.5 million patients are admitted to an intensive care unit (ICU) with acute respiratory failure each year in the United States, and survivors are often dependent on family caregivers due to severe, persistent health problems and complex medical needs following hospital discharge. Both acute respiratory failure survivors and their caregivers describe inadequate post-discharge support as a major barrier to patient recovery, and emerging evidence suggests that a family-centered intervention approach designed to meet the support needs of both patient and caregiver holds promise for improving long-term outcomes for acute respiratory failure survivors. This mentored patient-oriented research career development project will adapt and test a family- centered post-discharge support intervention to improve health outcomes for survivors of acute respiratory failure, which holds major public health relevance given the increase in acute respiratory failure survivorship due to COVID-19 and other severe, prevalent respiratory viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: SARS-2-CoV-2 (COVID-19) remains a highly endemic infectious disease in the U.S. and can cause serious cerebral vascular disease. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is a common cerebral small vessel disease and cause of stroke in the elderly. The purpose of this exploratory project is to evaluate how SARS-2-CoV-2 impacts the pathogenesis of CAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drawing from the urgent need to address the opioid crisis, our research aims to develop a wearable opioid sensor to continuously monitor drugs in body fluid for treatment of opioid use disorders. By facilitating personalized medication management and reducing the need for frequent clinic visits, this sensor can improve treatment adherence and accessibility, especially in underserved regions. The proposed technology has the potential to transform treatment protocols and patient monitoring, ultimately reducing fentanyl-related overdoses and fatalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: In the United States, over 1.9 million patients annually are affected by acute respiratory failure, which makes it a common serious illness. As highlighted in recent NIH and National Academy of Medicine reports, there is a pressing need to identify and overcome the causes of health disparities in serious illness care, including how clinicians counsel patients and families about goals of care in advanced illness. This award will provide the principal investigator with the protected time, structure, and resources to mentor the next generation of clinician-scientists focused on developing strategies to achieve equity and improve outcomes for patients with acute respiratory failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Although the influence of social experiences on mental and physical health are commonly accepted, the biological drivers of these effects are not yet understood. Understanding the biological underpinnings of social modulation of neural health and behavior are critical to improved human health outcomes. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission because assessment of the effects of a common environmental factor underrepresented in research models will ultimately allow identification of novel intervention strategies to ameliorate adverse consequences of social disruption and lead to enhanced health and reduced disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing novel and alternative therapies to treating patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). PAD, which affects approximately 8-10 million individuals in the US, is the leading cause of limb loss in the US. Despite significant improvements in medical and surgical therapies, the rate of limb loss continues to rise. Recently, the importance of skeletal muscle recovery to clinical outcomes in PAD has emerged as a new area of investigation and potential therapeutic strategy. The goal of this project is advance our understanding of the immune response to muscle injury in PAD patients. This is critical step for the future development of cellular therapies for limb preservation in PAD. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on understanding vitamin K insufficiency (a modifiable risk factor) in knee osteoarthritis, which is a common cause of disability among older adults worldwide. Insights from the proposed research would lay the foundation for identifying an important OA phenotype targetable for testing vitamin K supplementation leading to disease modification, providing an important breakthrough for this disease in which there are no proven effective disease-modifying therapies available to date. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIAMS’ mission to support research into the causes, treatment, and prevention of arthritis and musculoskeletal and skin diseases; and to support the training of basic and clinical scientists to carry out this research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research project aims to investigate the role of FGF21, a novel myokine, in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD). The objectives of the study include understanding the mechanisms that lead to FGF21 expression in dystrophic muscle and examining how FGF21 contributes to the pathology of DMD, particularly in relation to muscle, bone, and whole-body metabolism. The project seeks to establish a foundation for comprehending the interactions between muscles and bones in the context of DMD, thus this work has the potential to shed light on the intricate mechanisms involved in DMD pathogenesis and may offer insights into novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance Use Disorders (SUD) has become a major public health crisis in the United but many patients often encounter significant barriers to receiving a diagnosis and treatment for SUD due to lack of devices for rapid and low-cost quantitative measurement of drug concentrations and their metabolites for monitoring the compliance and metabolism of SUD medication drugs. If funded, this proposed project will fill current technology void in developing a low-cost, point-of- use, highly sensitive and specific non-instrument test that enables the convenient monitoring SUD therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In Alzheimer’s disease (AD), predictable spreading of tau pathology between functionally connected brain regions correlates well with progressive cognitive impairment, thus constituting a likely effective treatment target. The proposed study will evaluate the molecular mechanisms of pathological trans-synaptic tau spreading within the framework of selective cellular, regional, and clinical vulnerability. Specifically, the results of this investigation will contribute to the fundamental knowledge about the molecular mediators of tau oligomer binding and internalization in human synapses, thus providing novel and translationally relevant avenues for future AD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding what lifestyle health behaviors protect against cognitive decline and risk of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias is critical for prevention. This project will pool and harmonize participant-level data from existing trials to examine how changes in lifestyle health behavior impact cognitive outcomes across diverse older adults. Results from this research will inform clinical and public health guidelines focused on realistic changes in lifestyle health behaviors to protect against risk of cognitive decline across diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Benzimidazoles (BZ) are the treatment of choice for ascariasis in humans, but the development of resistance is a significant risk, as seen in other ascarids of veterinary importance. Mechanisms of resistance in ascarids are unknown but appear to differ from other nematode species. Therefore, we propose to develop an experimental system that will enable the identification of novel BZ resistance genes in ascarids of poultry as a model, allowing for clinical diagnosis of resistant ascarids and improving the quality of care and life of people in the developing world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE We have developed a brain-penetrant, small molecule drug candidate, called MW189, that targets dysregulated inflammation and attenuates brain dysfunction. The proposed project will fill the remaining gaps necessary to bring MW189 to a future clinical study in Alzheimer’s patients. MW189 has the potential to be a first-in-class disease-modifying therapy for Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this Mentored Patient-Oriented Research Career Development Award is to determine the contributions of social determinants of health to the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes in systemic lupus erythematosus, while gaining the skills and training to become an independent investigator. By skillfully integrating diverse data sources, we will identify the most meaningful social determinants of health that contribute to adverse pregnancy outcomes risk in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus both at an individual and community level. This innovative approach combines clinical factors with social determinants of health and stakeholder feedback to create a synthesis that will streamline the identification of at-risk patients, with the long-term goal of mitigating health disparities and improving pregnancy outcomes for those grappling with this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed Diversity Supplement: Leveraging Parents and Peer Recovery Supports to Increase Recovery Capital in Emerging Adults with Polysubstance Use: Feasibility, Acceptability, and Scaling Up of Launch (R34DA057639) will provide funding support for Dr. Castedo de Martell, a Hispanic woman with direct lived experience of substance use disorder, to complete two research activities that enhance the aims of the parent grant, and to receive intensive training and mentorship to advance to an independent research career. The overarching purpose of the Launch parent grant study is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of an innovative substance use services package, Launch, that leverages supportive parents and peer recovery support services to reduce poly-substance use and increase recovery capital in this critical developmental stage using quantitative, qualitative, and community-based participatory research procedures. The Diversity Supplement research activities will (1) prepare a cost-effectiveness analysis to accompany a future large scale Launch research project, and (2) will investigate recovery capital factors impacting peer workers’ ability to deliver services with fidelity, as well as expanding to peer workforce retention outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The accumulation of misfolded proteins represents a common feature in age-related neurodegenerative diseases, such as Huntington's disease. This project aims to uncover the role of specific molecular chaperones in neurons in mitigating protein aggregation in Huntington's disease. These findings hold the promise of guiding therapeutic strategies that harness the appropriate molecular chaperones to alleviate protein aggregation in Huntington's disease and potentially other neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of the proposed research are to develop and pilot test a patient-centered, pediatric clinic-based postpartum contraception intervention that will promote equitable access to care. The relevance of this research to public health lies in its potential to transform perinatal maternal and child health services to better meet women’s postpartum contraceptive needs, and to therefore improve related health and social outcomes for women and families. This research aligns with NICHD research objectives, including setting a foundation for healthy pregnancies, improving child health, and the cross-cutting topic of health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACT STATEMENT Preventive vaping interventions are critically needed that target the unique multilevel risk and protective factors of urban Indigenous youth; however, no such evidence-based interventions currently exist. The proposed study will test if a youth intervention can prevent nicotine and cannabis vaping for urban Indigenous youth. This research should provide important information that can be used to prevent and reduce vaping disparities among urban Indigenous youth and the downstream harmful impact on health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrest occurs in up to 600,000 adults per year in the United States and often leads to poor neurological outcomes in survivors. Older individuals are significantly more likely to suffer a cardiac arrest and have a worse long-term cognitive prognosis, yet the molecular mechanisms underlying differences between the ability of the brain in young and advanced age individuals to withstand a global cerebral ischemic insult are unknown. The proposed studies will analyze the role of aging-associated inflammation in the brain's response to global cerebral ischemia and may ultimately lead to new therapies for the treatment of cognitive dysfunction after a cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing loss in midlife (ages 45-65) is posited as a target for preventing Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's disease related dementias, but it is unknown whether hearing loss is associated with cognition or brain health in midlife. This study will link newly collected objective hearing tests with cognitive and brain MRI assessments in a well-characterized and diverse cohort of middle-aged adults. This study's findings will provide critical insights into midlife haring loss and brain health, which may offer an avenue for reducing late-life dementia risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is an effective adjunct for treating the cardinal motor features of Parkinson's disease (PD), but is less effective at treating cognitive symptoms. Typical DBS stimulation parameters utilize high frequency gamma stimulation (100-180 Hz); however, there is growing evidence that low frequency theta (4-8 Hz) oscillations are important in various aspects of cognition, including verbal fluency, working memory, response inhibition and sensorimotor conflict. We hypothesize that theta-burst stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus will confer a cognitive benefit over time while maintaining the motor benefit of high frequency stimulation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative More than 40% of pregnancies in the United States are undesired and non-use or inconsistent use of contraceptives is the leading cause. People must balance competing goals when striving to prevent pregnancy, but the literature on contraceptive use lacks a robust conceptual framework, measures, and data to analyze risk perceptions and tolerance as psychological mechanisms undergirding contraceptive decision-making amid conflicting goals particularly with data from both partners. The proposed research addresses barriers to scientific progress by (1) identifying the association between risk tolerance and contraceptive use among men and women via pilot data collected on pretested measures of risk tolerance adapted from psychology and (2) quantifying the relationship between risk perceptions and contraceptive use among couples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Upwardly mobile youth who “strive” to rise above poverty typically have better cognitive outcomes - which is protective against Alzheimer's Disease (AD) - but this striving may be stressful, and can induce health problems such as altered brain-gut axis signaling and systemic inflammation. Women are at greater risk for striving-related stress, stress-related health problems, and critically, when they possess other risk factors such as apolipoprotein-ε4 (ApoE-ε4) gene status, they are more likely to develop AD. Using a cohort of young adults who were part of a natural educational experiment, we will test the hypothesis that due to sex-specific vulnerabilities (such as stress) females, but not males, with greater mobility opportunity will exhibit more physical health risks (namely obesity and inflammation as well as altered gut microbiome profiles) in early adulthood, which will in turn be negatively associated with cognitive outcomes and brain structure/function that could put them at risk for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Sensorimotor disturbances have long been identified in psychotic disorders and may serve as objectively measurable readouts of fundamental process disturbances that drive clinical phenomenology. Determining which metrics of a motor learning task capture this dysfunction and fluctuate over time with symptoms is critical in linking aberrant behavior processes to the disruption of distinct neural circuits and resulting clinical symptoms. Enriching our models of brain-behavior-symptom relationships can then be leveraged to identify and develop targeted interventions for psychosis onset and maintenance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Black adults are disproportionately affected by chronic kidney disease (CKD) and have some of the worst health outcomes among those with CKD. Sedentary behavior is associated with poor health outcomes and is an extremely common behavior in those with CKD. This project will adapt and test an intervention to reduce sedentary behavior for Black adults with CKD, which will inform the development of a future large-scale trial to reduce sedentary and improve health outcomes in this at-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This renewed K24 Midcareer Investigator Award in Patient-Oriented Research of Integrative Medicine will expand the Candidate’s research and mentoring program in Translational Science of Complementary and Integrative Health. The main goals of this program will be: Goal 1: Conduct rigorous research into developing new interventions; testing the efficacy and effectiveness and implementation of the mind-body therapies; Goal 2: Advance expertise in implementation science; Goal 3: Develop an expertise in rTMS neuromodulation added to the mind-body interventions via direct training and research; Goal 4: Mentor future CIH researchers at multiple levels of training (medical students, graduate and post-graduate trainees in psychology, neuroscience, medicine and psychiatry) in Translational Science of the CIH. The proposed research, mentoring, and training programs are based on the currently funded studies, and a new proposed pilot project.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative: Veterans are at a higher risk of developing thyroid cancer in their lifetime due to the increased potential of radiation exposure in the armed services. Furthermore, veterans who suffered from thyroid cancer self-reported a higher prevalence of Agent Orange exposure, increasing the relevance of this malignancy to the VA population. There is no effective treatment for anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC). Cancer cell-specific expression of MADD and its ability to act as a pro-survival factor and promote metastasis in ATC makes it an ideal target for therapeutic development. We will test whether MADD depletion can be effective in inhibiting growth and overcoming ATC resistance to various drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A hallmark of cardiac diseases is mis-regulated RNA processing. This project seeks to understand how RNA processing of CLTC, a molecule that controls protein trafficking and cell structure, contributes to the function of the heart. The insights gained from this research will be fundamental to our knowledge of cardiac physiology and lay the foundation for identifying future therapeutic targets of cardiac diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is the most common primary brain cancer worldwide, and urgent treatment strategies are needed since it is almost a universally fatal disease. The focus of this project is to address unmet needs by developing tools that identify and monitor patients with significant anatomic and/or physiologic tumor changes much earlier than current methods, so that in the future, prompt, aggressive, and early therapy adaption can be implemented. This project will translate directly to the practice of clinical medicine and advance the field of glioblastoma treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (3-sentence limit) We propose to use next-generation laser-diode arrays to investigate the limits of production technology for hyperpolarized xenon-129, an emerging new FDA-approved imaging modality for functional pulmonary imaging. Specifically, an ultra-frequency-narrowed 180 W laser will be employed to map the hyperpolarized xenon-129 production efficiency, with the vision that recent gains in frequency narrowing can enable efficient contrast agent production with vastly reduced laser power and milder conditions. If successful, this research will substantially improve clinical access to this new MRI contrast agent for functional pulmonary imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even before the COVID-19 pandemic, stroke morality began increasing as did dementia incidence, high blood pressure and diabetes. This was in part driven by racial disparities in these conditions as Black Americans have experienced persistent and increasing risk of stroke, hypertension, diabetes and dementia compared with White Americans. This application will identify reasons for increases in shared risk factors between stroke and dementia (hypertension and diabetes) and the widening racial disparity in stroke mortality and dementia incidence in a 20,000 person population based cohort residing across the lower 48 United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) disproportionately affect Black and Hispanic adults, attributable, in part, to disparities in socioeconomic status and age-related health conditions. Only by identifying risk factors contributing to these disparities can we address them. Mass incarceration, which disproportionately affects Black and Hispanic people, may play a key role. This is the first comprehensive study to investigate how the dose of incarceration—frequency and duration of stays, type of facility (juvenile, jail, prison), age(s), and recency—affects overall health, age-related conditions, and risk factors for ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma disproportionately impacts youth who have been systematically marginalized. The purpose of this study is to develop and evaluate an Interactive Mobile Asthma Action Plan (IMAAP) to support asthma self- management and adherence to ‘as needed’ rescue medications, which are a critical component of preventing exacerbations. If successful, IMAAP has long-term potential in preventing exacerbations, improving health outcomes, and promoting health equity particularly for adolescents with asthma from marginalized populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We present here a novel magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) based imaging approach for a comprehensive quantitative assessment of vasculopathy, tissue hypoxia, and fibrosis in the hands of patients with scleroderma. The short-term goal of this project is to identify effective imaging biomarkers to guide prevention and to monitor effectiveness of therapy for digital ulcers in patients with scleroderma. The potential future implication of this study is the development of peripheral vascular imaging tools that could be applied to patients with other autoimmune rheumatic disease conditions or peripheral artery disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Around 50% of infants born extremely preterm develop a chronic lung disease known as bronchopulmonary dysplasia of which some infants will also develop pulmonary hypertension of which 50% of children will die before the age of 2. Physicians are currently limited in their (1) ability to predict which infants will develop this more severe form and (2) ability to select the most appropriate therapy that will improve outcomes in infants with this condition. This proposal will develop a tool to predict which infants are more likely to develop bronchopulmonary dysplasia and pulmonary hypertension, will examine whether currently used therapies for this disease improve infants’ condition, and determine whether using different amounts of oxygen improve outcomes in infants with this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Black Americans suffer the highest toll from hypertension with double the hypertension-related death rate from cardiovascular disease compared with White Americans, requiring urgent, more effective, and equitable hypertension care models. In our analysis, we noted that telemedicine management of hypertension overall is more effective for blood pressure control than usual clinic-based care, but the benefit is significantly diminished in studies that enrolled more Black patients than studies that enrolled more White patients, likely due to a lack of tailoring of the telemedicine intervention to the needs and social context of Black patients. This study proposes to leverage the contextual needs of socially disadvantaged Black patients and the primary care clinics they attend in using the telemedicine intervention to make the intervention responsive to the needs of the patients and clinics and will eventually examine the feasibility of the refined intervention compared with usual clinic-based care in a pilot randomized controlled trial, thus paving a pathway for a future larger study to confirm the benefit of the telemedicine intervention and to advance equity in blood pressure control in socially disadvantaged Black patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: While the number of Alzheimer’s disease cases is expected to increase nationally, racial and ethnic minorities are anticipated to bear a disproportionate burden of disease with the largest increase among Hispanics. New neuroimaging technologies have made it possible to study tau, a protein that is strongly linked with Alzheimer’s disease, in the brain, however, the majority of research has been conducted in non- Hispanic white adults. We now propose to extend these investigations to Hispanic older adults and examine factors that may increase the risk of tau build-up in the brain in effort to improve early detection of Alzheimer’s disease and inform the development of interventions relevant to this growing, underserved demographic. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The co-occurrence of trauma and substance use is highly clinically relevant; identifying drivers of this co- occurrence will benefit the health of our nation. This project will provide the groundwork for early detection and intervention of substance use by using cutting-edge technologies to identify emotional processes as time- sensitive proximal predictors of substance use in the daily lives of trauma-exposed individuals. The training experiences described in the current application represent a logical extension of Dr. Schick's program of research and will facilitate the acquisition and refinement of advanced research skills necessary to become an independent researcher at the forefront of cutting-edge research in the areas of substance use, emotional processes, and PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are a leading cause of death. Based on prior work finding optimism is related to longevity and health in aging, this project will extensively examine if optimism is associated with less cognitive decline over time and potential mechanisms explaining the relationship. This research can help identify new targets for interventions to improve cognitive health and reduce risk of ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE For ovarian cancer, the most deadly gynecological cancer, racial and ethnic disparities in outcomes are pervasive with a potential underlying role for biological impacts of social disadvantage. The vaginal microbiome may play such a role through its capacity to produce metabolites that shape the tumor microenvironment and its dependence on host factors such as race and ethnicity and poverty. The proposed study will enrich scientific knowledge on the functional implications of racial and ethnic differences in vaginal fluid metabolites, provide public health value by identifying potential prognostic biomarkers for ovarian cancer, and inform the design of therapeutic interventions that involve the modulation of vaginal microbiome to reduce inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chorioamnionitis, or in-utero inflammation is the most common cause of preterm birth and increases the risk for neonatal mortality and Bronchopulmonary dysplasia, a chronic lung disease with debilitating outcomes. This proposal is relevant to public health because it aims to establish that chorioamnionitis causes the development of bronchopulmonary dysplasia by altering the immune responses of the developing lung. Completion of this proposal will provide insight into how in-utero inflammation affects lung development, and characterize therapeutic targets, addressing the goals of the NIH to seek a mechanistic understanding of the developmental immunobiology of lung diseases in early life and reduce the incidence of chronic lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  This proposed diversity supplement will extend the parent grant's research on magnesium (Mg) supplementation in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) and heart failure (HF), examining its differential impact across diverse racial, ethnic, and gender groups. In this research, we will examine the differential effect of Mg supplementation and replacements on incident HF in patients with DM and on mortality and hospitalization in patients with HF by race, gender, and ethnicity. We will also study providers’ and patients’ perspectives on Mg supplementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several lines of evidence indicate that SNX19 may influence neurodegeneration. The goal of this project is to study SNX19 at single-cell resolution in aging autopsy brains, and study the impact of SNX19 on neuronal functions, including synapse loss, autophagy, and neuronal hypoactivity, using 3D cerebral organoids. This project will greatly advance our understanding of SNX19 in neurodegeneration and may reveal potential targets to prevent or treat neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) are the most abundantly mitotic cell in the brain and give rise to oligodendrocytes responsible for myelination through the process of OPC differentiation, which is critical to neurodevelopment and maintenance of myelination, yet the processes mediating this constancy are unclear. Oligodendroglia dynamics require the precise timing of transcription factors expression, that is essential for efficiently remyelinating lesions. The proposed research will determine genetic mechanisms through which the main circadian factor BMAL1 and other key transcription factors control OPC differentiation during myelination, providing critical insights into both normal and aberrant myelination associated with the demyelinating neurological disorder multiple sclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project proposal uses computational modeling, psychopharmacology, and pharmaco-fMRI to investigate the neural and computational mechanisms by which people allocate mental effort when faced with sustained and uncontrollable stress. These data will provide the first direct and multi-modal examination of how people process the controllability of sustained stressors to guide dissociable strategies for allocating mental effort. Collectively, this research will provide an important foundation for understanding the computations, networks, and neurotransmitter systems that drive effortful thoughts and actions, and when and why they fail to do so (e.g., motivational impairments in depression, anxiety, OCD, Alzheimer’s).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Public Health Narrative Women have a two-fold increased lifetime risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) compared to men, an effect that cannot be fully remediated by estrogen supplementation, suggesting that the underlying mechanism is complex. Recent reports have suggested that angiotensin II (ANG II) is involved in AD pathogenesis and that post-menopausal women have higher ANG II activation than aged men. The goal of these studies is to elucidate sex differences in AD pathogenesis by examining the interplay between sex hormones, sex chromosome complement, and ANG II signaling, which may explain the increased incidence of AD in women.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed research is to pinpoint the factors that contribute to the development of linguistic proficiency in young children, with a focus on an implicit form of learning that assesses phonology-to-orthography mapping, a hallmark of reading skill and an assay of reading interventions. There are widespread individual differences in language skills across the US population: as many as 30 million Americans only have rudimentary literacy skills, which negatively affects their health, social, and general life outcomes. Understanding the basic mechanisms that contribute to spoken and written language development will help better inform educational and remediation practices in both typical and atypical populations, and the tasks developed in this proposal may also be applied as diagnostic tools to identify children who may be at risk for reading-related difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Aging is a major risk factor for the onset of chronic diseases and thus slowing aging holds the potential to improve human health. In this project, we utilize a host-microbe model to investigate how microbial stress responses regulate host stress signaling and aging. This study aims to discover novel targets for manipulating the microbes to modulate stress tolerance and slow aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria kills over 600,000 people every year, and causes hundreds of millions of additional infections that impose significant financial burdens on the individuals infected, their families, their communities, and the health system. The Amazon region aims to eliminate the disease by 2030, but there are important gaps in our understanding of malaria epidemiology that will prevent successful elimination. The objective of this proposal is to address one of those gaps: how human mobility contributes to malaria population structure, importation, and diffusion, and do so by leveraging data fusion to effectively link efficient, cost-effective survey and genotyping methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Statistical fine-mapping identifies a handful of putative causal variants from hundreds of GWAS loci for psychiatric disorders, but due to the unavailability of methods, current findings are primarily based on analysis of the European cohort, leading to bias in causal genetic variant discovery and limiting the resolution of findings. This application proposes to develop novel statistical fine-mapping methods for admixed populations and the gene-based Neanderthal introgression burden and performs the most inclusive fine-mapping analysis on psychiatric disorders. By integrating genomic data across ancestries, this work will create a comprehensive list of fine-mapped variants/genes for psychiatric disorders, which serves as a valuable resource for experimentalists and clinicians, providing a generalized list of candidates for translating genetic findings into innovative preventative and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI) is a devastating condition that affects thousands of Americans every year and there are currently no available treatments that restore lost function. There is an urgent need for biomaterial interventions that deliver drugs locally, as systemic administration results in limited drug titer at the injury site; however, current biomaterial approaches are not capable of responding to a patient’s unique inflammatory response. This proposal details the development of a prototype magnetic biomaterial composite capable of releasing precise dosages via magnetically triggered release of an anti-inflammatory growth factor to mitigate the reactivity of astrocytes and create a growth-permissive environment for axonal regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Climate change has widespread and consequential impacts on human health, one of which may be the development of a form of kidney disease in Central America related to heat stress exposure called Mesoamerican Nephropathy. This project studies mechanisms connecting heat stress and Mesoamerican Nephropathy, with a particular focus on metabolic derangements arising during kidney injury that may be targeted with an oral B-vitamin to protect against disease. Understanding how heat stress produces kidney injury and identifying ways to help mitigate this injury is of vital importance in Mesoamerican Nephropathy and beyond as extreme heat events become more and more frequent globally with climate change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aims of this proposal are to identify prevalent patterns of beliefs (belief classes) that underlie the perception that e-cigarettes are as or more harmful than cigarettes among adults who smoke, use these belief classes to develop, pilot test, and refine messages employing neurocognitive and interview responses, and test messages for effects on change in e-cigarette beliefs, intentions, and behaviors among adults who smoke. Educational messages for adults who smoke about the relative risks of e-cigarettes versus cigarettes have the potential to improve understanding of harm reduction and potentially increase e-cigarette use, which may reduce exposure to harmful chemicals and the overall harm from tobacco use. Findings from the proposed research can inform future use of belief class messaging as a communication strategy in educational messaging, and the use of neuroimaging to more accurately predict message effectiveness during pretesting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Clostridioides difficile is the most common healthcare-associated infection, characterized by severe diarrhea and inflammation of the colon, with an estimated 500,000 cases per year in the U.S. and an annual economic burden of >$5 billion. We have an incomplete understanding of how antibiotic usage, forms of innate and acquired antimicrobial resistance among C. difficile strains, and patient co-variates, including immune status and other co-morbid conditions impact risks for disease development. My proposed research objectives will 1) support genomic-epidemiologic analyses of high-dimensional datasets with patient and epidemiologic data to improve our understanding of pathogen and patient factors that promote C. difficile colonization and infection and 2) optimize an active C. difficile hospital surveillance program through the development of more accessible clinical detection assays and functional antibiograms to better detect CD carriage as well as identify factors that may increase patient risks for carriage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Family caregivers of the estimated 698,000 children in the U.S. who are living with serious illness are challenged by gaps in the home-based healthcare system and by social determinants of health (SDOH) that, together, have deleterious impacts on children’s and families’ wellbeing, particularly for those living in historically marginalized communities. Home-based pediatric palliative care (PPC) teams are uniquely poised to support children and families living at home but lack information about families’ day-to-day care experiences and if care is aligned with families’ needs over time. Routinely collecting and rapidly feeding back digitally- captured data about families’ home-based PPC experiences to PPC teams may a) enable tailored clinical actions to increase concordance between families’ needs and home-based PPC, b) support teams to address the health system and SDOH challenges faced by children and families, and c) improve outcomes for children living with serious illness and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While 1 in 4 Americans with diabetes who require insulin therapy ration their insulin to save money, emerging adults with type 1 diabetes report even higher rates of cost related non-adherence and experience worse glycemic outcomes. The goals of this career development project are to understand objective financial burden and subjective financial distress, as well as associations with social determinants of health, cost-coping behaviors, health insurance access, and glycemic outcomes in emerging adults with T1D, leading to the development and pilot testing of a psychoeducational intervention to reduce financial toxicity and cost related non-adherence. This research will advance the understanding of financial toxicity in diabetes and support Dr. Katherine Wentzell on her trajectory towards becoming an independent clinical investigator.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative This Supplement project aims to identify molecular markers of risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in young children with Down syndrome (DS) to advance early screening procedures. We will leverage the ASD-related phenotyping data collected in project #R01HD110542 and collect blood samples concurrently with ASD assessment visits. The addition of biospecimen collection to parent project data collection could facilitate the discovery of molecular indicators of ASD in DS and advance early detection of DS+ASD. It could also identify potential mechanisms that contribute to the onset of DS+ASD and contribute to a new scientific foundation for early intervention and future treatments in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative: Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and AD Related Dementias (ADRD) are among the most prevalent and impactful diseases in the United States and throughout the world and currently there no effective treatments or therapeutics that slow or stop disease. This project seeks to determine whether a metabolite derived from the gut bacteria, which is generated from the breakdown of the dietary amino acid histidine, has negative effects on the vasculature and can modify the pathogenesis of AD. The proposed work will generate new information that can potentially inform the development of new therapeutic strategies for prevention or treatment of AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Maternal obesity, which affects 20 million women in the United States, is one of the strongest risk factors for childhood obesity. Children born to mothers with pre-pregnancy obesity are up to four times more likely to develop obesity in the lifecourse, fueling a cycle of intergenerational transmission complicated by serious health consequences. The proposed study will contribute to our understanding of the role of the in utero environment in shaping neural and behavioral processes that predispose towards obesity development.

PHR: Project Narrative Betacoronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV and pre-emergent bat coronaviruses, pose a significant threat to human health and broad countermeasures to prevent and treat these viruses are urgently needed. The spike subunit 2 (S2) of betacoronaviruses is highly conserved, making it an attractive target for broadly acting therapeutics. This proposal will generate new knowledge about the function of S2-directed antibodies and inform novel approaches to vaccine development and antibody therapeutics for betacoronaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Tobacco use disorder is the most common substance use disorder in the US with many current smokers displaying dependence, which can lead to premature death and further health inequities. American Indian people have the highest tobacco use rates, and it is important to investigate the genetic, epigenetic, and environmental influences on nicotine metabolism and its relationship to smoking cessation efficacy. Merging innovations in pharmacogenomics and community-based participatory research in partnership with the Strong Heart Study, the largest ongoing epidemiological study to involve American Indian communities, to develop an Indigenous precision pharmacogenomics approach to smoking cessation is lacking in the field and holds promise to support and create equitable access to innovative smoking cessation efforts through personalized treatment and culturally appropriate interventions.

PROJECT_TITLE: Precision pharmacogenomics and Indigenous research: A novel approach to tobacco cessation efficacy in American Indian communities

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prescribing cascades are an insidious type of suboptimal medication prescribing that occurs when adverse events from one medication are misinterpreted as symptoms of a new medical condition and result in the addition of a new unnecessary medication, thereby predisposing patients to additional adverse events and major harms. This research will identify important prescribing cascades and rigorously examine their effects on health outcomes in older nursing home residents with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias. Study findings will provide evidence that directly informs medication prescribing, deprescribing, and management to improve the safe use of medications among nursing home residents with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the prevalence of physical inactivity in children with the FC is excessively high and consequently, they have reduced physical fitness and poor long-term outcomes. Pediatric cardiology teams should promote physical activity in children with the FC, but currently they lack the necessary tools to do so in the home setting. This project aims to develop and test the efficacy of a mobile health platform for pediatric cardiology teams to promote physical activity in children with the FC and is relevant to the NHLBI’s mission to develop and optimize novel therapeutic strategies to treat heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Viral lower respiratory tract infections are a major cause of mortality in young children and severe disease can be associated with a suppressed immune response. Myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSC) are known to potently suppress T cells and contribute to impaired immune response. In a single-center, prospective, observational study we will test the hypotheses that expansion of MDSC will be associated with worse clinical outcomes and decreased numbers of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in children with severe viral LRTI, and that pediatric MDSC-induced T cell suppression is preventable through PD-1 blockade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Although many persons living with dementia prefer to remain at home as long as possible, they spend a great deal of time in institutional settings, such as acute care hospitals, skilled-nursing facilities, and long-term care nursing homes. The investigators will assess impact of physician, hospital, and skilled-nursing facility factors related to geriatric care on days spent at home in dementia care using a comprehensive data set. This research will inform future policies to improve care for persons living with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative NUT carcinoma is an incurable highly aggressive cancer driven by the BRD4-NUT oncoprotein that has a median survival of 6.5 months with no effective treatment options. We predict the proposed studies will identify novel mechanisms that synergize to drive NC growth while blocking differentiation that will facilitate precise and effective therapeutic targeting. The findings will greatly impact treatment of NC and likely other BRD4-dependent and pediatric fusion-driven cancers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to develop effective treatments for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) which would limit inflammatory lung injury and improve patient outcomes. Novel cellular immune therapies represent one potential strategy to ameliorate the course of ARDS. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We integrate two technologies to provide rapid point-of-care assessment of Hepatitis C viral load from untreated blood samples at the point of care. One is an ANM technology to isolation and enrichment HCV and EVs in blood samples while the other is a new PCR-free optical microparticle assay that can quantify the virus load directly and rapidly. The integrated device is manual, turn-key and portable. If successful, it is expected to significantly lower the mortality of Hepatitis C virus related liver diseases and introduce a new virus detection platform.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this proposed renewal of a K24 Midcareer Investigator Award is to mentor the next generation of patient-oriented researchers focused on improving the care of vulnerable populations with skin disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation is a common arrhythmia with downstream consequences that include stroke, heart failure, and death. Despite its growing burden, our understanding of the mechanistic basis of AF is incomplete and therapeutic interventions are limited in efficacy, associated with adverse effects, and have not seen any significant advances in years. This proposal aims to exploit a common signaling pathway that may underlie both genetic and acquired forms of atrial fibrillation, with an effort towards identifying novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a relentless interstitial pneumonia that claims the lives of more than 40,000 Americans every year and primarily presents in individuals over the age of 55. The goal of this project is to understand the effects of aging and disrupted metabolism in epithelial progenitor cells within the alveolar space of the fibrotic lung. This study has the potential of identifying new therapeutic options for a terrible disease that, currently, has only two FDA approved medications.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delays in lung cancer diagnosis result in death or other serious harms for tens of thousands of Americans each year. This comprehensive study of the lung cancer diagnostic process aims to describe patient, provider, and system-related factors contributing to these delays. The outcomes of this research will deepen understanding of the diagnostic process for lung cancer, lay the groundwork for developing tailored interventions to improve diagnostic safety and equity, and ultimately yield better patient outcomes in Maryland and nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death and disability in industrialized nations and its prevalence is rising rapidly in developing countries. Mutations in nuclear envelope proteins cause devastating genetic diseases characterized by the presence of high levels of DNA damage and skeletal muscle and cardiac phenotypes. This proposal aims to elucidate the underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms of these diseases in order to strategically design specific therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative RNA posttranscriptional modifications emerged as a key regulatory component of cardiac gene expression and function, influencing various cardiovascular diseases. RBPMS is a novel regulator of RNA posttranscriptional modification in the heart, modulating heart function and disease progression. Through the study of RBPMS, the proposal aims to gain insights into the fundamental mechanisms whereby RNA binding proteins regulate cardiac function and develop new potential therapeutics for cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medicare coverage expansions for telehealth and increasing demand for telehealth services during the COVID-19 pandemic have led to a surge in telehealth use in nursing homes (NHs), which may impact the delivery of care for long- stay residents with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD). This project will examine how telehealth is provided in NHs and its impact on the utilization, quality, and cost of care for long-stay NH residents with ADRD that are Medicare Fee-for-Service beneficiaries or are enrolled in Medicare Advantage. The results of this study will provide critical evidence to clinicians, payers, and policymakers on the uptake and impacts of telehealth use in these facilities and how telehealth is used in long-stay residents with ADRD.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE “Advancing, Expanding, and Streamlining University of New Mexico Health Science Center Animal Resource Facility Rodent Housing Capabilities” requests funds to support purchase of ten ventilated mouse racks with cages/accessories and two Class II Type A2 animal handling biosafety cabinets as flexible clean working stations. The University of New Mexico (UNM) Health Sciences Center (HSC) Animal Resource Facility (ARF) supports approximately 77 biomedical and behavioral research investigator laboratories (44 PI laboratories affected by this project). This project, when completed, will allow us to increase needed cage capacity, improve room and cage air quality, and improve research procedural space as a means to sustain ongoing strategic goals: expand a productive partnership between the NIH and UNM HSC; develop new synergies among research programs to enhance Signature Programs (Brain and Behavioral Illnesses, Cancer, Cardiovascular and Metabolic Disease, Child Health Research, Environmental Health Sciences, and Infectious Diseases and Immunity); and modernize the animal core in compliance with required standards and maintenance of AAALAC accreditation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorders (SUDs) are complex and heritable mental disorders and a serious public health challenge, but the neurogenetic mechanism of addiction remains largely unknown. In this project, we focus on the human brain functional connectome and propose a novel transcriptome-connectome approach by developing novel transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) and meta-analysis methods to identify pleiotropic genes associated with both functional connectivity (FC) change and addiction to understand the neurogenetic mechanism of nicotine and cannabis addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many people with dementia suffer from epilepsy which is often not recognized in this patient population. The proposed research will contribute to fundamental knowledge by identifying clinical and genetic risk factors for epilepsy in people with dementia which could lead to early identification and treatment of epilepsy. This knowledge is relevant to public health because early identification and treatment of epilepsy could improve patient care and outcomes in people with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death and disability in the world, and with an aging population only expected to increase. Genetics play a significant role in the causes and outcomes of a heart attack, yet we know little about the etiology, pathways and modifiers of disease progression, nor do ideal biomarkers exist. Therefore, we are examining genetic effects of a mild heart attack on the left ventricle of the heart in mice and humans, and identifying markers in human and mouse plasma that can diagnose and treat the effects of the heart attack. Subsequently, we will verify these results in a much larger population of patients undergoing heart surgery.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite increasing concerns that stimulant therapy could contribute to stimulant use disorder and overdose in some adults, risk factors for such harms have not been well understood. This project, using existing large datasets, will apply machine learning to assess personal, clinical, and geo-socioeconomic characteristics of stimulant-treated adults to identify risk factors for stimulant use disorder and overdose, and design a clinical decision support tool for clinicians and patients who consider stimulant therapy, with the ultimate goal of reducing the risk of stimulant-related harm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low androgen levels (andropause) in men increases risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia. Models of andropause have been stalled for over a century and are limited to gonadectomy, which does not accurately mimic reduced androgen levels observed in andropause in men. The lack of models of andropause that more closely mimic the human hormonal profile is severely limiting the fields of aging and dementia; thus, the objective of this proposal is to develop two new mouse models of andropause.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD), the most common neurodegenerative disease, affects 1 in 8 people older than 65 in the US and arises through unknown genetic and environmental mechanisms hindering the development of effective therapeutic strategies. We recently discovered that APOE4, the strongest genetic risk factor for AD, alters cholesterol homeostasis in the human brain, which likely adversely interacts with high-fat/ketogenic diets to accelerate AD pathogenesis. Combing innovative in vitro models of the human brain with in vivo mouse studies we will gain an in-depth mechanistic understanding of how APOE genotype interacts with diet to modulate outcomes in AD that will identify potentially non-invasive, genetically targeted therapeutic and diagnostic strategies for AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Neurodegenerative diseases constitute an imminent health challenge, affecting tens of millions of Americans, and have been difficult to effectively treat due to limitations in our capability to study and perturb cellular processes in the brain. This proposal seeks to identify the mechanism of action of a neurotrophic (causing pro-survival and regenerative processes in the brain) small molecule which also affects how iron is used in the cell. This work will advance the molecule’s use as a biochemical tool for the study of the relationship between neurotrophic changes and iron levels and will further lead to new therapeutic targets in neurodegenerative disease, making the project relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to expanding the knowledge base of medical science and reducing illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alcohol use and suicidal thoughts and behaviors are strongly related, but the exact relationship between alcohol and suicide risk is poorly understood. Behavioral economic decision-making, such as rapid devaluing of delayed rewards (i.e., delay discounting), appears to be a common factor for increased alcohol use and suicidal thoughts and behaviors. The proposed research is to better understand how behavioral economic decision-making differs between individuals who use alcohol and those who use alcohol and have suicidal thoughts and behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: We propose studies to investigate the mechanisms by which eosinophils contribute to antibacterial host defenses during opportunistic pneumococcal bacterial infection. These studies are relevant to public health because they will provide mechanistic insight into immune responses in hosts with allergic asthma during synergistic viral and bacterial co-infection. Identified mechanisms may provide novel insights into unforeseen targets of intervention that may be broadly applicable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extracellular vesicles (EVs) serve as mediators for cell-cell communication to maintain tissue homeostasis and contribute to age-related pathologies, in which angiogenesis is impaired. Given that Y-RNAs are one of the most abundant EV-enclosed non-coding RNAs and the levels of Y-RNAs correlate with age-related cardiovascular diseases, this proposal seeks to understand the role of EV-enclosed Y-RNAs in endothelial cell (EC) senescence and age-related decline in angiogenesis. If this study proves that Y-RNA in EC-derived EVs inhibits EC senescence and reverses the age-dependent impairment of angiogenesis, this work will lead to the development of new and better EV-based strategies for age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Glioblastoma is the most common primary brain tumor in adults, is essentially incurable, and is associated with significant morbidity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Cognitive impairment manifests in later life from the accrual of exposures in the preceding decades, which also exhibit disparities by race. There is consistent evidence that mid- and late-life diet patterns are linked to cognitive decline, but the underlying pathways are incompletely understood. In this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that gut microbiome-related metabolites are associated with subsequent cognitive impairment, and influence the rate of conversion of amyloid- and vascular-related dementia; these studies will improve our ability to identify individuals at risk, identify potential reasons for racial differences in those risks, and clarify the role of gut microbiome-related metabolites in cognitive function over the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The focal point of this project is to decode the cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate the metabolic reprogramming occurring in glioma and the tumor microenvironment, which is one of the major mechanisms contributing to tumor progression. I propose to investigate how pH-dependent metabolic pathways contribute to glioma growth and glioma-vascular interaction. These studies aim to uncover new regulatory mechanisms of glioma metabolism and glioma-vascular metabolic communication, offering potential avenues for the identification of therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nuclear speckles are distinct compartments within the cell’s nucleus that regulate turning genes on or off and are composed of several different proteins and RNA. Genes are successfully turned on only when specific proteins reach the right location in the nucleus at the right time. I propose to develop tools to discover how proteins in the nuclear speckles assemble with their partner RNA and achieve the correct placement of the proteins and RNA.
