IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Characterizing the Function of Cyclic di-AMP on Chlamydial Growth and Differentiation Chlamydiae are important pathogens of humans and significant causes of morbidity, causing a range of illnesses including sexually transmitted diseases, trachoma, pneumonia, and other respiratory tract infections. In addition, these bacteria undergo a unique developmental cycle that is essential for their growth and ability to cause disease. The work proposed here is to identify the function of a compound produced by the bacterium and how it regulates its growth and developmental cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal aims to establish robust phenotyping pipelines for early detection of Collagen Type IV-Associated Nephropathy (COL4A-AN) using electronic health record (EHR) data. To overcome diagnostic challenges of this prevalent monogenic form of chronic kidney disease (CKD), the study focuses on utilizing Natural Language Processing (NLP) to extract nuanced phenotypic traits from unstructured clinical narratives and build accurate and portable prediction models. These models lay the foundation for developing effective EHR-based decision support tools that enable clinicians to identify patients with genetic CKD subtypes, even when unfamiliar with specific genetic syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) with autologous gene therapy is a promising approach to treating non-malignant blood diseases; however, optimization of stem cell mobilization, transplant conditioning regimens, and stable engraftment of gene-edited hematopoietic stem cells is essential to maximizing the curative potential of HSCT. This proposal seeks to overcome these major barriers by investigating novel stem cell mobilization and antibody-based transplant conditioning strategies and leveraging these approaches to improve therapy of sickle cell disease. These studies will yield novel insights that will advance the basic science and translational potential of autologous gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapidly growing population of older incarcerated adults in the United States is at high-risk for delirium due to higher rates of known delirium risk factors and incarceration-specific risk factors, such as accelerated aging and decreased delivery of evidence-based delirium prevention measures in the hospital. Because there is virtually no data on delirium in this population, this project aims to establish foundational data on delirium epidemiology (including prevalence, incidence, and risk factors), on the frequency of delivery of evidence- based delirium prevention measures (e.g. cognitive stimulation, ambulation), and on potential barriers and facilitators to delivery of those measures. The definitive goal of this work is to design, test, and implement an incarceration-specific approach to evidence-based delirium measures that will reduce the risk of delirium in the marginalized and high-risk population of older incarcerated adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic wound infections are a major medical burden, as they are difficult to treat due to an improper immune response and the presence of dangerous bacterial pathogens. This proposal will investigate key aspects of the diabetic wound environment including the immune response, hyperglycemia, and polymicrobial interactions to provide insight into why many patients have poor healing outcomes. These studies seek to more fully understand the molecular mechanisms by which bacteria evade the diabetic immune system in this environment to inform more targeted therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health through the development of a new geriatric palliative care delivery model with potential to improve serious illness communication, decision-making, and goal-concordant care for hospitalized older adults with advanced cancer discharged to skilled nursing facilities. This proposal is consistent with the National Institute on Aging’s mission to develop effective strategies to improve the interaction and experience of older adults near the end of life with the health system and to identify ways to support family caregivers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pontocerebellar Hypoplasia Type 1b (PCH1b) is a devastating inherited neurological disorder that preferentially affects specific regions of the brain, the pons and the cerebellum, causing children born with this condition to have dramatically reduced lifespans. The mutations that cause PCH1b occur in a gene that encodes a critical component of a molecular machine that is important for the regulation of gene expression. The proposed studies exploit the fruit fly (Drosophila) as a model system to provide insight into molecular mechanisms underpinning PCH1b.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Metabolic-dysfunction associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) is a highly prevalent liver complication that disproportionately effects Hispanic/Latino patients. Lifestyle modifications focused on weight loss and management are recommended as the first-line treatment. This study will develop and test the feasibility of a culturally appropriate, multilevel lifestyle intervention to provide MASLD-specific education and support while also addressing the influences of family, healthcare providers and access to social services on lifestyle behaviors and weight management in Hispanic/Latino patients with MASLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Addiction is a pressing health concern in the United States, and deaths from cocaine overdose have steadily increased over the past 5 years. Despite its increased prevalence, the intrinsic brain mechanisms that control response to cocaine are not clearly defined. Recent studies suggest that an endogenous signaling peptide in the brain, nociceptin, has potential to suppress addictive behaviors induced by cocaine. The proposed studies will fully explore the potential of nociceptin to block cocaine drug seeking behaviors, and will characterize the nociceptin circuits in the brain that may contribute to its suppressive actions. The findings may pave a path towards a novel therapeutic strategies to treat cocaine substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Suckling and mastication behaviors are critical for the survival of all species. Unraveling the mechanism of activation and modulation of sensory-motor circuits during normal development is essential to elucidate muscle activity and how their dysfunction impacts neurodegenerative diseases. This proposal is designed to study the sensory-motor orofacial circuits in neonatal mice under normal conditions and in the neurodevelopmental motor neuron disease, spinal muscular atrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is well established that the hippocampus, entorhinal cortex, and prefrontal cortex as well as the coordination of activity across these brain regions is disrupted in any of the major neurological, neurodegenerative, and psychiatric diseases. Despite the knowledge that these circuits are particularly vulnerable in brain diseases, the diversity of memory computations that these brain regions support is only beginning to be revealed. By identifying how neural computations are performed and coordinated across brain regions, our results will be the foundation for therapies that profoundly improve cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will investigate the role of LZK and DLK, a pair of MAP kinase kinase kinases, in the multicellular responses to spinal cord injury, which will provide novel insight on the neuron intrinsic and extrinsic regulation of axonal repair after spinal cord injury. If manipulating LZK and/or DLK is found to enhance tissue and axonal repair after spinal cord injury, this would pave the way to develop therapeutic intervention targeting LZK and/or DLK. The ultimate goal is to improve the quality of life for people with spinal cord injury or related neurological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a large unmet need for developing new approaches to Treatment-Resistant Depression (TRD), a highly prevalent and debilitating disorder with major impact on public health. Clinical trials investigating deep brain stimulation (DBS), a neurosurgical approach widely used in neurological disorders, in the treatment of TRD have led to inconsistent results, possibly due to inadequate technology to precisely identify, target, and modulate the abnormal networks that mediate this disorder. The proposed studies will investigate the feasibility and safety of using a next-generation DBS system to “steer” stimulation simultaneously to two different brain regions implicated in TRD that may lead to new and better treatments for this and other severe neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GBM is the most aggressive primary brain tumor with a two-year survival rate of less than 50% following surgical resection, radiation and chemotherapy. It is characterized by extensive hypoxia-induced, mitochondria-dependent phenotypic changes such as a glycolytic respiration, decreased ability to undergo apoptosis and extensive invasiveness which are linked to GBM's resistance to radiation and chemotherapy. Mitochondrial LonP1 is an ATP-stimulated protease, directly up-regulated by HIF-1α. LonP1 is overexpressed in human malignant gliomas and its elevated expression levels are associated with high glioma tumor grade and poor patient survival. Therefore, regulation of mitochondrial function by inhibiting LonP1 protease could represent a novel approach for GBM and potentially other fast-growing malignancies which heavily depend on hypoxic adaptation. The proposed project is based on our preliminary results obtained from in vitro (cell-based) studies with our LonP1 inhibitor compound BT317 and in vivo LonP1-overexpression xenograft models studies. BT317 is a small molecule compound and highly effective against multiple GBM cell lines – identifying BT317 as a potentially new therapy for this universally fatal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) affect 2.8 million individuals each year in the United States and often cause long-lasting cognitive and mood alterations, with the greatest external cause for TBI being falls, especially in older adults over 65 years of age. Given that behavioral tests performed to date after experimental brain trauma have primarily focused on motor and spatial learning deficits and not on commonly-reported complex attention impairments, this R01 application aims to characterize alterations in sustained attention, behavioral flexibility, and anxiety-like responses after experimental TBI in both young adult and aged rats, as well as to address mechanistic questions regarding altered cholinergic neurotransmission responsible for such behavioral impairments by restoring behavioral performance and acetylcholine brain marker levels with NS 1738 - a positive allosteric modulator of alpha-7-nicotinic acetylcholine receptors – alone or in a combination with enriched environment housing as a preclinical model of neurorehabilitation. Integrating animal models of higher-order cognitive processing in the behavioral battery after TBI is paramount to finding clinically-relevant therapeutic targets, and therefore the proposed studies will be carried out in males and females, an approach which may prove valuable for translation from bench to bedside and advanced rehabilitation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of mechanisms linking demyelination to neuronal hyperexcitability and neurodegeneration will increase understanding of the pathogenesis of numer- ous neurological disorders and diseases including multiple sclerosis, trauma, and stroke. The project is relevant to NIH's mission, as the research pursues fundamental knowledge of glial-neuronal interactions in the brain, and how they go awry in the context of demyelinating disease, which may provide a foundation for the develop- ment of novel and more effective strategies to treat neurological disorders by selectively targeting specific glial- neuronal interaction mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Memory allows us to remember specific past experiences, but also find commonalities across experiences generalizable to novel situations. The proposed research will improve our understanding of mechanisms supporting memory specificity and generalization, their contribution to decision-making, and their implementation in the healthy brain. These findings will generate new predictions about the causes of a wide variety of memory impairments, such as reduced memory specificity in aging and Alzheimer’s disease, imbalance of specificity and generalization learning in anxiety, depression, and autism, and mixed patterns of impairments following a stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: There is a possible connection between insulin resistance, metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease, and Alzheimer’s disease, but the biology behind this connection is presently unknown. The current proposal examines this connection by investigating the impact of age-associated changes in peripheral metabolism, mainly focusing on insulin resistance and inflammation in the liver, on neurodegeneration. Our findings will identify a novel function of liver macrophages and cytokines in bridging the connection between the aging liver and neurodegeneration, potentially identifying new therapeutic targets to treat metabolic liver disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and other age-related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: "TDP-43 proteinopathy" refers to a relatively recently identified, common cause of cognitive impairment in aging (affecting approximately 50% of persons beyond age 85 years). It is increasingly clear that a variety of different factors in the aged brain can cause or exacerbate TDP-43 proteinopathy. We here propose a research program to characterize the disease-driving mechanisms of age-related TDP-43 proteinopathy and to use those data to help support future research efforts in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A significant number of studies suggest that aggregated proteins in frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and Lewy body dementia (LBD), such as TDP-43 and α-synuclein, can spread from cell to cell, yet little is known about mechanisms of how the abnormal proteins spread. Our preliminary studies show that redox-based post- translational modifications (e.g., S-nitrosylation) of critical proteins contribute to aberrant aggregation and spread of TDP-43 and α-synuclein. In the proposed studies, we will determine if redox-dependent regulation of TDP-43 and p62 contributes to pathological spread of TDP-43 and α-synuclein in hiPSC (human induced pluripotent stem cell) and mouse transgenic models of FTD and LBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) affects over 5.7 million Americans and is expected to rise to nearly 14 million people by 2060, as the number of people living with this disease doubles every 5 years. Cognitive and memory impairments are a defining characteristic of AD and are thought to arise from dysfunctional circuits spanning multiple brain areas. Our proposed studies will advance foundational knowledge of cognition- and memory- related brain circuits across AD clinical stages and their links to neuropathology, and more generally, also contribute novel tools for examining dynamical causal circuits underlying human brain function and dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This new R61/R33 application seeks to address the unmet need for reliable, efficient, and objective preclinical procedures to improve translational predictive validity in analgesic drug discovery. The crisis of opioid abuse and overdose deaths has stimulated the effort to develop non-opioid, non-addicting analgesics, and this effort depends in part on preclinical procedures for analgesic efficacy testing with high predictive validity in general and resistance to false-positive effects in particular. Here we propose a new procedure with excellent potential to have high sensitivity to analgesics, selectivity for analgesics vs. non-analgesics, and additional attributes to promote replicability of results, efficiency in experimental design, and objective and quantitative data collection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Polysomnographic Biomarkers of Brain Aging RELEVANCE: Loss of brain function including memory and executive function is an inevitable part of aging, yet some individuals’ brains age better than others. We recently developed the brain age index – a statistical model that reports the difference between an individual’s apparent brain age, based on the pattern of overnight EEG (brain waves), and their chronologic age. This project will use existing data from 4 large cohorts to further develop and validate sleep EEG-based biomarkers of brain health, by characterizing the relationships of brain waves during sleep to cognitive health and to the structural health of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section Suicide has been a leading cause of death and disease burden for the past 50 years, and existing treatments  fall woefully short of meeting this immense need because they are not scalable. People who perceive suicide  as relatively less negative/aversive are more likely to attempt suicide. This K23 proposal aims to test whether a  highly scalable, smartphone-delivered treatment adapted for adults with relatively frequent and recent suicidal  thoughts/behavior (STB) is safe, acceptable and can increase suicide-aversion (i.e., make suicide seem  worse) and thereby reduce STB severity and incidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is focused on studying a critical step in the development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), microglia activation, which contributes to inflammation and disease progression. The proposal is designed to examine the contributions of circulating cell-free DNA on microglial activation and chronic inflammation. The proposed research lays the groundwork for clinical studies to identify individuals with AD and chronic inflammation who can benefit from treatments targeting microglia activation pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In the fight against Alzheimer’s disease, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) holds promise as a non-invasive, widely available, relatively inexpensive source of biomarkers that could help advance clinical trials and clinical care. A barrier to fMRI-based biomarkers is the challenge of individual precision, given the high noise levels of fMRI data. This project will produce novel statistical techniques for fMRI analysis capable of extracting accurate, nuanced functional brain features in individuals and will deploy those techniques to develop fMRI-based biomarkers of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) are a group of chronic inflammatory illnesses of the gastrointestinal tract that represents a significant public health and economic burden. There is an urgent need to improve our understanding of modulators of intestinal inflammation in order to identify novel therapeutic targets. Based on my recent findings that TRPV1+ nociceptors modulate the intestinal microbiota and mitigate intestinal inflammation during acute intestinal damage and inflammation, the focus of this proposal is to elucidate the role of these neuro-immune interactions and neuron-microbiota axis in regulating intestinal inflammation and tissue protection in the context of IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Experience-dependent refinement and efficient memory storage in CNS circuits is thought to require homeostatic forms of plasticity, such as synaptic scaling and intrinsic plasticity, that stabilize overall neuronal activity by endowing individual neurons with a `firing rate set point'. Here we will investigate the mechanisms and function of these set points, and ask how their loss impacts critical features of circuit function including memory stability. These studies will enhance our understanding of neurological disorders that arise from aberrant circuit excitability, and will provide a new avenue of investigation into disorders (such as PTSD) that arise from excessive generalization during aversive learning.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanisms and function of firing rate homeostasis in cortical circuits

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Millions of people are exposed to repetitive head impacts (RHI) from American football and other contact sports and may be at increased risk for dementia including due to the neurodegenerative disease, chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). Research diagnostic criteria for the clinical manifestation of CTE pathology were developed, known as traumatic encephalopathy syndrome (TES); however, making a CTE diagnosis during life is limited because there are currently no validated biomarkers for underlying CTE pathology, longitudinal studies are lacking, distinctions of the clinical features and biomarkers of CTE from those of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias are unknown, and risk and resilience factors of TES are unclear. This R01 will retain and grow a unique, well-characterized, longitudinal established cohort of people at high risk for CTE and test aims focused on advancing our ability to diagnose CTE in life in order to pave the way for identification of treatment and prevention targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Although the last five years have seen tremendous advancements in the use of tau biomarkers in blood, there remains a need to discover new and improved markers that will better inform on risk of cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) or aid in an earlier diagnosis of progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) or other non- AD tauopathies. Results from our innovative studies will provide additional evidence of tau proteoform differences in the human brain between AD and PSP and explore how tau immunotherapy treatment influences what forms are identified in blood. These studies will identify biomarker candidates for exploration of clinical utility across primary tauopathies, and will have potential to inform on progression, enable earlier diagnosis, and enable clinical trials at earlier stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community health centers (CHCs) serve a large share of racial and ethnic minority patients and have disproportionately low colorectal cancer (CRC) screening rates compared to the general population. Even a delay of a few years for screening initiation can lead to increased CRC incidence and mortality. Using a rigorous mixed methods approach, the proposed research will identify equity-driven implementation strategies to initiate CRC screening in previously unscreened individuals 45 to 54 at a CHC with a predominantly Black patient population, and advance our understanding of strategies to increase CRC screening in the newly eligible population aged 45 to 49 at CHCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Substance use disorders (SUDs) are prevalent, have a large societal impact worldwide, and are associated with many adverse psychological and health outcomes including increased rates of injury and elevated disease risk. The majority of individuals diagnosed with a SUD also meet diagnostic criteria for at least one additional SUD posing further psychiatric and medical risk; however, the ability to distinguish the genetic and biological risk for specific SUDs, and influences shared across co-occurring SUDs, remains limited. An advanced understanding of the genetic and neurobiological influences on real-world patterns of substance use, SUDs, and SUD co-occurrence has the potential to inform SUD intervention and treatment modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing new combination strategies to treating bladder cancer which a common and lethal disease. This project will dissect the mechanisms by which tumor-associated macrophages drive resistance to current systemic therapies and will investigate the mechanisms of tumor-macrophage crosstalk that prevent immunogenic cancer cell death with the ultimate goal of developing more effective macrophage- directed strategies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission to lengthening life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite being one of the most common bacterial infections worldwide, the diagnostic strategies for urinary tract infections (UTI) are surprisingly insensitive, which can result in mistreatment. The proposed research will use human genomic data, gene expression data at single cell resolution, and UTI mouse models to find genetic risk factors associated with developing severe or recurrent UTI. These results will reveal novel genes and cell types that have antimicrobial properties in the kidney and bladder, which can lead to more precise UTI diagnoses and tailored therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Patients who have received joint replacement are at risk for periprosthetic joint infection, a serious condition which can lead to morbidity, disability, amputation, and even death. We will investigate how an injectable biomaterials-based vaccine system improves host immunity to prevent Staphylococcus aureus periprosthetic joint infection in murine and rabbit models. This project will lead to a better understanding of immunity in device- related infection and characterize a new vaccine modality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study evaluates the cumulative effect of toxic stress from the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) with maternal social determinants of health in preterm infant and maternal dyads. Measures of epigenetic alternations serve as a robust indicator of biologic changes secondary to toxic stress. These data are vital for the development and testing of much needed targeted stress reducing interventions that will improve long-term health and development in vulnerable dyads requiring NICU hospitalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delirium is a type of acute confusion experienced frequently by older adults after surgery or during critical illness that is associated with subsequent long-term cognitive impairment and increased risk for Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementia. Yet, we currently lack drugs to prevent delirium due to a poor understanding of its underlying biological mechanisms. Using immunoassays and unbiased proteomics of cerebrospinal fluid obtained from older surgical and critically ill patients, the current study aims to test whether increased levels of activated complement proteins, a set of powerful inflammatory mediators, are associated with 1) postoperative delirium, 2) intensive care unit (ICU) delirium, and 3) post-ICU long-term cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) cases are projected to rapidly expand in low- and middle- income countries in the coming decades and government cash transfer programs may be effective interventions. This proposal will address NIA strategic priorities by answering key questions about the amounts, durations, target recipients, and adult life course timing of cash transfer income necessary to reduce ADRD risk and explore potential mechanisms through household assets and spending on cognitively stimulating resources. Results will provide actionable evidence to inform the optimal design of cash transfer programs to support the health and longevity of the rapidly aging populations that they serve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to revitalize research training in kidney, urologic and hematologic (KUH) science by creating a new program in the Northwest US: the Northwest COmprehensive Research Training in Kidney, Urologic and Hematologic Sciences (NCOR-KUH) Program. The VISION of the Program is to train the next generation of KUH scientists who will drive scientific innovation to improve the lives of patients with KUH diseases. To realize this vision, the MISSION of the Program is to create an integrated KUH scientific environment across five institutions (University of Washington, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, Seattle Children’s Hospital, Puget Sound VA and Bloodworks Northwest) to furnish trainees with world-class hands-on research training, mentorship, education, and networking to foster their personal and professional development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to human health because it can directly benefit a group of cancer patients that currently have extremely poor prognosis by providing them with targeted treatment options that overcome chemotherapy resistance. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences max): Kidney stones represent a significant burden on the US healthcare system with approximately 10% of Americans suffering from this disease at some point in their life. The objective of this proposed body of work is to develop a nanotechnology based treatment that can specifically target kidney stones and cause stone comminution through irradiation with a low power near-infrared laser in a non-contact mode. This project will advance the career development of the investigator and provide the basis for the introduction of a paradigm changing treatment modality for urolithiasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Projective Narrative Pediatric otitis media poses a significant burden on our healthcare system: it is the fourth most expensive condition among children in the United States and impacts hearing and speech, leading to delays in cognitive development and school performance. This proposed project will study the effectiveness of surgical treatment of otitis media using a large multi-institutional database and a prospective cohort study; and form a multi- institutional pediatric otolaryngology clinical collaborative. Results and knowledge gained from this proposal will prepare the applicant to conduct future multi-institutional pragmatic trials to define optimal surgical otitis media management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuronal cell polarity is a prerequisite for its unique function in receiving and relaying electrochemical signals, yet we lack a basic understanding of how it is achieved. We will combine human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) and high-resolution cryo-electron tomography to investigate the role of biomolecular condensates proposed to impact the organization of the early secretory pathway in polarized neurons. Our approach will provide an unprecedented insight into the molecular organization of secretory hubs in neurons, and may uncover how neuronal cell polarity is established and maintained.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) undergo rigorous treatment regimens yet frequently experience high cancer recurrence rates and cancer death, leading to uncertainty, distress, and poor quality of life. The proposed research project aims to develop, refine, and pilot test a nurse-led, coping, and supportive care intervention for patients with TNBC during the critical transition from curative therapy to surveillance, designed to alleviate distress, improve quality of life, and increase stress-coping skills. By focusing on this previously understudied high-risk group of patients with breast cancer, study findings will inform future research utilizing risk-stratified survivorship care models with potential applications to other high-risk cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to ethical, legal, and social implications of genomic information sharing as it focuses on evaluating information models which support stewardship of biospecimens and data – including genomic information. This work has the potential to account for a variety of expressions of biospecimen contributors’ preferences and values, as expressed in consent forms, and promotes transparent and ethical use of downstream applications such as those leveraging machine learning and artificial intelligence approaches. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the goals of the National Human Genome Research Institute’s Ethical, Legal and Social Implications Research Program, including their focus on research for Genomic Research Design and Implementation, specifically in Data Science and Data Sharing.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Rutgers University New Jersey Medical School is requesting funds for the installation of an integrated automatic watering system (AWS) from Avidity Sciences to meet the needs of the expanding rodent facility. The Integrated system consists of a Chlorination system and a distribution system to deliver clean drinking water directly to the rodent cages. This system will benefit the research of over 42 NIH funded investigators by delivering constant and consistent supply of high quality water with precision, thus, ensuring reproducibility of results in our highly sensitive animal disease models; creating a significant gain in efficiency of operations, reduced costs and save staff time; reduce repetitive motion injuries in staff members; and providing “Green Energy” savings by eliminating the use of excess water, non-recyclable plastic water bottles and disposable plastic bags that are currently used in the facility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the importance of a timely Alzheimer’s disease (AD) diagnosis, AD is underdiagnosed in real-world community settings, particularly in understudied populations. Our objectives are to identify undiagnosed AD in non-Hispanic white, Hispanic/Latino, and non-Hispanic African American groups utilizing disease trajectories and genetics followed by validation and replication. Our contributions will enable the application of disease trajectories in precision medicine and future work to reduce the bias of underdiagnosis in understudied populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Post stroke cognitive impairment (PSCI) is a frequent complication experienced by stroke survivors and yet there remain gaps in both fundamental knowledge of how cerebral vascular contributions to dementia interact with likely preexisting neurodegenerative burdens among stroke survivors and practical decision support tools to aid in clinicians in prognosticating and managing PSCI to optimize stroke recovery and prevention of recurrent stroke. This project addresses these two gaps by developing novel machine learning algorithms to process a large and ethnically diverse routine clinical neuroimage and electronic health record dataset to predict PSCI and also assess, through a prospective study, added benefits of incorporating novel physiological and biological metrics of cerebrovascular and neurodegenerative underpinnings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes in Medicare coverage for telehealth during the COVID-19 pandemic may have long-standing effects on the delivery of care at the end of life (EOL) to NH residents with Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's disease-related dementias (ADRD). This project will examine patterns of telehealth provision for NH residents at the EOL, particularly for palliative care, advance care planning, and hospice use, and the association between telehealth access and the quality and cost of care for NH residents, by race/ethnicity, dual eligibility, and rurality. The results will provide critical evidence for clinicians, payers, and policymakers on the uptake, applications, and impacts of telehealth use for NH residents with ADRD at the EOL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of the over 1 million people in the United States living with Parkinson's disease and related disorders (PDRD) such as Lewy-body dementia (the second most common degenerative dementia after Alzheimer's disease), are cared for by medically untrained family members. Though Lewy-body dementia is specifically named by NIH as an Alzheimer's and Related disorder (ADRD) and an area of high priority research, there has been minimal research of care resources and support for these carepartners who face physical, emotional, spiritual, and financial challenges. To engage relevant targets to improve carepartner wellbeing, support, and preparedness, this proposal will use stakeholder engagement research methods to identify the dimensions and positive and negative aspects of caregiving, and partner with former PDRD carepartners, adapt, design, and conduct a pilot randomized control trial of the peer-led Competence, Autonomy, Relatedness, and Connections (CARe Connections) intervention that targets what matters most to PDRD carepartners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative JC virus is a human polyomavirus which infects and establishes lifelong infections in upwards of 70% of the human population. While JCV is considered to pass through the oral/fecal route, its primary site of infection has remained elusive. In this proposal we will address how JCV interacts with the gastrointestinal tract which will allow us to better understand, in the long term, how this interaction impacts the establishment of a lifelong infection of the kidneys.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: The proposed study will leverage data collected in a completed randomized clinical trial (D- CARE) to examine end-of-life care for persons living with dementia—outcomes not included in the original trial. The large number of decedents in D-CARE provides a unique opportunity to study how community-dwelling persons with dementia die and compare end-of-life outcomes between two effective dementia care management interventions. Completion of these new aims will provide greater insight into how best to care for PLWD near the end of life, including information about end-of-life care preferences, met or unmet care needs near death, and healthcare utilization in the last 6 months of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative  Deficits in cognitive behavioral flexibility lead to disability and pose barriers to recovery in many mental disorders, including schizophrenia, autism, post-traumatic stress disorder, and dementias, but these symptoms are largely unaddressed by conventional pharmacologic or somatic therapies. To develop new ways of intervening to improve or even prevent these neurocognitive impairments, we must better understand the underlying brain circuits, their networking, and how they coordinate their activity. This research proposal will identify brain circuits and specific neurochemical signals facilitating flexible learning and adaptive behavior, with the long-term goal of advancing the development of new treatments for neurocognitive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although current behavioral weight loss treatments achieve clinically significant weight loss and corresponding health benefits, most participants regain their weight soon after treatment. The proposed project will test the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of using just-in-time adaptive interventions (JITAIs) that facilitate mindfulness, acceptance, and self-compassion to help participants respond more adaptively to small weight regains and ultimately, achieve better long-term weight control. If effective, these interventions can be used as an easily disseminable, low-cost supplement to behavioral weight loss treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite recent advances in therapeutic options showing promising results for patients with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP), there is still no FDA-approved therapy, and not all patients respond to these therapies. There is a critical need to understand the pathogenic mechanisms that underlie PAP in order to develop novel therapies. This proposal is the first step to unveil these mechanisms by evaluating how disruption in granulocyte- macrophage colony-stimulating factor signaling leads to lipid dysregulation and surfactant accumulation in the alveolar space.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Persistent irritability in childhood impacts up to 20 percent of youth and is associated with elevated risk for adolescent mental health problems, such as anxiety and depression, as well as significant functional impairment, including school problems, family problems, and problems with peers. By seeking to understand how prenatal exposure to PAH affects children’s irritability and brain function, this project is a first step towards identifying modifiable environmental risk factors and establishing potential etiologic pathways for persistent irritability. Such knowledge may be used in public health interventions to improve the quality of children’s environment and support the development of novel treatment options for children with irritability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Narrative Using cannabis as a sleep aid may carry specific health harms for women. Cannabis use can affect biological sleep directly or through altering stress-reactivity systems, and such relationships may be influenced by fluctuating reproductive hormones. The goal of this application is to study women across the menstrual cycle and compare sleep, cortisol, and autonomic nervous system functioning on nights of cannabis use versus nights of no use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer disease (AD) and Parkinson disease (PD) are heterogeneous, multifactorial disease that selectively affects certain regions of the brain. In this proposal, we will use our established in vitro and in vivo mouse experimental systems and the cutting-edge technologies of spatial transcriptomics and scRNA-seq to systematically evaluate ten candidate TF in regulating astrocyte activation their roles in AD and PD pathogenesis. These TFs are excellent candidate targets for the development of effective AD or PD treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative MicroRNAs are a very particular type of RNA molecules that can regulate many cellular processes at once - including the cell’s pathological processes – and have been understudied because common genomics tool do not usually detect them. Here we serendipitously discovered that one of these microRNAs was very abundant in the neurons most vulnerable to Alzheimer’s disease, and we propose to demonstrate that it is used by vulnerable neurons to keep pathological tau in check, before it goes down as the disease unfolds. We propose to define its mode of action and investigate if it could represent a good therapeutic target for early stages of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative For reasons that are still unknown, Alzheimer’s Disease only affects, in its earliest stages, neurons involved in new memory formation. The molecular events that are taking place around these neurons before the first symptoms even occur, and that determine the entire course of the disease are not known, and it is therefore challenging to design drugs to block early stages of neurodegeneration. Here we propose to use cutting-edge genomics and proteomics technologies to fully describe the molecular events taking place when pathological proteins start to aggregate in the most vulnerable region of the brain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pakistan is the fifth most populous country in the world and more than 63% of all marital unions in Pakistan are consanguineous, posing a greater impact on genetically transmitted diseases like Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementia, which has never been systematically studied before. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This study examines the relationship between disasters and adverse substance use outcomes, both of which have increased dramatically over the past several decades with no signs of abating. This study uses quasi- experimental methods and longitudinal and spatial modeling to determine whether disasters have affected substance use outcomes, including through mechanisms such as psychological distress and treatment and drug market disruption, by combining data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the National Survey on Drug Use and Health, the FBI Uniform Crime Reports, and an underutilized dataset of all disaster declarations from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). By examining these mechanisms as well as analyses by key aggregate- and individual-level sociodemographic characteristics, this project has the potential to improve morbidity and mortality by informing how resources and individual- and community-level interventions may be deployed to intervene on drug-related problems in the face of future disasters.

PHR: Narrative This study will characterize unique subtypes of COPD-related abnormalities in airway and chest wall deformation between two lung volumes, identify their associations in COPD and comorbidities, and assess their impacts on disease progression and clinical outcomes. This project will leverage established datasets from nationwide longitudinal lung studies and deliver chest CT-based automated metrics of lung volume-determined airway and chest wall deformation, normative models, computation of standardized scores of alterations in airway and chest wall metrics, and characterization of unique airway and chest wall subtypes in COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative NEXMIF is a novel X-linked ASD gene and an increasing number of female individuals with NEXMIF haploinsufficiency have been reported to demonstrate autistic symptoms. In the brain, neurons lacking NEXMIF proteins contain a normal copy of the NEXMIF gene which is inactivated due to its localization in the silenced X-chromosome. We therefore propose to reactivate the dormant Nexmif copy by X chromosome reactivation, and to determine whether the potential therapeutic reagents are able to rescue the cellular defects and behavioral abnormalities in female heterozygous mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative To address the challenge of demand for ADRD care outpacing supply, we propose a novel modeling approach, macro-simulation, to simultaneously account for supply and demand factors. Using the family as a decision-making unit, the model describes the tradeoffs families face when using a combination of formal and informal care to meet the needs of their elderly members. This analytical tool will shed light on the aggregate consequences of growing care needs and widening care shortages and how targeted policy interventions may help.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Despite revolutionizing the treatment of hematological malignancies, chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy has had limited efficacy against solid tumors including pediatric neuroblastoma, which is associated with a dismal prognosis upon recurrence. To overcome the molecular and cellular mechanisms that limit the efficacy of CAR T cells against neuroblastoma, we will use targeted radionuclide therapies that selectively deliver low dose radiation to all tumors throughout a patient’s body to stimulate infiltration and activation of CAR T cells in these sites. We expect that this project will provide the preclinical data needed to justify clinical studies that will test the safety and efficacy of combining for the first-time targeted radionuclide therapy and CAR T cells for treatment of children with neuroblastoma and potentially any type of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral neuropathies, characterized by sensory and motor dysfunction, are a major clinical problem and can be a consequence of genetic disorders, metabolic diseases, environmental stressors, or injury. Due to a lack of direct treatment options patients with peripheral neuropathies are often prescribed medications to treat symptoms (e.g. pain medication), that do not promote nerve repair, highlighting a limited understanding of how peripheral nerve plasticity is induced and maintained. In this application, we will investigate new cellular mechanisms governing Schwann cell plasticity in an effort to identify novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of nerve injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The utilization of Diabetes Self-Management Education and Support (DSMES) services is low, despite their proven benefits to patients. This study aims to understand factors associated with low utilization of DSMES and to identify potential DSMES provider opinion leaders by: (1) exploring the association of demographic, health status, provider availability, rural and urban residence status, and DSMES program density with DSMES participation at the patient-level by leveraging claims data from the Arkansas All-Payer Claims Database for Medicare, Medicare Advantage and privately insured patients; (2) constructing patient-sharing networks of providers who care for patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and applying social network analysis to determine whether patient-sharing relationships among providers is associated with DSMES participation; and (3) identifying the potential agents of change (i.e., opinion leaders) through self-designating surveys of providers. Delineating the social network of T2D providers yields the preliminary data needed to design effective interventions that can expand DSMES referral networks and enhance patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  The project by Dr. Mertens and colleagues aims at deciphering the interface of age-related pathways and genetic risk for mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) using patient-specific induced neurons (iNs). The team will study the underlying molecular structures of MCI using unbiased multi-omic approaches in MCI and AD patient-derived iNs, and compare them to healthily aging control iNs. They will further employ targeted experiments to study the role of neuronal functionality as a convergence platform for aging and disease, and they will leverage insights from their multi-layered characterizations to explore novel approaches to treat MCI and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Small brain bleed and swelling termed amyloid-related imaging abnormalities (ARIA’s) are adverse effects of recent FDA approved aducanumab antibody used for AD, and this occurs more frequently in patients carrying the APOE4 gene. In this study we will use a previously described mouse AD model expressing human APOE isoforms to interrogate the contribution of activated microglia to APOE4 mediated ARIA following aducanumab treatment. We will generate a detailed time-course of functional, pathological and gene level changes to the cerebrovasculature, and reveal novel targets that can reduce the risk of ARIA in APOE4 carriers receiving anti-A? ?  antibody therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Natural Killer (NK) cells are crucial for antiviral defense and require stimulation via cytokines through STAT transcription factors to exert their function. Multiple cytokines activate STAT3 in NK cells which is involved in immune disorders and is regularly mutated in malignancies including NK cell derived lymphoma. The goal of this study is to dissect how STAT3 influences NK cell function in a new model of viral infection that shows a context-dependent role of STAT3 in NK cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Fungal diseases are on the rise, and one of them, cryptococcosis, causes devastating meningoencephalitis in immunosuppressed individuals, including organ transplant recipients. There are no biomarkers to detect risk or early stages of disease in individuals on immunosuppressive drugs. This project is designed to discover antibody biomarkers to identify those at risk for disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapy using patient’s own engineered immune cells has shown dramatic cures in some leukemias and lymphomas. But every patient, like their cancer, is unique, and immunotherapies built using an individual patient’s cells are highly variable from one patient to another. The proposed research will focus on identifying the degree of functional variability across patients in engineered cellular immune therapies, and if successful will ultimately enable predictive diagnostic testing to personalize cell therapies to individual patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: This proposal will examine the impact of obesity on the human endometrium from a well-phenotyped cohort of reproductive-aged women. We will utilize single nuclear RNA sequencing, high-resolution mass-spectrometry, functional assays of endometrial decidualization, and multiple measures of adiposity to better understand how obesity alters the endometrium. Results from this study may aid in identification of novel biomarkers and will help stimulate additional studies to inform clinical practice and counseling for women with obesity and infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance: The brain shows marked plasticity across a variety of learning and memory tasks as well as during recovery after injury. This proposal aims to investigate targeted stimulation of cortex to drive cortical plasticity and induce functional recovery via state-of-the-art electrophysiology and optogenetics to simultaneously record and manipulate activity of sensorimotor neurons in awake behaving macaques. Understanding the role of these basic physiological phenomena will shed light on underlying mechanisms of brain plasticity that leads to functional reorganization in the brain and can provide us with vital insight to develop stimulation-based therapies for a broad range of neurological disorders such as stroke.

PROJECT_TITLE: Engineering neuroplasticity using volitional control of activity-dependent optogenetic stimulation in macaque sensorimotor cortex

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research will utilize mitochondrial transfer to rescue motor neuron-related mitochondrial dysfunction in spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA), an X-linked neuromuscular disorder. The goals of the proposed research are to identify new biomarkers for SBMA and to establish the rationale and validate the feasibility to harness neural stem cells as an efficient mitochondrial supplier to treat disease motor neurons. This work will help establish a clinically translatable platform for human induced pluripotent stem cell-based therapeutic intervention for SBMA and other related neurodegenerative and neurologic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The prefrontal cortex is the part of the brain that hold our cognitive abilities, and it is thought to communicate with our visual system to produce attention towards visual information important for our current needs. In this proposal, we will study the nature of this communication to understand how we choose to attend to discrete aspects of our surroundings. With a thorough understanding of the underlying neuronal mechanisms, we can begin to understand how this communication malfunctions, and attention falls short, in disorders like attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and Schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Existing methods of predicting response to surgical treatment based on patient's clinical and imaging characteristics are inadequate for guiding personalized treatment of pharmacoresistant epilepsy and ameliorating its high burden in adults and children. This proposal uses advanced analytic methods with a novel network-based approach to derive predictors of outcomes from non-invasive and accessible functional brain images. The results of this proposal will guide future studies and advance the field toward developing biomarkers, predicting response to treatment, and understanding the disease mechanisms in epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-operative atrial fibrillation (poAF) is the most common complication following cardiac surgery (~30%), and patients who experience poAF are more likely to suffer a number of adverse outcomes, including longer stays in the ICU and increased mortality. To improve patient outcomes, we propose to collect left atrial tissue from patients who are in normal sinus rhythm as they undergo cardiac surgery, and then identify gene-expression and epigenomic differences in this tissue between patients that subsequently do and do not develop poAF. We will then perform a functional validation of variants causing these changes in cardiac muscle stem cells. Successful completion of this study will identify new pharmacological targets for preventing and treating poAF, potentially improving the lives of millions of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The perspectives of sexual minority youth are vastly underrepresented in extant theories, research, treatment development for suicide prevention, particularly considering the substantially elevated rate of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in sexual minority populations. Failure to incorporate the voices and lived experiences of sexual minority youth perpetuates health disparities, underutilization of treatment, and treatment dropout among sexual minority youth. Using a rigorous, ethnographic approach called Cultural Consensus Modeling, this project will provide an empirically-based multi-method model of the shared cultural determinants of suicidal thoughts and behaviors among sexual minority youth, as perceived by sexual minority youth themselves, to inform culturally relevant treatment targets and provide clear recommendations for adapting theoretical models of suicide to address the needs of sexual minority youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder with both motor and non-motor features whose pathologic hallmark is misfolded α-synuclein. This proposal’s goals are to identify the tissue source of pathologic α-synuclein strains found in human plasma in an unbiased manner and determine the biochemical and functional properties of these strains by introducing them into cellular models. Understanding the origin and properties of circulating forms of α-synuclein could lead to therapies that target early disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: At present, no disease-modifying therapies exist for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension. While it is known that increased pulmonary blood flow can lead to structural changes in the distal arterioles, the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. My study will provide novel insights into the contribution and involvement of smooth muscle cells to flow-induced vascular remodeling. Additionally, my work will establish new murine models that will provide a valuable resource for future researchers investigating pulmonary hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Gastrointestinal (GI) dysfunction may be an early manifestation of Parkinson's disease (PD), the second most common neurodegenerative disorder. The Gut Brain Parkinson's Disease Consortium (GBPDC) will support the establishment of the GBPDC biorepository and accelerate the development of innovative early-phase GI-based research tools and biomarkers for PD. Our proposed Clinical Data Management Center will establish the required infrastructure, data management, analytics, and resource-sharing functions to efficiently support the establishment of the program with a focus on expanded reach, efficiency, and accelerated data analysis and result dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease can affect people younger than age 65, yet it is unclear whether the disease is different in middle aged people compared to older individuals. This research project aims to advance our understanding of the protein changes that occur in Alzheimer’s disease in people younger than age 65. Such knowledge is critical to ensure that diagnostic tests and therapies developed for Alzheimer’s disease are applicable to this younger population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cervical dystonia (CD) is a chronic, disabling neurologic disorder for which available treatments are purely symptomatic and not satisfactory in 20-40% of patients. Lack of known biologic pathways associated with the pathogenesis of CD has limited development of point of care tests that are urgently needed to diagnose and guide the treatment of CD. This research project will utilize immunophenotyping, gene expression profiling, and quantitative neuroanatomical methods to advance our understanding of pathogenic immune mechanisms in CD, and may ultimately direct the development of better diagnostic tools and guide research for the development of disease modifying therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will adapt an evidence-based mobile health (mHealth) intervention to reduce overdose risk behavior among people who use drugs (PWUD). We will pilot the adapted intervention and then conduct a randomized controlled trial to evaluate its efficacy, along with qualitative interviews to understand participants’ experiences of the intervention. We will conduct this research in partnership with the National Harm Reduction Coalition, PWUD, and local harm reduction service providers using a generative co-design process so that the potentially lifesaving OD prevention intervention will be usable and feasible in real-world settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This study seeks to address the challenge of how to deliver targeted interventions that address the individualized cognitive needs of mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) patients. The overall objective of our predicate SBIR Phase I grant that started in July 2023 is to determine the feasibility of a timing intervention (PATH neurotraining) to significantly improve visual working memory, processing speed (primary outcomes) and auditory working memory, selective attention, cognitive flexibility, sustained attention, reading speed, and reading proficiency (secondary outcomes) in mTBI patients more than after either Sham or conventional N-Back Working Memory training (Aim 1). The challenge is to: 1) have PATH neurotraining be distributed by centers aimed at cognitive remediation for mTBI patients, such as neurologists, rehab centers, and learning centers, which can only be done after this clinical trial is completed, and 2) increase awareness of our clinical trials research so that PATH neurotraining will be accepted as a proven method for remediating cognitive skills after a concussion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative T2* mapping and quantitative susceptibility mapping (QSM) are critical MRI techniques for in vivo iron quantification, providing crucial information about brain development and neurodegenerative diseases, including Multiple Sclerosis (MS). However, T2* and QSM have yet to be widely adopted in clinical practices due to long scan time and sensitivity to motion and B0 fluctuations. This work aims to develop and validate a motion- and B0- robust technique for T2* and QSM quantification using the spherical echo planar time-resolved imaging (sEPTI), deep learning-based image reconstruction, prospective motion correction, and retrospective B0 correction, which will significantly improve the image quality and accessibility of T2* and QSM and widen their clinical and scientific applicability in general populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Distinct groups of eukaryotic DNA mismatch repair (MMR) family proteins facilitate crossing over between homologs to ensure proper Meiosis I chromosome segregation, and act to prevent recombination between divergent DNA sequences that can lead to chromosomal rearrangements associated with diseases such as cancer. In humans, failures in meiotic chromosome segregation result in aneuploidy syndromes (at least 10% of human pregnancies), which are thought to occur as the result of Meiosis I and II errors, defective or inappropriate recombination, premature homolog separation, and defects in sister chromatid cohesion. Importantly, mutations in MMR genes have been found in about half of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (2-7% of all colon cancers) patients, and are thought be linked to infertility, underscoring the importance of obtaining new mechanistic understandings and molecular tools to establish allele pathogenicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Gonadal hormones profoundly influence social behavior and many psychiatric disorders associated with social dysfunction, such as depression and anxiety disorders; some social behaviors, such as self-initiated (“proactive”) behaviors can promote resiliency to these disorders. Despite this, we lack a clear understanding of how gonadal hormones shape network scale neural coding of the social environment and proactive behavior at a moment-to- moment level. Here, I develop new technology to probe the effect of hormonal change on “proactive” social behavior and its encoding by a multi-brain region network of neural circuits, building an experimental framework for future studies on the relationship between hormones, self-initiated behavior, and resilience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Between 2016-2020, over 12,000 hematopoietic cell transplants (HCT) were performed in children in the United States as treatment for cancers, immunodeficiencies, blood disorders, and other life-threatening diseases. After HCT, injury to the lung due to infections, chemotherapy, or inflammation can lead to a type of scarring called pulmonary fibrosis that affects quality of life and leads to premature death. As pulmonary fibrosis is challenging to diagnose but potentially treatable, this proposal aims to develop respiratory and blood-based screening tools that can identify patients with or at-risk for pulmonary fibrosis who may benefit from novel treatment strategies.

PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in chromatin regulators are a major cause of neurodevelopmental disorders. While these chromatin-linked neurodevelopmental disorders display misexpression of sperm and ovary genes in the brain, the mechanisms and impact of such gene misregulation remain unknown. The proposed research aims to determine whether such germline gene expression in the brain impacts brain development and behavior, thereby identifiying therapeutic targets of neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the mechanisms behind vascular stabilization during embryogenesis is vital to preventing vascular birth defects, which are too often fatal. The goal of this research is to investigate the role of endothelial primary cilia as mechanosensitive signaling structures in vascular development and stabilization, which will have an impact on how new approaches are developed to manage and prevent vascular birth defects such as arteriovenous malformations, aneurysms, and congenital defects of the heart and great vessels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative We have identified a relatively unexplored aspect of neuroinflammation with aging and Alzheimer’s disease characterized by microglial upregulation of the Major Histocompatibility Complex I (MHC-I) and paired immunoglobulin receptor families (Lilrs and Pilrs). This pathway could cell-autonomously regulate microglial phenotype with aging and Alzheimer’s disease in addition to canonical interactions with T cells. MHC-I will be suppressed specifically in microglia to assess the effects on microglial phenotype/function and T cell recruitment and phenotype with aging and Alzheimer’s.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Consolidated sleep is crucial for older individuals' cognition, health, and well-being, but the fragmentation of sleep and wake increases with age. This study will investigate underlying mechanisms contributing to sleep- wake fragmentation and explore the utility of a novel intervention, afternoon phototherapy, to reduce the consequences of sleep-wake fragmentation, including ameliorated cognition. Results from this project may lead to an inexpensive or free scalable intervention with the potential to ameliorate cognitive decline and other concomitants of fragmented sleep, delay institutionalization, and improve the quality of life in older individuals.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE United States value-based reforms targeting surgical conditions have had a modest effect on perioperative costs and outcomes, which may be related to misguided policies that reward strategies seeking to minimize post-operative care variation rather than streamlining the sequence of episode-specific events preceding surgery. Reframing current value-based surgical reforms to capture both patient/provider perspectives and a broader set of episode-specific clinical and non-clinical events will have the dual effect of improving surgical value and better aligning policies with patient/provider needs. By employing a mixed methods approach to surgical episode modeling and evaluation, this proposal will lay the foundation for a future clinical decision aid that targets at-risk populations with structural interventions to improve surgical value by reducing variation in perioperative care intensity and duration.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Using mixed methods to reduce disparities in renal colic care: a model for surgical value transformation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study investigates how a fundamental cellular process called autophagy, which degrades damaged proteins, functions to maintain the health of human brain cells and how defects in this process place individuals at great risk for developing dementia and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. The proposed research supports the identification of new therapeutic strategies for age-related neurodegenerative diseases that are steadily increasing in prevalence in our population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative This diversity supplement to R21AG083393 will provide funding for Mr. Michael Segovia, a rising scholar from an underrepresented group, to (1) conduct research related to the Parent Grant focusing on the interaction between rural/urban residential context and state-level policies for mid-age adults in line with NIA’s Strategic Goals B and F, (2) be exposed to theoretical frameworks that guide aging research, and (3) develop research skills. The candidate will also benefit from opportunities available through the numerous research centers and research activities occurring at the Pennsylvania State University. Mr. Segovia will be integrated into the Research Team and Penn State as a Postbaccalaureate Researcher.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The prevalence of inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), continues to rise worldwide, debilitating the quality of life of millions of people. Given the linked association between extraintestinal inflammation, such as inflammatory skin diseases, and susceptibility to IBD, improving our understanding of modulatory factors in such inter-organ inflammatory circuits may allow for rational therapeutic strategies and preventative medicines for IBD and other inflammatory diseases. Based on my recent findings that neuromedin U (NMU)-producing cholinergic neurons and group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) cooperatively orchestrate the tissue-protective pathway in IBD pathogenesis, the focus of this proposal is to dissect the potential role of this neuro-ILC2 axis in the regulation of the inter-organ skin-gut inflammatory circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Occlusive vascular diseases are the leading cause of death in the United States and worldwide. The proposed study focuses on investigating the function and the underlying mechanisms of the uncharacterized nuclear protein HMGXB4 in vascular smooth muscle cells related to occlusive vascular diseases. Completion of the proposed studies will provide novel insights into the mechanisms regulating smooth muscle inflammation and phenotypic switching, and will determine if inhibiting HMGXB4 is an attractive novel therapeutic strategy for ameliorating occlusive vascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The computational methodologies we develop will be applicable to a broad range of conformational changes of RNA polymerases with biomedical relevance. In particular, oxidative DNA lesions cause transcriptional mutagenesis of RNA Polymerase II that contributes to tumor growth in skin cancer, and mechanistic insights from this work will help uncover a route to address the adverse effects of these DNA lesions. In addition, antibiotics against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) often target the dynamic motion of its RNA polymerase, and this work will provide mechanistic insights to facilitate the rational design of new antibiotics fighting drug resistance of Mtb.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inequities in substance use disorder pose significant risk to Indigenous communities in the United States (here, American Indians, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians). Many Tribes and organizations serving Indigenous populations have been deeply committed to addressing substance use disorder, but since the preponderance of research has been designed and led from outside these communities, progress has been limited. Indigenous scientists have the potential to apply critical expertise from both scientific and community/cultural perspectives, but they remain significantly underrepresented among Principal Investigators funded by NIH. The NCRE Scholars Program invests in the career development of early stage Indigenous investigators to help prepare them to lead this research and close the equity gap.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone quality deteriorates with obesity, diabetes, and aging and increases bone fragility and fractures. There is a need to identify new therapeutic targets for improving skeletal health, especially during the perimenopause transition and in later life stages when many more women suffer from age-related diseases, obesity, and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D). The studies outlined in this proposal aim to determine the role of brain-derived cellular communication network factor 3 (CCN3), a new therapeutic target, in bone and marrow fat metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mounting evidence support the idea that aging is rooted in metabolic dysfunction, which occurs when chemical reactions become dysregulated during aging and negatively alters the body's processing and distribution of nutrients, inducing the aberrant accumulation of certain metabolites. Identifying metabolic pathways and metabolites that drive cell senescence and metabolic dysfunction is critical to understanding and treating age- related diseases. This project aims to unravel the association between propionate metabolism and aging, providing insights into potential diagnostic biomarkers and therapeutic targets for mitigating aging and age- related diseases.
