IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite ample evidence of the benefits of cardiac rehabilitation, only a small fraction of transcatheter aortic valve replacement patients participate. This proposed research tests the use of clinically controlled, commercially available fitness programming (Rehabbing with Peloton) that targets physical activity and cardiovascular health outcomes. Commercially available mobile health provides an opportunity to deliver cardiac rehabilitation content to a vulnerable population who are disproportionately excluded from CR services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acinar-to-ductal metaplasia and pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia are precancerous lesions and risk factors for the development of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. This proposal addresses: 1. how metabolic changes in cellular redox pathways drive precancer and 2. how the metabolic microenvironment regulates aspects of cell competition during metaplastic transformation. Insights from the proposed experiments will connect major metabolic pathways with precancerous states and inform new insights into pancreatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The carbon stable isotope ratio (CIR), which can be sampled from breath, blood, and hair, is an objective, low- burden, and valid method for capturing added sugar (AS) intake but remains understudied in real-world behavioral interventions with youth. This study will examine CIR from breath as a novel measure of intervention adherence (i.e., short-term AS intake) and intervention effectives (i.e., change in AS intake) among adolescents (n=70) 12-16 years participating in a 12-week behavioral randomized controlled trial to reduce AS intake. Findings will provide evidence on the comparative feasibility, acceptability, and sensitivity to change of different CIR sample types (e.g., breath, blood, hair) to inform a fully powered R01 trial and yield important insights to address limitations associated with adherence and self-report in dietary intervention trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The formation of long term memories requires correct functioning of the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus. In Alzheimers disease, function of the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus are affected by pathological forms of the protein tau, which is thought to contribute to cognitive and memory impairments associated with the disease. This proposal will investigate how pathological tau potentially impairs the function of select vulnerable neurons in the hippocampus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This study will develop and test a novel culturally tailored family-based videogame, FamilyBond, to prevent worsening substance misuse among urban Black adolescents in community-based primary care settings by addressing both universal and unique risk and protective factors for this population. Findings from the study will provide the first effective family-based digital intervention to lower intentions to misuse substances among urban Black adolescents. The intervention will reduce barriers to accessing care among Black adolescents and their parents by delivering a mobile videogame intervention in primary care settings.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall prevalence of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) is increasing worldwide. Our proposed project aims to examine the impact that early diagnosis of MCI and ADRD has on employment, care trajectories, and quality of life. This research will identify health policies that can best protect the most vulnerable from the negative consequences of ill-health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compulsively persisting with fixed ways of behaving even when negative consequences mount is a central component of many psychiatric disorders. For the first time in psychiatry, is it now possible to longitudinally record from neural circuits during a patient’s treatment course, and to do so while administering sophisticated tests of cognition. Directly studying the neural circuits of individuals undergoing treatment for compulsivity may reveal the biological basis for the kind of rigid thinking and behavior present in a wide range of devastating mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative α-Synucleinopathies, which exhibit strong associations with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementia (ADRD), have raised the possibility of T-cell immunity involvement in α-synuclein propagation. An interdisciplinary research team will systematically investigate T-cell responses to pathogenic α- synuclein, their influence on α-synuclein propagation, and the potential therapeutic applications of immunotherapy. These investigations aim to elucidate the intricate disease mechanisms, identify T-cell related molecular determinants in α-synucleinopathy-related ADRD, and provide novel insights into therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The proposed research will develop and test an online Emergency Preparedness Toolkit to help caregivers prepare for their own unexpected health events. Caregivers of persons with dementia often ignore their own health needs as their primary focus is the care of the person with dementia. This can lead to a caregiver delaying their own care and subsequently emergent health events. The Emergency Preparedness Toolkit provides guidance to the caregiver as to how to identify and transfer care to a standby caregiver. The goal is to provide a caregiver with the security and comfort that the person with dementia will be well cared for while they care for their own health needs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults with differences of sex development make critical and potentially irreversible, life-altering surgical decisions about their bodies without standardized resources to support their engagement in shared decision making. To fill this gap, the proposed research will examine the decisional needs of adolescents and young adults with differences of sex development, as well as develop and pilot a set of surgical decision aids addressing identified needs. Standardized decision aid use will promote adolescent and young adult engagement in shared decision making, leading to improved care, patient health, and psychosocial outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Seasonal influenza causes 290,000-645,000 deaths annually and many of these deaths are in low-middle income countries especially in particularly vulnerable groups such as infants, pregnant women, and the elderly. However, how influenza transmits between members of a household is not well understood in low-middle income countries. This project hopes to fill the gap in knowledge of how influenza spreads within-households in low-middle income countries and has the potential to influence vaccination and mitigation measures recommended in these countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of muscle strength occurs with age and in females estradiol deficiency contributes to strength loss. Through the uses of genetic, surgical, and pharmacological interventions to alter both estradiol levels and estrogen receptors, our project aims to not only expand our understanding of estrogenic mechanisms affecting skeletal muscle function in females but also determine if there is a role in preservation of muscle strength in males. Such understanding paves the way for estrogenic treatments that will impact the field of aging in both women’s and men’s health from multiple perspectives, beyond reproductive considerations

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Auto-brewery syndrome is a rare, but likely underdiagnosed condition in which intestinal microbes produce alcohol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream and results in intoxication. There is no accepted therapy for patients with auto-brewery syndrome. The primary goal of this clinical trial is to test safety and tolerability in eight patients with auto-brewery syndrome using fecal microbiota transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will test the preliminary efficacy of a newly developed dyadic sleep intervention, My Sleep Our Sleep (MSOS), in a 2-arm randomized controlled, noninferiority trial design (MSOS vs Brief Behavioral Treatment for Insomnia, BBTI) on reducing sleep disturbance and improving health-related quality of life in both adult patients with cancer and their sleep-partner caregivers, and explore the roles of close relationship characteristics in the dyadic intervention. New knowledge from this project will guide comprehensive investigations on the psychosocial and biobehavioral factors of the dyadic sleep intervention for adult patients/survivors with cancer and their sleep-partner family caregivers. The knowledge from this project may also have substantial implications for traditional sleep research and telehealth practice with medical populations, shifting the emphasis from individual- to dyad/family-based approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The digitization of health records and widespread availability of tumor DNA sequencing results offer a chance to better risk-stratify patients with implications for therapy selection, monitoring, and side effect mitigation. Here, we will test whether multimodal, artificial intelligence pipelines improve outcome modeling over standard predictors for patients with non-small cell lung cancer at three points: 1) Patients with localized disease at risk for relapse following definitive therapy, 2) Patients with oligometastatic disease considering consolidative radiotherapy, 3) Patients at risk for central nervous system disease who may benefit from MRI surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alteration of the gut microbiome associated with chronic diseases, known as dysbiosis, has been described in patients with cirrhosis. While many infectious complications of cirrhosis are thought to originate from the gut microbiota, the effects of dysbiosis on disseminated infections remain poorly understood. In this application, the candidate outlines a systematic approach to study the effect of lactulose, a common prescription for patients with cirrhosis, on bacterial growth in the microbiota and disseminated infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Traumatic injury is the leading cause of death from ages 1-44 in the United States, claiming more than 200,000 lives per year and is responsible for millions of hospital encounters at an annual cost of over $4 trillion USD. While approximately half of trauma patient deaths occur early after injury from bleeding or brain injury, the other half occur in a delayed fashion and frequently are related to organ failure (lungs, kidneys) that is driven, in part, by inflammatory responses. We are performing research focused on understanding how a key inflammatory system called complement gets activated and contributes to the organ failure and delayed deaths observed after traumatic injury, which may eventually lead to novel therapeutic interventions to prevent death in these predominantly young, healthy patients who would otherwise have a long life ahead of them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Methadone, the most dispensed Medications for Opioid Use Disorder (MOUD) in poor and minority neighborhoods, which maintains the most stringent federal regulations, must be obtained at an Opioid Treatment Program (OTP), for one, two, or three years of daily supervised use before a person receives up to 6, 14, and 30 days of unsupervised take-home doses, respectively. Future health innovations must deliver low-cost liquid methadone dispensing and telehealth solutions through a single device to overcome current digital barriers (e.g., required use of a mobile phone/smartphone) and traditional SUD barriers (e.g., taking time off work, long travel times, transportation costs, pharmacy preparation costs). SANO’s MOUD-Environmental Interactive Device (EID) provides such a single device solution, with capabilities of obtaining Food and Drug administration Breakthrough Medical Device Designation, as it is comprised of (a) an inner-container, which uses electromechanical valves to precisely dispense up to 30-days liquid methadone through a low-cost volumetric-control system; (b) a reusable external Smart- container with audio, video, and a low-cost gravimetric-control system (supplemental adherence/device efficacy assessment); (c) Wi-Fi and Bluetooth® capability for remote supervised use (Video Observed Therapy) and telehealth/behavioral health access, without use of a smartphone; and (d) a unique device identification system with biometric security (Phase 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This assesses whether integrated Dually Eligible Special Needs Plans (D-SNPs) in Medicare offer adults living with Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s related dementias (AD/ADRD) improved long-term care coordination and better outcomes compared with non-integrated D-SNPs. The results of this project will be used to inform state Medicaid policy decisions regarding D-SNP implementation in their states and also will help individuals with AD/ADRD and their families select a Medicare Advantage health plan that best meets their individualized needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder of the optic nerve and retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) which affects a substantial percentage of the adult and elderly population of the United States. Clinical studies and our preliminary experimental data in mice suggest that there is an understudied relationship among serotonin, an important neurotransmitter, RGC function, and glaucoma. In this proposal, we will study the roles that serotonin level and a key serotonin receptor play in RGC biology in both normal mice and mice with experimental glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Wolbachia bacteria of arthropods are key to several global initiatives such as the World Mosquito Program in controlling pests and the transmission of arboviruses such as dengue. Based on new data demonstrating Wolbachia’s ability to inhibit fungal pathogenesis as well, this proposal will combine a variety of approaches to determine the breadth, mechanistic basis, and translational potential of this phenotype. Doing so will have many important implications for human health, including the potential for novel antifungal therapies, bolstering the accuracy of population modeling for vector control initiatives, and increasing our basic understanding of interkingdom microbial interactions within hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child obesity and metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) are driven by the early onset and progression of insulin resistance, fueled by diets high in sugars. Over 7 million children in the United States are estimated to be affected by MASLD and the accompanying features of the cardiometabolic syndrome including abdominal obesity, insulin resistance, and dyslipidemia. The aims of this K24 will expand the mentorship of new patient-oriented researchers and increase patient-oriented research in the area of prevention of childhood cardiometabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is important to public health because it focuses on α-synuclein (αS), a central protein implicated in Parkinson’s disease (PD), PD with dementia (PDD), dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), and certain forms of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The applicants have developed a unique set of experimental ap- proaches to distinguish normal and abnormal Serine129 phosphorylation in αS since this post-translational mod- ification is not only a principal component of “Lewy bodies”, pathological αS deposits in diseased brains, but also has a physiological role in healthy neurons. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to NIA’s “AD/ADRD” mission of seeking fundamental knowledge to reduce the burden of PD, PDD, DLB, and AD in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Gut integrity is markedly worsened following sepsis, the leading cause of death among critically ill patients. Cancer is the most common comorbidity in sepsis, and the presence of malignancy results in significant alterations in both immunity and gut integrity. This program seeks to understand mechanisms through which sepsis alters gut integrity and through which cancer worsens outcomes in order to uncover new potential therapeutic targets to improve outcomes in a disease that is very common and highly lethal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergency hematopoiesis induces the rapid expansion of inflammatory neutrophils during infection, a process which must remain tightly regulated as the overproduction of hyperactivated granulocytes underlies the disease progression of systemic inflammation into septic shock. Therefore, myeloid progenitor fate during emergency granulopoiesis must be carefully controlled at a molecular, cellular, and systemic level. This proposal aims to examine the machinery that regulates the dramatic shift in myelopoiesis towards emergency neutropoiesis, with the goal of targeting this pathway to reduce the adverse effects of an over-activated immune system during septic shock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Blood-based biomarkers have the potential to transform diagnosis and clinical management of Alzheimer’s disease in the community, but it is unclear how these biomarkers perform in diverse populations. We plan to investigate the effects of various sociodemographic and medical factors on the performance of plasma p- tau217, a promising new blood-based biomarker for Alzheimer’s disease. Results from this study will ultimately contribute to improved early identification and screening for Alzheimer’s disease in communities that are disproportionately affected by the disease.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal for mentored career development is designed to train the principal investigator in order to confer the skills necessary to be a successful independent investigator. The first focus is on commitment to ensuring that the principal investigator receives the mentorship and training to address any gaps in technical knowledge and ensure attainment of skills required of an independent biomedical investigator. The second focus is on understanding unexplored mechanisms by which a new combination immunotherapy (OX40 activation+PD-1 inhibition) reshapes the cardiac immune landscape and promotes myocardial vulnerability.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of appropriate dosing information in pregnant individuals with uncontrolled asthma is an unmet public health need that can result in therapeutic failure and death. This proposal will build a framework for the use of physiologically based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) modeling for pregnant individuals with asthma. These developed PBPK models can be broadly applied to inform dosing of other drugs, improve outcomes in pregnant individuals, and further the NIH’s mission to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Lack of contraceptive autonomy is associated with health inequities and adverse health outcomes ranging from STIs to depression to low birth weight. However, without the tools to measure contraceptive autonomy, researchers and policymakers are left without a clear idea of where and how contraceptive autonomy is lacking, and which sociodemographic groups are most affected. The study proposed here will develop and validate a standardized metric of contraceptive autonomy, documenting reproductive inequities and situating the multidimensional construct of autonomy within cultural context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The communities of microbes that inhabit our bodies modulate our immune systems with remarkable precision leading to the generation of antigen-specific responses in the absence of inflammation or barrier breach. This proposal seeks to uncover the function and molecular mechanisms elicited by the skin microbiota on the immune system and leverages this knowledge to develop non-invasive approaches to induce targeted immune responses. Overall, this work lays the foundation for a novel vaccination modality against viral and bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will use a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods to develop and validate a measure of structural gendered racism (cross cutting racism and sexism) and determine the impact of early life exposure on Black women’s cognitive aging and risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD). This proposal will also leverage data collected from the Health and Retirement Study to identify categorically distinct subgroups of older Black women whose exposure patterns to gendered racism in early life differ, and examine associations with cognitive baseline, cognitive decline, and incident ADRD. Results of the study will include the development of a novel index that can be used longitudinally to track changes in Black women’s exposure to structural gendered racism over the lifecourse and illumination of modifiable structural mechanisms that, with intervention and public policy, may reduce the disproportionate burden of ADRD in a historically marginalized subgroup.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-acquired pneumonia is one of the most common infections among children in the United States. However, accurately diagnosing community-acquired pneumonia can be challenging due to its similarity with other common respiratory infections, resulting in misuse of diagnostic tests and overuse of antibiotics. The proposed research will develop a prediction model for community-acquired pneumonia using data from the electronic health record and design a clinical decision support system that will improve use of radiographs and antibiotics, thus improving health outcomes of children with this infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal infection during pregnancy increases the risk of neuropsychiatric disease/disorders in offspring; however, maternal immune activation does not induce neurodevelopmental disorder vulnerability in the majority of offspring. Here, we test whether maternal immune activation acts as a ‘priming event’, increasing susceptibility to subsequent risk factors such as early-life stress, exposure to which has been shown to increase susceptibility to neuropsychiatric disorders. In this R21 proposal, we will test the hypothesis that a two-hit model of maternal immune activation using toll-like receptor 7 activation during pregnancy in combination with early-life postnatal resource deprivation stress results in sex-specific neurodevelopmental vulnerabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The contribution of lifecourse income to late life risk for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) is not known. The parent grant will tackle this research gap by creating a pooled, synthetic cohort with data that spans the full lifecourse. This diversity supplement research project will validate the parent study’s pooling method using valid and accurate income data from the social security administration (SSA) data linked to the Health and Retirement Study (HRS). Furthermore, this project will evaluate the association of lifecourse income data from the SSA and, separately, the pooled, synthetic cohort with cognition, ADRD risk, and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Poor sleep during cocaine abstinence is one of the strongest predictors of return to use (relapse). The current project will use cutting edge approaches to characterize how cocaine alters the function of a brain neuropeptide system critical for arousal. These studies will contribute to the development of novel medications to treat cocaine use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lipoic acid, an over-the-counter dietary supplement, is associated with NELL1 membranous nephropathy, an autoimmune kidney disease characterized by urine protein loss (proteinuria), and at late stages, kidney failure. In this proposal we will determine the relationship among NELL1 antibodies, proinflammatory T cells, and proteinuria in people who use lipoic acid. This research has the potential to identify early-stage disease in lipoic acid users and unmask important treatment targets to prevent kidney failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Patients with ALK+ lung cancer experience variable levels of tumor control when treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI), and our data suggest neutrophils within the tumor microenvironment can reduce patient response to TKI. Using immunocompetent mouse models and patient specimens, this proposal will determine how neutrophils dampen TKI response. These insights will support future clinical trial approaches with novel immunotherapies not yet considered in patients with ALK+ NSCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Environmental exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation mediates systemic inflammatory responses in susceptible individuals with photosensitive autoimmune disease, yet mechanisms of signal transduction are poorly understood. We present evidence that exposure to UVB results in release of photoproduct-containing DNA in extracellular vesicles, and photoproducts can be detected in the lymphatic systems of mice and in urine of human subjects. The proposed research seeks to understand the mode of circulation and impact of extracellular damaged DNA in the context of photosensitive autoimmune disease and contribute to better diagnostics and treatments for sensitizing exposures to environmental genotoxins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD) are predicted to increase substantially, yet how early life risks work together with midlife and late-life modifiable factors to alter AD/ADRD risk is unclear. The proposed project will leverage twin and sibling data, with genomic data, to evaluate life course risk and protective factors for AD/ADRD, testing causal hypotheses and gene-environment interplay. Converging evidence from our approaches will inform clinical and policy recommendations regarding life course risk and protective factors that create differential vulnerabilities for AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Sleep disruption commonly occurs during opiate withdrawal and elevates the probability of relapse. This application will elucidate the circuit mechanism underlying opioid withdrawal-induced sleep disturbances. We will determine whether and how locus coeruleus-centering arousal circuits become dysfunctional during opioid withdrawal and expected results will reveal novel circuit-based strategies for treating sleep disruption in Opioid Use Disorder (OUD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria regulate metabolism, the process that changes food to energy and if people have abnormal or missing copies of the genes required for mitochondrial function they will develop primary mitochondrial disease for which there are neither cures nor treatments. Many patients with mitochondrial disease have neurologic symptoms, so to understand how mitochondrial dysfunction causes neurologic problems, this proposal studies mitochondrial metabolism in neurons. Successful completion of the proposed studies would result in advancing both the understanding and methods for studying mitochondrial metabolism in the brain, with the goal of translating these findings into treatments for patients with mitochondrial diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and it disproportionately affects African Americans and Hispanics. Emerging data suggest that the “causal” pathological markers of AD, as defined by the AT(N) framework (Amyloid, Tau, Neurodegeneration) vary by race/ethnicity. The current grant will examine the role of the exposome, and its link to the ATN framework, in the risk of developing AD among the three ethnic groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Fecal microbiota transplant (FMT) is a promising therapeutic for alcohol misuse. FMT in patients suffering from alcohol use disorder (AUD) reduced craving for alcohol, improved transplant-free survival, reduced rates of infections, and this drinking reduction could be transmitted to mice where drinking was also reduced as compared to untreated donors. This proposal will use behavioral and genomic approaches in a murine model to test the composition of individual human donor samples which will reduce drinking in mice; dietary fiber will also be used to test for relative enhancement of engraftment and further reductions in drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative 20 million patients have surgery in the United States every year, with approximately 1 million of those patients requiring life-saving blood transfusion. Presurgical preparation for transfusion is important to allow for safe and timely transfusion during surgery; however, excessive preparation is unfortunately common, costly, and contributes to blood waste. This study aims to develop an intelligent clinical decision support system to help clinicians prepare blood for patients who are likely to need it, while avoiding excessive preparation for patients who don’t, thus improving patient safety while reducing blood waste and healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have little knowledge of factors that promote optimal neurodevelopmental outcomes in opioid-exposed infants. In this K23, we propose incorporating lived experience through an active partnership with a local community advisory board with an innovative focus on positive experiences in an established, large prospective longitudinal birth cohort of children with neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. Our investigation of children who exhibit positive adaptation in the face of biological and social adversity will identify specific protective or promotive factors for optimal neurodevelopment in this high-risk population which could serve as future intervention targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardio and cerebrovascular risk factors (CVRFs) such as hypertension, diabetes, heart disease, obesity, and stroke increase the risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD). This project uses cutting-edge multi-omics data in humans with advanced statistical methods to identify novel genes that interact with CVRFs in AD using GWAS and to identify epigenomic and transcriptomic profiles, and integrative pathways in AD that interacts with vascular pathologies. My findings may elucidate how genes and CVRFs interplay to influence AD risk, provide insights into the racial/ethnic disparities in AD, suggest personalized strategies for preventing AD in elderly individuals with CVRFs, and reveal novel molecular targets for potential AD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Dr. Abbott’s K08 research project addresses critical gaps and known disparities in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) clinical outcomes and survival through the development and testing of enhanced predictive models that include pre-hospital, patient-level, hospital-level and individual-level health-related social needs (HRSN) data. Using natural language processing (NLP) and large language models (LLMs), mediation analysis, and machine learning algorithms, his study will advance current predictive models improving clinical care and survival for OHCA patients. His research will result not only in important knowledge and techniques regarding the inclusion of HRSN for OHCA care, but also set the stage for his subsequent R01-supported study to externally validate in other health systems the HRSN-inclusive models from this K08 research project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it identifies the needs of family caregivers of persons living with dementia (PWLD) who suffer from urinary incontinence, the interpersonal dynamics of these care dyads (caregiver-PLWD), and potential targets for future interventions to support them. The ultimate goal of this research is to improve in-home continence care support for all parties and to keep PWLD living in their homes for as long as possible. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIA’s mission to improve our knowledge and to develop more effective ways to care for older adults, in particular, those living with Alzheimer’s Dementia and their family caregivers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early identification of children at high risk of deterioration is a challenge, but a data-driven approach that incorporates high-frequency physiological data from bedside monitors will improve our ability to identify this at- risk population. The proposed work will derive, validate, and design for the implementation of a machine learning-based prediction model that identifies mechanically ventilated children at risk of new or worsening cardiorespiratory dysfunction. This is a critical step towards implementing acceptable and effective real-time, longitudinal prediction models at the bedside of the critically ill child.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Progressive pulmonary fibrosis encompasses a broad range of diseases with a shared progressive phenotype for which there is no cure. This application seeks to address a fundamental gap in knowledge about how fibroblasts gain BCL-2 mediated resistance to apoptosis through persistent IL-6 signaling. The results of our studies will provide insight into targeting IL-6 signaling in fibroblasts to therapeutically restore fibroblast sensitivity to apoptosis as a treatment for progressive pulmonary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a powerful technique for assessing the human brain in vivo, but head motion continues to be a substantial problem for neuroimaging, especially in patients who are agitated or confused, and in children and infants. The proposed project will develop an MRI-navigator based motion correction technique to eliminate through-plane slice-alignment errors and in-plane movements in 2- dimensional structural (T2-weighted) MRI, and validate the new technique in healthy cdontrol subjects. Successful completion of the proposed development will improve the robustness of MRI from those with head movements and promises to improve the quality of 2D brain MRI scans both in the clinical and research settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innovative methods to improve timely and accurate detection of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias are urgently needed for optimizing dementia care. We propose to leverage passively collected smartphone data capturing smartphone interactions (via screen use and battery data) and everyday activity (via accelerometer and GPS data), and evaluate their utility to detect neurobehavioral impairment in frontotemporal dementia and Alzheimer's disease. We will further validate their clinical relevance by testing baseline and longitudinal associations with gold-standard in-person cognitive tests and biomarkers of neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemic stroke causes long-term disability, stroke-related co-morbidities, and accelerated cognitive decline which negatively impact quality of life in a sex-specific manner. The proposed studies will investigate the secondary injury mechanisms underlying disease progression during the chronic phase of stroke in older males and females to reveal the chronicity of events leading to a higher risk of vascular dementia. The determination of brain injury-induced cellular senescence as a causal driver of long-term neurological impairment will dramatically improve our understanding of recovery after stroke, provide means for improving diagnostics, and open new and wider windows of delayed treatment for stroke survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mechanisms driving weight loss after bariatric surgery remain unclear, though rapid delivery of nutrients mimics the augmented gut peptide response of bariatric surgery even in non-surgical patients. This career development award combines enteral nutrient infusion and tolerance testing with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to (1) test the hypothesis that rapid nutrient delivery is associated with increased gut peptide and brain fMRI responses, (2) test the hypothesis that Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is associated with faster nutrient absorption compared to sleeve gastrectomy, and (3) identify brain regions rapidly responsive to enterally delivered nutrients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE____________________________________________________________________ Up to 30% of heart transplant recipients develop acute rejection of the new heart within the first post-transplant year. Although they reduce the risk of rejection, contemporary immunosuppressive agents are associated with infection, malignancy, and nephrotoxicity, all of which contribute to post-transplant morbidity and mortality. If heart transplant candidates at low risk for rejection could be identified pre-operatively, a crucial opportunity to personalize immunosuppression without increasing the risk of rejection could be realized. This application proposes to leverage proteomic and transcriptomic profiling to identify circulating pre-transplant biomarkers for post-transplant rejection risk to facilitate a personalized and precision approach to safely minimize immunosuppression and promote post-transplant survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a multi-center trial, within an established research network, to study the use of a medication (inhaled Nitric Oxide) in the management of newborn infants with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). We will use a novel study design approach to learn about the effects this medication has on the level of oxygen in the blood, the need for heart-lung bypass support, and survival, along with the cost-effectiveness of the medication and how well physicians and centers adopt the new approach. Our objective is to advance the adoption of cost- effective, evidence-based strategies in CDH care, leading to cost-effective improvements in CDH and neonatal outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Muscle-generated force is transmitted to tendon across a specialized interface called the myotendinous junction (MTJ). The MTJ is susceptible to injury due to constant exposure of force during physical activity. The objective of this proposal is to identify how the extracellular matrix and mechanical loading establish and maintain the strong linkage between muscle and tendon as this knowledge will be essential for developing therapies to restore functionality to the damaged MTJ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The objective of this research is to culturally tailor a commercially available mindfulness-meditation mobile app for African American (AA) adults and assess its feasibility. A User-Centered Design (UCD) approach will be used to co- develop a culturally tailored app prototype and will be tested in a pilot RCT in AA adults with elevated levels of stress. This proposal will advance our understanding of methods to culturally tailor commercially available mindfulness- meditation apps which may, in the long-term, increase access to mental health care and reduce mental health disparities in AA adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A large number of patients with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) undergo surgery, but the nature of their risk for postoperative complications as well as the decisions that can reduce this risk are unknown. This project will link electronic medical records data with administrative healthcare claims data to characterize the extent to which surgical patients with ADRD are at increased risk for postoperative complications and to identify clinical decisions (such as the use of anesthetic gases and choice of discharge location) that can reduce this risk. The results of this study will improve shared decision making and healthcare outcomes for surgical patient with ADRD by increasing what is known about the increased risks of surgery to these patients as well as the ways to manage these risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because its goal is to enable the diagnosis of two important brain pathologies that account for more than 20% of dementia cases in those who are 85 years and older. This age group is the fastest growing segment of the population and has the highest rates of dementia. Around half of those suffering from dementia by mid-century will belong to this group highlighting the importance of studies dedicated to the causes of dementia in this older age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative RFA-DA-24-018 Field-Deployable, Low-Cost Point-of-Need Approaches and Technologies to Lower the Barriers to Substance Use Disorders (SUD) Diagnosis and Treatment Opioid Use Disorder (OUD), already a life-threatening condition, has additional risk in certain settings such as correctional reentry, Emergency Departments, Tribal Nations, residential substance use disorder treatment, and the perinatal period. We propose just-in-time provision of smartphones with needed connectivity to allow for enrollment in and continuity of telehealth that includes buprenorphine. Our efforts will be co-led and guided by partner researchers with lived experience in a Phase I that informs scaled efforts in Phase II.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This high-risk, high-reward proposal addresses racial health equity and challenges the typical scientific paradigm through innovative approaches in youth substance use prevention for Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander (NHPI) rural populations. Implementation science and participatory methods will shift power, ownership, and responsibility from the project's inception to NHPI communities to actively promote adoption and sustainment of culturally grounded substance use prevention. Community-led innovation tournaments and ecological momentary assessment will produce new generalizable findings for other indigenous and underserved populations, promoting the spread and reach of culturally grounded substance use prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persons with kidney disease are 16 times more likely to need surgery and have a higher risk of complications from surgery compared to patients with normal or near normal kidney function. This proposal will study the link between how we perform hemodialysis before surgery and complications after surgery, including heart attack, stroke, heart failure, irregular heart rhythms, or infections. Completion of this work will provide health care providers with important information about how to prevent complications when persons living with kidney disease need surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By revealing how employment insecurity (EI) relates to substance use and the contexts and populations that buffer or amplify these effects, this study can provide precision targets for policy makers. Additionally, such definitive findings may dispel stigma that substance use is primarily a cause and not a consequence of EI, which can further support broad adoption of employment-enhancement programs and policies as a means of combating the nation’s addiction crisis. The current secondary data analysis study will provide vital evidence that can guide public health efforts in preventing EI from fueling the national drug crisis today and during future turbulent economic times by learning from the most recent societal crisis with economic volatility and addressing decades- long and unresolved issues in the relevant science base.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE [Original Proposal] The proposed study will examine midlife women's relationships and support exchanges with their late adolescent and adult children, as well as with other kin and non-kin, and the implications of these relationships and exchanges for women's psychosocial well-being. The experienced bi-national team will collect and analyze survey and in-depth interview data building upon an existing longitudinal panel of women in rural Mozambique, a setting that in many respects is typical of sub-Saharan Africa. The results of this study will fill important gaps in our understanding of intergenerational and community relationship dynamics and their consequences for women's welfare in rapidly changing resource-limited patriarchal contexts and will inform policies aimed at improving health and well-being of rural women and at optimizing health and social services for that vulnerable population segment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rekovar is developing a low-cost wearable monitoring system that integrates wirelessly with a mobile device to allow real- time monitoring of the baby’s physical and physiological state and its ability to sleep, eat, and be nurtured while undergoing neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS). This device has significant impact in helping reduce both hospital stay and costs as neonates receiving pharmacological treatment are usually in the NICU away from family and non- pharmacological care. Our interest lies with respect to proper neonatal care, where separate procedures occur for essential neonatal needs and needs for neonates undergoing withdrawal, and by using this monitoring device to assess addicted neonates undergoing withdrawal, caregivers are provided the better ability of treating the right neonatal needs with the appropriate procedure in hospitals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is the leading cause of disability in the United States, leaving a substantial number of survivors with permanent weakness. Neuromodulation of sensorimotor areas using physiologically targeted low-frequency stimulation is an innovative new direction to facilitate recovery of motor function. Our proposal seeks to optimize stimulation parameters as well as to develop electrophysiological makers of network function that delineate underlying mechanisms of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  This research seeks to understand how O-GlcNAc (O-linked β-N-acetylglucosamine) glycosylation, an essential, abundant posttranslational modification of proteins, contributes to the onset and progression of Alzheimer’s disease and other related dementias. The insights gained will further our understanding of how specific changes in O-GlcNAc glycosylation regulate cellular functions and drive toxic aggregation of proteins that are hallmarks of these diseases. A major goal is to reveal new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to define the role of the SigmaR1-IRE1a-XBP1 signaling axis in astrocytes during CNS inflammation. To achieve this goal, we propose to apply spatial transcriptomics, scRNA-seq, and genetic and pharmacologic perturbations to the analysis of MS patient samples and murine disease models. In summary, this project investigates a novel molecular pathway in astrocytes using cutting edge techniques to define basic mechanisms that control CNS inflammation and identify novel therapeutic targets.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: This research proposal will inform public health decisions, as our findings will transform how clinicians and scientists think about neurodegeneration in Parkinson's Disease and Parkinsonism's. Understanding factors that render cells vulnerable to degeneration and the common and distinct mechanisms of molecular dysregulation underlying the disease states, particularly among inherited or familial subtypes, will increase the accuracy and precision to predict risk, improve diagnosis and establish a new framework for innovative therapeutic strategies in line with the mission of the NIH to improve the human condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The scale of opioid harms in the US and globally requires urgent action to improve efforts to reduce such harms. The proposed project will leverage the strong data linkages capacity in the US (Rhode Island, Wisconsin, Colorado, and Massachusetts), Australia (New South Wales), and the United Kingdom (Scotland), to transform the evidence base on the prevalence of opioid use disorder and the impact of opioid agonist treatment as a strategy to prevent opioid harm. The study team will project where benefits can be gained from expanded access to opioid agonist treatment, including in which settings and targeted to which subpopulations, and make the analytic code and resources publicly available to facilitate replications in other jurisdictions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has been FDA approved for managing several brain disorders, including Parkinson’s disease (PD), and has been increasingly used to treat patient over the past couple decades. However, the therapeutic mechanisms of DBS remain largely unknown. This study aims to systematically study the neural circuits involved in PD, and the therapeutic mechanisms of DBS using novel single cell voltage imaging techniques.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Early diagnosis of FGR and the ability to predict abnormal fetal oxygenation later in gestation would improve outcomes for these babies not only during pregnancy and the neonatal period but also throughout life. Currently there are no methods for early second trimester diagnosis of placental dysfunction leading to poor fetal growth. Developing safe diagnostic tests of placental function as early in gestation as possible is therefore critical to improving population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Working memory and the ability to generate timed motor responses are essential for carrying out most daily tasks, and impaired in many neurological and psychiatric conditions. Yet, the brain regions, activity patterns, and learning rules that drive working memory and timing are not understood. Here we propose that the brain often multiplexes both forms of information, and we will use a novel behavioral task along with computational and experimental methods to test this hypothesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative ! Converging lines of evidence provide compelling evidence that the functional domain of the cerebellum is not restricted to sensorimotor control, but extends to domains as diverse as perception, attention, language, and mathematics. To date, functional hypotheses have either been largely descriptive or targeted to account for cerebellar function in a relatively narrow, task-specific manner. The overarching goal of this research program is to take a more mechanistic approach, one designed to extend our understanding of cerebellar function across multiple task domains through the integrated use of behavioral and neuroimaging studies in healthy and neurologically impaired populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Alpha herpesviruses, like herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1), naturally infect the peripheral nervous system causing recurrent herpetic lesions, and can spread to the central nervous system causing encephalitis or may contribute to neurodegenerative disease. To spread to and within the nervous system, alpha herpesvirus particles must transport inside and then exit from infected cells, either non-neuronal cells, or neurons. The goal of this research is to better understand how HSV-1 spreads in the nervous system by investigating the molecular and cell biology of these processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although neuronal loss following brain injury is generally considered permanent, new neurons are born in select locations in the mammalian brain and then integrated into specific neural circuitry (i.e. neurons born in the subventricular zone and then guided by the rostral migratory stream to the olfactory bulb). We have created the first implantable engineered microtissue that structurally and functionally emulates the glial tube of the rostral migratory stream, to date being biofabricated from both rodent as well as human cell sources. The current proposal will evaluate the efficacy of this approach to redirect endogenous newborn neurons to sites of focal degeneration in a preclinical model of traumatic brain injury, which if successful, would provide a regenerative medicine strategy for neuronal replacement potentially capable of mitigating the often devastating — and currently untreatable — cognitive and motor deficits in afflicted patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A growing number of repeat expansion disorders have been shown to accumulate toxic repeat- associated non-ATG (RAN) proteins in patient neurological tissues. This proposal will characterize the accumulation of RAN proteins across multiple CAG·CTG repeat expansion disorders using novel repeat-specific antibodies. Additionally, we have designed AAV and small molecule approaches aimed at the protein kinase R (PKR) pathway to inhibit RAN translation. Using these tools we will test our central hypotheses that RAN protein pathology is a common feature shared across CAG·CTG expansion disorders and that inhibiting the protein kinase R pathway will reduce RAN protein levels and mitigate disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  We are proposing to develop an axon-specific bidirectional optical neural interface and test the system's efficacy to neuromodulate the parasympathetic nervous system by modulating heart function. We will use optogenetics and multiphoton optical excitation to simultaneously detect the neural activity and photostimulate individual axons from the exterior of the nerve i.e. an approach that is non-invasive yet has specificity. This technology has potential for major impact on the ability to treat many conditions; for example, vagal nerve stimulation in humans has been found to control epilepsy and depression, and evidence points to improvements in treatment of inflammatory bowel disease and Alzheimer's Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Our movements are shaped by sensory information, and though much progress has been made in understanding how proprioceptors (muscle sensory neurons) shape motor function, much less is known about how touch receptors (skin sensory neurons) influence motor pathways. To generate a complete picture of how sensory information affects motor actions, this project incorporates a multidisciplinary approach to provide a functional roadmap of how skin touch receptors interact with spinal cord motor centers to shape movement. By understanding the final path for movement organization (i.e., the spinal cord) our research lays the critical foundation for novel ways to modulate spinal circuits for improving motor function affected by disease or injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most common cause of idiopathic and familial Parkinson’s disease, an adult onset movement neurodegenerative disorder, are mutations in leucine-rich repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2). The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand the underlying mechanisms of mitochondrial DNA damage, a shared phenotype between LRRK2-associated and idiopathic PD. It is hoped that cellular pathways involved in maintaining mitochondrial genome integrity will reveal potential new therapeutic strategies to treat this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Fibrosis is a common and debilitating physiological response to injury and inflammation in many tissues and organs, however very little is known about whether there is a fibrotic response to inflammatory diseases of the central nervous system (CNS) including multiple sclerosis, neuromyelitis optica, stroke, and CNS infections. We have identified that a robust fibrotic scar forms in response to CNS neuroinflammatory lesion formation and we will test the hypothesis that a fibrotic scar limits repair following neuroinflammatory disease. We will further examine the molecular mechanisms that lead to fibrotic scar formation, with the goal of identifying potential therapeutics to aid in repair following neuroinflammatory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine the mechanisms by which pupil-linked arousal modulates information processing in the brain. Dysregulation of the pupil-linked arousal system has been implicated in major clinical disorders, including schizophrenia, Parkinson’s disease, and depression, evidenced by abnormal pupil dynamics reported in individuals with the disorders. Therefore, the results of the proposed project will contribute to the knowledge base, potentially leading to more effective diagnosis and improved treatment of the disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because our ability to diagnose and treat neurodevelopmental disorders and brain tumors is critically dependent on fundamental understanding of cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate neural stem cell self-renewal and differentiation in vivo. Research described in this proposal will uncover new and potentially evolutionarily conserved mechanisms governing these processes. If successful, it will have a broad impact on the understanding of human brain development and associated brain disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Type 2 Diabetes is a common, complex health condition which can result in many serious and costly health complications if not treated and controlled properly. Overall, 24% of Veterans are diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes. Vulnerable Veterans, such as minority, low-income, or rural Veterans, and Veterans with comorbid mental health diagnoses, are disproportionately affected and are less likely to have their diabetes under control. One way to help Veterans improve their diabetes control is through the use of technology to help provide information, motivation, and reminders necessary to support diabetes self-management. This study seeks to leverage “Annie”, a new VA texting system. The study will seek input from vulnerable Veteran groups living with diabetes to help develop DD-TXT, a new customizable, interactive texting intervention that allows Veterans to choose what kinds of diabetes self-management support they need, and when. It will compare DD- TXT with another education-only texting intervention called DSE that is based on a diabetes skills workbook.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal uses in vitro, in cellulo and in vivo strategies to understand the mechanism of action of a new class of small molecules, modified polycyclic compounds (MPCs), to address the unmet need for therapeutics for Myotonic Dystrophy (DM), the most common cause of muscular dystrophy. A design-model-test cycle will be used to understand the mechanism(s) of action of these new compounds, systematically refine their efficacy and test their therapeutic potential in patient-derived DM cells lines and animal models. The successful completion of this project will provide a new class of small molecules, a better understanding of their mechanism of action and in vivo data from multiple animal models supporting their future therapeutic potential – all critical steps towards future clinical studies for this complex and devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteria are protected from the surrounding environment by a multi-layer structure known as the cell envelope. In this study, I will characterize how a recently identified, conserved, and essential protein maintains cell envelope integrity in the animal pathogen Brucella ovis. This work will provide new understanding of how the Alphaproteobacteria, which includes the genus Brucella, sustain cellular integrity in the face of inhospitable environmental conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: No technology to date can provide customized therapy that adapts to the individual’s needs with regard to the specific FoG triggering scenarios. The wearable sensor and smart-phone system proposed has the potential to detect different environmental triggers and deliver an optimized dose of vibration at the precise moment it is needed. For people who are isolated in their homes and at risk for falls due to FoG, this new technology has potential to improve their mobility, independence and quality of life; and have important economic benefits for patients, their families, and for the health-care system as a whole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Fentanyl and other ultrapotent opioids interfere with the normal functioning of brainstem circuitry that controls breathing leading to potentially fatal respiratory depression. The proposed studies will provide mechanistic details on serotonergic mechanisms involved in respiratory depression to inform how the serotonin system could be leveraged to combat acute fentanyl toxicity. The outcomes of this research will advance our understanding of the pontomedullary circuitry that controls breathing and provide timely assessment of the safety of co-use of drugs activating 5HT2A receptors, such as serotonergic psychedelics, with fentanyl.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Physical function in older age is among the best predictors of independence and disability and social determinants of health (SDOH) play a critical role in shaping physical function, yet the biologic mechanisms linking SDOH to physical performance are poorly understood. The goal of this proposal is to establish the reliability and validity of using the respirometry in frozen samples (RIFS) method on HRS frozen blood samples to obtain measures of mitochondrial function, and then to examine whether these mitochondrial measures relate to socioeconomic position and physical function. The results of this study will provide important evidence that measures of mitochondrial function, obtained via the RIFS method, can be related to social factors and other important aging-related outcomes and has broad potential to, for the first time, open access to large- scale population-based aging studies with existing biorepositories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative To gain a deeper understanding of long-range airborne pathogen transmission, it is essential to investigate how pathogens behave within different sizes of bioaerosols under various environmental conditions. To achieve this, we propose a novel and easily constructed bioaerosol generator, which can produce monodisperse bioaerosols, making it possible to study the size-dependence of viable pathogen transmission. We will design and build the bioaerosol generator, and investigate the size dependent viability decay for Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) under various environmental conditions.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Liebermann, Erica PROJECT NARRATIVE HPV Vaccination is a critical tool for the prevention of cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers; as such, evidence-based guidelines are to vaccinate children ages 11-12 and provide catch-up HPV vaccination for adolescents and adults up to age 26. Reaching unvaccinated college students for catch-up vaccination is an important strategy to improve HPV vaccination rates in the US. This study will explore college healthcare providers' current beliefs and practices related to assessing HPV vaccine history and offering and recommending HPV vaccination for students in their college health settings. OMB No. 0925-0001/0002 (Rev. 03/2020 Approved Through 02/28/2023) Page Continuation Format Page

PROJECT_TITLE: College Health Provider Attitudes and Practices Regarding HPV Vaccine

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Non-Hispanic Black adults are disproportionately impacted by both acute and chronic post-injury pain relative to Non-Hispanic Whites, yet the biopsychosocial mechanisms underlying these racial differences remain poorly characterized. This prospective study will follow adult traumatic injury patients from hospitalization across a 6- month follow-up period to determine the extent to which biobehavioral and social factors contribute to racial differences in the transition from acute to chronic pain. Enhanced scientific understanding of these mechanisms may provide a unique opportunity to begin mitigating these clinical pain disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial-ethnic socialization (RES)–or the delivery of messages that promote racial-ethnic pride and prepare youth to cope with racism–is a cultural strength that helps to buffer Latino/a/x youth from the damaging effects of racial- ethnic discrimination on mental health and conduct problems. Yet, few preventive interventions directly target parents' RES practices to address health inequities, and a RES intervention specifically for Latino/a/x families is needed. This study will develop, iteratively refine, and pilot a video-feedback intervention to bolster Latino/a/x parents' motivation to engage in RES and strengthen their RES competency (improved skills and confidence, decreased stress), with anticipated benefits on youths' racial-ethnic coping, racial-ethnic identity development, and mental health and behavioral functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Traumatic Axonal Injury: Tau and Amyloid Pathogenesis in vitro. Traumatic brain injury can induce chronic neurodegenerative changes as seen in Alzheimer’s disease/ Alzheimer’s disease related dementias, including tau and amyloid pathologies. While the mechanism leading to these pathologies are not well understood, traumatic axonal injury (TAI) may provide the environment for their genesis. We propose to use a clinically relevant in vitro model of axonal stretch injury to investigate the genesis and metabolism of tau and amyloid-beta in injured axons and their roles in axon degeneration or protection and repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Childhood absence epilepsy (CAE) is the most common pediatric epilepsy syndrome, affecting 10–17% of all children with epilepsy. Those with CAE often experience significant diagnostic delay and limited monitoring due to the difficulty in detecting absence seizures, which also limits clinical studies of new anti-epileptic drugs in this patient population. An in-home diagnostic method would reduce the wait times associated with in-clinic VEEG appointments, potentially reducing time-to-diagnosis and improving access, especially in rural and low-income areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The constant exposure to Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) does not correlate with protective immunity. Antigen processing and loading on MHCII is regulated by H2-M (DM in humans) and its inhibitor H2-O (DO in humans). Here, we find that H2-O-deficient mice mount immune responses that lead to the decolonization of S. aureus and we propose to exploit these animals to identify the underlying mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Parent Grant) Germinal matrix intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) occurs in 15-20% of babies born before 32 weeks of pregnancy. Lifelong consequences may include post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus (PHH), developmental delay, and cerebral palsy. We propose to use cutting-edge optical, genetic, molecular, and clinically informed approaches in our mouse model of neonatal IVH to test if two distinct and complementary endogenous responses to intraventricular blood can be harnessed to mitigate IVH sequelae: (1) ChP-NKCC1 gene therapy to remove excess CSF, and (2) macrophage clearance of ventricular blood. Our findings will give insight into the sequence and causality of events following IVH, unveil new therapeutic targets, and test the first potential gene therapy for PHH.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: The Leica ARTOS 3D is an automated ultramicrotome specifically designed to create long series of sequential sections of cell or tissues to prepare the samples for three-dimensional electron microscopy methods. The ARTOS will greatly improve the efficiency of serial sectioning and permit much larger datasets than currently possible with electron microscopy sample preparation equipment on campus. There is a substantial and fundamental need for this piece of equipment to support the ongoing work of numerous NIH-sponsored grants at Vanderbilt University and Vanderbilt University Medical Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the dynamic process of LLPS that results in the formation of the biomolecular condensates and the reverse process that results in their dissolution will lead us to the knowledge how important cellular behaviors such as cell migration, neurite growth and endocytosis are regulated. It is known that the stability of a biomolec- ular condensate depends on electrostatic forces as well as hydrophobic interactions between the molecules residing in the condensate, but there are no known biosensors for real-time monitoring of environmental hydro- phobicity in living cells, limiting our understanding of how hydrophobicity changes over the lifetime of biomolec- ular condensates. Here we propose to develop a genetically encoded hydrophobicity biosensor consisting of a pair of fluorescent proteins that can undergo Förster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET), and to demonstrate that this biosensor, once partitioned to biomolecular condensates of prescribed species, will dynamically report the hydrophobicity within the condensate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chronic pain is a serious problem in the USA and worldwide and this international collaboration focuses on the use of interdisciplinary approaches to identify and validate novel drug targets and build pain research capacity in Cameroon and Central Africa. The scientific focus of the proposal is on identifying the compounds from analgesic medicinal plants that modulate neurons through calcium metabolism. This includes investigating Cameroonian plants used in traditional medicine, like Paullinia pinnata, that show analgesic effects in models of pain, have affinity for the calcium modulator sigma-2 (σ-2)/Transmembrane Protein 97 (TMEM97) receptor in vitro, and are capable of regulating primary sensory neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Guided by Fundamental Cause Theory with innovative methodologies, this proposal examines the impact of geospatial intersectional stigma and affirmation on substance use and HIV risk among bisexual Black and Latino men in Chicago and Palm Beach County. The study will first collect a cross-sectional household-based probability sample of general population adults (n= 2,000 ) before collecting a geo-targeted online survey sample of bisexual Black and Latino men (n= 600) followed by a qualitative interviews with bisexual men (n=48) and key informants (n=24). By estimating geospatial intersectional stigma scores, using ecological momentary assessments, and qualitative interviews the proposed project will examine and contextualize the impact of geospatial intersectional stigma on substance use and HIV risk outcomes using both a static geospatial model and an activity space model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with obesity often have poorer interoceptive awareness, the ability to sense, interpret, and regulate internal bodily states like hunger. This project will examine how individual differences in interoceptive awareness relate to children’s overeating behaviors (e.g., eating in the absence of hunger), and whether dysregulation of appetitive hormones ghrelin and leptin contribute to poorer interoceptive awareness. Findings will inform whether interventions targeting interoceptive awareness may be helpful for prevention of obesity and related chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Low-income, racial/ethnic minoritized individuals with substance use disorder (SUD) face the greatest disparities in HIV treatment and prevention outcomes, including experiencing significant barriers due to structural factors, including racism and discrimination. Although long acting injectable (LAI) formulations of HIV treatment and prevention are being developed to reduce barriers to care, additional adherence support is still needed. Implementing an evidence-based, peer delivered approach to support adherence to LAI interventions may be a feasible, acceptable, and sustainable way to improve HIV treatment and prevention outcomes among underserved, minority individuals with SUD.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Enhancers are the key units of gene expression control in humans and activate genes across vast genomic distances, yet current 3D genomics methods cannot reliably capture enhancer-promoter interactions, thus hindering our understanding of transcriptional regulation. We plan to apply our recently developed Region Capture Micro-C to profile ultra-high-resolution contact maps for selected genomic regions from three human cell types, and then use our deep learning approach CAESAR to impute the ultra-deep genome-wide chromatin contact maps for diverse human tissues, which will provide accurate quantification of E-P interactions. These E-P interactions will be integrated with NIH Common Fund GTEx and 4DN datasets in knowledge graphs.

ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Solidified aggregates containing proteins that initially phase separate into liquid assemblies are hallmarks of multiple devastating neurological diseases. Novel fluorescence microscopy approaches for characterizing the physical properties of macromolecular assemblies will be applied to identify solid aggregates containing the fused in sarcoma (FUS) protein in live cells. Assessing where such solid aggregates initiate and grow is expected to reveal potential pathways for the onset of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) at the cellular level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MECHANISMS OF AGING September 24 – 28, 2024 This biennial international conference series on the Mechanisms of Aging at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory is designed to be an interdisciplinary forum that accelerates research into the biological basis of aging, which will improve treatment for age-associated diseases and reveal mechanisms of the aging process itself. The conference is unique in the aging research field because it features selected talks from influential invited speakers combined with a large number of short talks chosen by the organizers from openly submitted abstracts, which are submitted three months before the meeting. This format provides ample opportunity for presentation of cutting-edge discoveries and for broad and diverse representation of junior scientists. The research program is augmented by mentoring and career development events that target graduate students and post-doctoral researchers.
