IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY/ABSTRACT Preterm birth (PTB) is the leading cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality, with long-term physical and mental health outcomes for the affected infant. Despite efforts to predict PTB risk and improve pregnancy outcomes, the establishment of etiological pathways has been constrained by the heterogeneity of PTB. Available evidence suggests that maternal exposure to adversities and chronic stress (i.e., maternal childhood trauma, adult abuse, and psychosocial stressors) are strong predictors of PTB. At the molecular level, DNA methylation (DNAm) variation is a well-studied epigenetic marker associated with maternal exposures occurring in pregnancy, some of which can have long-lasting effects on the offspring’s health. Emerging evidence shows that DNAm is related to gestational age at birth in newborns, reflective of fetal development processes. We propose a novel examination of the infant’s DNAm to elucidate the potential biological mechanisms contributing specifically to early PTB (ePTB) (< 34 weeks’ gestation) and related neonatal outcomes in a high-risk population. We will establish whether newborn DNAm mediates the association between maternal risk factors and poorer neonatal outcomes in this group. We will also identify if increased epigenetic age acceleration mediates the relationship between maternal stressors and poorer neonatal outcomes. New knowledge of biological mechanisms influencing ePTB and neonatal outcomes will facilitate the development of timely interventions to prevent ePTB's immediate and long-term consequences, particularly in high-risk populations, and to identify newborns at higher risk of adverse health outcomes. Specifically, this study will: Aim 1. Characterize the DNA methylation profile of infants born early preterm versus those born at term. Aim 2. Examine the extent to which newborn salivary DNA methylation mediates the association between maternal psychopathology and lifetime stressors, with neonatal outcomes linked to ePTB. Aim 3. (a) Estimate the extent to which newborn salivary DNAm predicts clinical gestational age, and (b) use causal mediation analysis to examine if gestational age acceleration mediates the relationship between maternal psychopathology and lifetime stressors with neonatal outcomes. A clear understanding of the role of DNAm and other biological mechanisms associated with ePTB and gestational age may facilitate the development of early interventions related to prematurity, especially in high- risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 50% of persons with Parkinson’s disease (PD) have gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms, especially constipation, which often precede the motor symptoms of PD. This proposal seeks to meticulously compare neurological and GI clinical features, GI transit, anorectal functions, enteric neuropathology, functional brain imaging (PET), the colonic mucosal metagenome, transcriptome, and epigenome and the blood exposome in persons with PD with and without constipation and in asymptomatic healthy controls. By doing so, we plan to assimilate the bigger-picture cellular networks that drive disease processes, enteric neuropathology, brain-gut dysfunctions, and the clinical phenotype in persons with PD with and without constipation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative To address the ongoing nationwide crisis of overdose deaths we propose to develop technology that encourages people who use drugs to protect themselves and the people around them, and that facilitates linkage to available harm reduction services. We will collaborate with a network of community members with whom we have developed strong relationships during prior research projects and will employ a highly participatory, iterative approach to developing intervention content in English and Spanish. Our proposed intervention is designed to be readily scalable for sustainable use in urban settings nationwide, future iterations can be developed for rural populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Successful completion of the proposed study will enhance our knowledge of the role genetic variation has on the resistance, susceptibility and severity and subsequent immune responses to urinary tract infections. The results gained from this project will identify candidate genes associated with UTI susceptibility and resistance and inform the selection of novel strains of mice to be used in further investigation of UTI pathogenesis. This will provide knowledge that can translate these novel discoveries into clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Salivary gland function is chronically impaired in Sjӧgren’s syndrome, a challenging autoimmune exocrine gland disease affecting 4 million Americans with no cure or effective therapies available. There is an urgent need to develop effective and targeted new therapeutic approaches to protect and improve salivary gland secretory function in these patients. Completion of this research project will generate critical new knowledge and insights for the development of novel, microbiome- and microbial metabolite-based therapies to prevent and treat salivary gland hypofunction caused by Sjӧgren’s syndrome and other disease conditions, thereby improving the oral and systemic health of millions of people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Mast cells (MC) are potent inflammatory cells that accumulate within airway and digestive mucosal tissues during type 2 inflammatory diseases, including asthma, nasal polyposis, food allergy, and eosinophilic esophagitis, where they take on discrete intraepithelial and parenchymal phenotypes based on their tissue microenvironment. While each population is known to carry a discrete protease phenotype, the degree to which these populations differentially contribute to tissue inflammation is poorly understood. We have developed a novel cell culture system allowing the differentiation of both phenotypes from human peripheral blood progenitors, allowing direct comparison of the effector function of these two phenotypes. Using these systems, we have discrete cytokine and pro-inflammatory eicosanoid production profiles from the two phenotypes in response to activation and find that they both differentially respond to stimulus with type 2 inflammation-associated cytokines, all of which reflect the in vivo transcriptomic phenotype of intraepithelial versus parenchymal mast cells within human nasal polyps. This proposal seeks to comprehensively characterize the effector function of both subsites as a first step in understanding their relative contribution to human disease in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adaptive auditory processing is critical for navigating everyday listening situations that are dynamic and context-dependent and is known to be compromised in conditions such as aging and hearing loss. The experiments outlined in this proposal will investigate the circuit and physiological mechanisms underlying adaptive processing. Therefore, the proposed experiments may identify how adaptive processing is implemented in normal listening situations and lay the groundwork for investigating how it may be altered in pathological states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer stem cells drive growth and resistance of glioblastoma, the most common primary malignant brain tumor; however, the development of anti-cancer stem cell therapies has been limited by the identification of targetable signaling nodes. We have observed that glioblastoma cancer stem cells require the presence of connexin 43 (Cx43), a gap junction protein that is challenging to specifically target due to its function in non-transformed cell types and due to its homology to other connexin proteins. The objective of this project is to gain mechanistic insight into a signaling network downstream of Cx43 with the goal of identifying targetable downstream signaling nodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will examine the temporal and geographic correlations of structural racism, natural disaster susceptibility, and rates of behavioral health outcomes in Texas and Louisiana. Additionally, we will assess how Hurricane Harvey shaped behavioral health outcomes and the extent to which these outcomes differ based on county levels of structural racism. Finally, we will engage in collaborative data analysis with community members in Houston to optimize interpretation and actionability of results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Approximately 1 in 2 children in foster care exhibit a clinically significant mental health (MH) need, less than ¼ of those children receive treatment, and those who do – experience over a decade delay in seeking treatment. This project will test a family navigator program (FN+) to build foster parent capacity to: 1) recognize their child’s specific MH needs and address any preliminary barriers to treatment; 2) work with the child’s caseworker to engage the child in mental health services; 3) manage the child’s difficult behaviors; 4) overcome barriers to treatment access and use digital mental health tools, and 5) support treatment goals at home. Outcomes include foster parent activation, reduced barriers to treatment, and perceived change in child behavior.

This study will develop new statistical strategies that accurately estimate the disease course using five longitudinal datasets of Huntington disease, a genetic neurodegenerative disease. This administrative supplement will offer both research and career development opportunities to Mr. Kyle Grosser, an outstanding doctoral candidate in biostatistics at the UNC Gillings School of Global Public Health, so he may develop statistical strategies that more accurately predict disease course and inform the selection of outcomes used in clinical trials of Huntington disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Oral cancer is a deadly and a debilitating disease that continues to have poor prognosis despite advances in treatment modalities including surgery, radiotherapy and immunotherapy. The use of bacteria as anticancer agents is an emerging therapeutic approach. This study will investigate the impact of two commensal bacterial species found in the oral cavity on development of oral cancer and its response to immunotherapy in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major contribution to cancer drug resistance is that cancer cells can move into and out of different drug resistance states. This work aims to build computational models of the timing and probabilities of these events and how drugs affect them, so that better combination therapies can be designed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relapsed acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a leading cause of cancer death in children/adolescents, and Philadelphia chromosome-like ALL is a common, high-risk subtype characterized by miswired signaling, high relapse rates, and extremely poor survival. Our research uses systems biology approaches to identify how changes in multiple pathways at the single-cell level may lead to leukemia resistance and relapse. Through these studies, we hope to improve our understanding of the critical biologic mechanisms driving this high-risk leukemia and to develop more effective combination precision medicine therapies to cure patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A subset of pregnant and lactating (“perinatal”) people are persistently using cannabis despite knowledge of its association with negative parental-child outcomes, and materials are needed to train medical providers in how to discuss perinatal cannabis use with patients in a way that effectively promotes health. This study has the potential to impact public health by creating, in collaboration key informants (patients, providers, leaders in healthcare and public health), a toolkit to enable US medical provider adoption of a harm reduction approach to the discussion of perinatal cannabis use with patients. The proposed project will advance the care of perinatal patients by equipping medical providers with the tools necessary to support patients in reducing health harms related to cannabis use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and excessive fat consumption increase the risk of pancreatic cancer, but how they contribute to tumor development is not completely understood. In the parent R01, we aimed to determine how dietary fatty acids directly modulate pancreatic lipid composition to drive tumorigenesis. In this supplement, we focus on the downstream effects of these dietary fatty acids on pancreatic cell metabolism, which may lead to novel targeted dietary and pharmacologic strategies for the prevention of pancreatic cancer and other obesity-driven cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Consent, assent, and decision-making are regularly encountered in the clinical and research settings but can be stymied in youth and adults with Down syndrome (DS). This supplement will add 1) two sites (Miami and San Antonio) and 2) an investigator new to research in people with DS and from a background considered under- represented in research in its efforts to conduct a national patient-centered study of a diverse group of people with DS and caregivers on the use of multi-media materials to promote understanding/appreciation of study purpose, procedures, risks/benefits and decision-making involvement.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Pediatric clinical trials are important for discovering new and effective medicines, treatments, devices, and interventions specifically designed for children and adolescents. Decision-making about clinical trial participation includes both parents and adolescents; however, limited research has directly examined their decision-making process and how this process may impact parents’ and adolescents’ pediatric clinical trial decisions and communication satisfaction. Understanding the unique and dyadic effects of parents’ and adolescents’ communication and decision-making can inform pediatric clinical trial recruitment strategies and decision aids with the goal of improving clinical trial accrual.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we will seek to investigate the efficacy and mechanisms of a novel small molecule with inhibitory activities of non-canonical IkB kinases, TBK1 and IKKe, in alleviating hyperglycemia by (1) improving pancreatic islet cell function and (2) mitigating adiposity via stimulating energy expenditure to achieve enhanced glycemic control in obesity-linked diabetic models. The outcomes of the proposed studies will make a significant breakthrough for developing highly translational therapeutic strategies to mitigate obesity-linked diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Corneal epithelium is maintained by limbal stem cells and loss of limbal stem cells results in limbal stem cell deficiency; the patients suffer from severe vision loss due to the ingrowth of cloudy conjunctiva. We propose to reveal the characteristics of limbal niche cells such as limbal fibroblasts and limbal dendritic cells, evaluate the interaction of limbal niche cells and limbal epithelial cells, and establish limbal fibroblast injection method for the treatment of LSCD. Successful completion of this project will improve our understanding of limbal niche cells in normal and LSCD conditions, and provide us with novel strategic option to treat LSCD, namely limbal fibroblast injection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Herpes simplex viruses persists for life in neurons as a latent infection and can reactivate to cause disease. The aims of this study are to understand the how abundantly expressed neuronal protein, ATRX, promotes both establishment of HSV latency and also prevents reactivation occurring. The long-term goals are to understand how HSV gene silencing occurs in neurons for the development of therapeutics that can target the latent stage of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Targeted gene therapy approaches are reemerging as attractive experimental clinical agents; our ligand-directed hybrid virus of adeno-associated virus and bacteriophage (AAVP) is a targeted gene delivery vector that has been used in several formulations displaying targeting ligand peptides to deliver clinically applicable transgenes. Here we will evaluate a novel combination of two AAVP constructs to target multiple compartments and deliver tumor necrosis factor (TNF) in a clinically relevant model of breast cancer. The double-cyclic RGD4C motif ligand is specific for alpha v integrins expressed in tumor cells and associated vasculature, and the recently reported CSSTRESAC peptide ligand is specific for protein disulfide-isomerase A3 (PDIA3), a novel marker on the surface of tumor associated macrophages, and displays immunoregulatory activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: Project Narrative: Successful completion of this proposal will reveal a novel role of Runx3 in mediating lung cDC2-driven priming and activation of non-Th1 CD4+ T cell subsets during influenza infection. The proposed studies will enable us to identify novel factors and pathways that prevent optimal immunity against respiratory viral infection. The proposal will lead to a comprehensive understanding of Runx3 regulation of T cell immunity during respiratory viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  African American students are under-represented in genome sciences, in part, because of a lack of opportunities exposing them to research methodologies and related careers. The proposed program will expose under-represented students at Hampton University (an HBCU) to a broadly themed series of genome sciences activities aimed at: (1) enhancing computations skills relevant to human diseases, (2) increasing laboratory research experiences translatable to biomedical sciences, and (3) improving training platforms in data analysis, interpretation, and dissemination. Comparative genomic analyses of vertebrate genomes will be used as a framework for bone cell evolution/biology, cell culture methods will reinforce the potential for manipulating the behavior of bone forming cells, and integrated analysis of next-generation sequencing data will allow first-hand exposure to the entire process of scientific inquiry toward the overarching goal of placing our students into post- graduate programs that develop into productive genome sciences careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This project focuses on the role of neuronal activity in regulating the timing of oligodendrocyte progenitor cell differentiation. While extensive literature indicates that increased neuronal activity increases oligodendrocyte progenitor cell differentiation and myelination, the current studies establish that in early brain development, neuronal activity blocks differentiation. The current studies investigate how this difference is regulated and when in development there is a transition from neuronal activity blocking oligodendrocyte progenitor cell differentiation to neuronal activity enhancing differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Family peer mentors are peer supporters with lived substance use disorder recovery and child welfare histories who help parents navigate substance use disorder and child welfare systems. They are critical for delivering interventions that connect parents to treatment but often leave their position after feeling unsupported and stigmatized within child welfare agencies which stops implementation. This proposed study will examine the impacts and build infrastructure to scale-up CrOss Systems Technical Assistance for Retaining Staff (COSTARS) – an innovative supervision coaching model for child welfare supervisors designed to improve supportive supervision, reduce stigma in child welfare agencies, and retain staff which will lead to stronger implementation and parent outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community re-entry is disorder following residential opioid use disorder (OUD) treatment is a critically vulnerable time that characterized by high rates of return to use, particularly for individuals with co-morbid posttraumatic stress (PTSD). This proposal willuse a ground-up approach to rigorously develop and evaluate a mobile app with both on-demand (24/7 PTSD-OUD resources) and automated (skills-based PTSD-OUD interventions) features to reduce opioid use/harms during community re-entry of adults with co-morbid PTSD-OUD. Our final productwill be a highly scalable mobile app that has strong potential to improve health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative: Rutgers University-New Brunswick is requesting funds to convert fourteen IVC racks to a smart artificial intelligence (AI) enabled system to monitor the animals and fourteen environmental monitoring (REM) devices to monitor the macroenvironment of the animal housing rooms. This novel digital ventilated caging (DVC) will enable continuous (24 x7) monitoring of animals in their home cage, help detect early clinical signs of disease or discomfort in animals, prevent human errors such as missed low food or lack of water bottles in the cages, identify soiled bedding using a digital biomarker-bedding status index, increase operational efficiency, and improve animal welfare. The REM devices will help facility management monitor extrinsic variables for research such as noise, light, temperature, humidity, vibration and correct the variables in a timely manner to improve reproducibility of research results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will conduct prospective cross-sectional and longitudinal studies to assess the overarching hypothesis that disruptions in the Gut-Microbiota-Brain-Axis (GMBA) contribute to PD pathogenesis. We posit that a comprehensive model, incorporating validated clinical measures and pathophysiological markers of GMBA disruption, will predict disease severity (Aim 1) and progression (Aim 2) and onset (Aim 3). Outcomes from this project will shed light on mechanisms underpinning PD, identify new therapeutic targets / approaches, and the totality of this project in combination with the collective efforts and resources of others in the NIDDK Consortium is expected to vertically shift the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The veridical representation of odor information in the olfactory cortex is challenged by behavioral signals and representational drift. Using in vivo two-photon microscopy, behavioral monitoring and closed-loop manipulations, we seek to understand the functional role of behavioral signals in odor processing. Completion of this study will open up new avenues of inquiry into the selective manipulation of neural circuit components underlying olfactory sensory-motor transformations during active sensing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomolecular condensates (BMCs) are compartments formed within cells that contribute to normal biological function but can be dysfunctional in certain diseases, including ALS and FTD. The goal of this project is to create a new class of molecular tools known as PNAs to manipulate and monitor formation of BMCs so that we can better understand the mechanisms by which they form and how their dysregulation can lead to diseases. Our PNAs will accomplish this by targeting specific RNA components of BMCs and either making them fluorescent for visual detection in a microscope or blocking their incorporation into BMCs to study the effect on the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: Project Narrative This project provides needed professional development, mentoring, networking, and psychosocial support to allow early-career biomedical researchers from historically excluded groups in science to persist and thrive in a research career, especially in the neuroscience and human physiology fields. This effort will increase the diversity and inclusion of the scientific biomedical workforce, contributing to the national capacity to advance health research outcomes and address scientific challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic medicine seeks to improve clinical outcomes and public health, and identification of clinically actionable inherited genetic conditions before symptoms manifest can enable physicians to intervene earlier and achieve these goals. The newborn screening program exemplifies this paradigm but is limited to a narrow subset of conditions relevant at birth, thereby missing the opportunity to identify many other similarly actionable conditions. Given the many challenges associated with clinical whole genome sequencing in the newborn period, we propose to expand the scope of genomic screening by offering parents targeted sequencing of their children at distinct time-points during development, to discover actionable genetic conditions when that information would have the greatest relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) which are characterized by communication deficits and repetitive behaviors affect between 1 and 2% of children in the US and Canada. This study comprehensively investigates several modifiable risk factors of autism and its associated traits including comprehensive measures of folate status and exposure to environmental contaminants such as air pollutants, phthalates, and pesticides. Findings from this work are highly relevant to North American populations and public health agencies and will provide critical information for the potential prevention strategies for autism and its associated traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FOR THE PREDICATE PHASE I GRANT. Despite the high prevalence and life- threating nature of opioid induced respiratory depression (OIRD), current strategies to monitor for signs of OIRD are not suitable for deployment for all patients receiving opioids. To address the critical clinical need for technology capable of detecting the onset and progression of OIRD, RTM Vital Signs, LLC is developing a wearable, wireless sensor that continuously monitors a patients’ respiratory patterns to provide actionable alerts. By developing and validating this novel monitoring strategy for OIRD, RTM Vital Signs will ultimately improve patient outcomes and avoid adverse events including hypoventilation, hypoxemia, cardiac arrhythmia, and death.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Problem behavior such as self-injury or aggression engaged in by persons with intellectual and developmental disabilities is a major cause of suffering for them and for their caregivers. Identifying effective treatments that can withstand everyday challenges is therefore of utmost importance. This project investigates a novel tactic for making treatments better able to withstand everyday challenges compared to the current standard-of-care approach, and the project's outcomes could significantly impact care and improve the lives of individuals who engage in problem behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative-Overall  The primary objective of the State Alzheimer’s Research Support Center (StARS) is to assist states and sub-states build partnerships; successfully develop 1-year pilot projects; and contribute toward a centralized data infrastructure to examine and advance the accessibility, affordability, and effectiveness of integrated/coordinated dementia care services across the U.S. The specific aims are as follows: 1) to establish partnerships to identify existing coordinated/integrated dementia care services and available data sources within states; 2) to successfully support 16 dementia care pilot projects; 3) to build a within- and across state data infrastructure to evaluate dementia care services and policies; and 4) to implement a multifaceted dissemination strategy to promote best practices in the identification, linking, and sharing of dementia care data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Brigham & Women’s Hospital (BWH), Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center (BIDMC), Boston Children’s Hospital (BCH), and Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH), four major Harvard teaching hospitals, have joined forces with the Harvard Medical School Division of Medical (HMS-DMS) to form the Harvard Kidney, Urology, and Hematology Training Institute (HKUHTI). The HKUHTI will build off each site’s long-standing successful training track record and will develop courses, professional development, and networking opportunities to cultivate a dynamic and diverse community of lifetime contributors to research and innovation. We aspire to train future global leaders in research, establishing a supportive learning environment that is trainee-focused, collaborative, interdisciplinary, and highly interaction with supportive feedback to trainees and program evolution driven by feedback from trainees and faculty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chemotherapy treatment is associated with a loss of muscle mass and resistance to adaptations to exercise, which are among the most impactful physiologic conditions that survivors face. Although there are various mechanisms by which chemotherapy can negatively affect muscle mass and function, we hypothesize that an accumulation of senescent cells inside of skeletal muscle is a powerful, but under-studied, contributor. Providing insight into the mechanisms driving muscle wasting during cachexia, as well as its treatment, could lead to creative therapeutic avenues to help preserve or restore muscle health and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive condition characterized by uncontrolled pulmonary vascular cell proliferation that ultimately leads to right heart failure and death. In this proposal, we will uncover a novel mechanism that is involved in oxidative stress-mediated pulmonary vascular remodeling. This work will test new therapeutics that are targeted to stop pulmonary vascular proliferation attenuating the disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The processes by which people with cerebral palsy adapt and learn to coordinate their muscles in response to rehabilitation remains unclear. New computational tools from machine learning can be used to understand the mechanisms that drive an individual's response to an intervention and guide treatment. The purpose of this supplement is to model individual responses to feedback training for children with cerebral palsy to support improvements in walking function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The human virome, i.e. the collection of viruses found in or on humans, is now primarily explored via metagenomics, which can yield large catalogs of novel virus genomes. Here we plan to develop new tools for taxonomic classification, host prediction, and functional annotation of these novel virus genomes. Building on our experience in establishing some of the foundational viral ecogenomics tools, and leveraging innovative sequence analysis and machine-learning methods, we aim at providing the Human Virome Program consortium with advanced analytics capabilities to better characterize the broad diversity of viruses associated with humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Screening, diagnosis, and monitoring of disease in internal organs is challenging as tissues are not readily ac- cessible. Endoscopic optical imaging possesses the greatest potential for addressing this problem, but its util- ity is significantly impaired by outdated, problematic endoscope design. The successful development of our metasurface-enhanced endoscope will bring dramatic improvements to the technology while also setting a clear course for future technological innovations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The identification of gene mutations associated with hearing loss in humans and animal models has contributed greatly to our understanding of cell type specific functions in the inner ear. Experiments in this grant proposal are strongly motivated by the premise that a detailed elaboration of the molecular and cellular mechanisms of cochlear development and function will not only provide better insight into the workings of this complex sensory organ, but may also profoundly change the way inner ear disorders, including hearing loss, are treated in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This U01 proposal aims to advance the Human Virome Project by developing and validating innovative technologies that address critical challenges in virome analysis, especially in human tissue samples. Our focus is on the development of Viral-MEM and Viral StochQuant, which are designed to enrich viromes, preserve microbial context, and enhance the accuracy and reproducibility of viral sequencing. These advancements may significantly improve our understanding of the human virome and its interactions with the immune system and the rest of the microbiome, paving the way for new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is increasing evidence that differences in responding to everyday visual, auditory, and tactile stimuli are present in infants later diagnosed with ASD, and that attentional patterns (mainly differences in disengaging attention) may explain some of these sensory behaviors in ASD. Comparable research in ADHD is sparse, and because ASD and ADHD share some overlapping causal factors as well as certain early markers, there is a need to examine whether infants developing ASD and/or ADHD show similarities or differences while responding to incoming sensory information early in development and whether links between attentional disengagement and sensory patterns are similar or different across neurodevelopmental disorders. Findings from this study will lead to better understanding of the core and associated symptoms of different neurodevelopmental disorders and provide a route for developing and refining interventions/supports.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The latent phase between traumatic brain injury (TBI) and the manifestation of chronic adverse symptoms such as sleep disruption and epilepsy is associated with activation of an innate immune response with concomitant recruitment of systemic immunocompetent cells, such as monocytes and lymphocytes, into damaged brain areas. The goal of the parent proposal is to determine the role of these peripheral immune cells in neural circuit plasticity that promotes sleep disruption and epileptogenesis after TBI. In this diversity supplement application, the goal is for Ms. Vivianna DeNittis to determine the role of a subset of T cells in post-traumatic electrophysiological and behavioral changes after TBI.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal loss in neurodegenerative diseases and brain injuries necessitates innovative treatments. While transplanting neural progenitor cells (NPCs) offers therapeutic promise, their limited survival and migration hinder efficacy. To overcome this challenge, we aim to epigenetically reprogram CNS vessels, enabling them to provide survival factors and guidance cues for transplanted NPCs, facilitating the reconstruction of lost circuit connections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Older individuals are at increased risk for swallowing impairments (dysphagia), and in many remote care settings (e.g. nursing homes, home health) treating clinicians do not have ready access to fluoroscopic imaging equipment for diagnosis, monitoring, and treatment of swallowing disorders. Ultrasound imaging is a promising option that would allow providers and patients to monitor swallowing movements at the bedside, but validity and reliability of ultrasound use to objectively characterize swallowing has not yet been established. This study will provide essential, fundamental evidence validating ultrasound measurements for characterization of swallowing movements, forming the foundation for future improvements in dysphagia treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major cause of disability, and leads to sleep disruption and epilepsy over time. The latent phase between TBI and the manifestation of chronic adverse symptoms is associated with activation of an innate immune response with concomitant recruitment of systemic immunocompetent cells, such as monocytes and lymphocytes, into damaged brain areas. The goal of this proposal is to determine the role of these peripheral immune cells in neural circuit plasticity that promotes behavioral and electrographic abnormalities like sleep disruption and epileptogenesis after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In response to RFA-DA-23-061 we propose “Race & Place: Impacts of Racial Inequality on Substance Use and HIV Outcomes in Los Angeles” to investigate how historically racist policies and practices affect current Black and Latinx Sexual Minority Men in Los Angeles, how the introduction of peer case management may help reduce some of the barriers in terms of access to HIV care, substance use, food and housing, and in turn how these may improve HIV and substance use outcomes. Our team includes the LA LGBT Center, the largest LGBT Serving community site in the country to ensure that evidence-based research is targeted where it in needed the most. Capitalizing upon cross-cutting expertise with academic and community partners to articulate the drivers of the ongoing HIV epidemic among the most vulnerable populations in the US, we will identify strategies to address the intersectionality of this ongoing public health crisis.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rodents represent around 97% of the vertebrate animals used in biomedical research in the US, yet standard housing guidelines typically expose rodents to cold stress. Growing evidence indicates that the translational value of rodent models of human disease is dependent on housing temperature, a variable seldom controlled for in biomedical research. The goal of this application is to acquire modern rodent housing cabinets that will advance research-related operations within the shared-use rodent metabolic and behavioral phenotyping core at Arkansas Children’s Research Institute. These housing cabinets offer an innovative and energy-efficient mean for breeding, housing, and studying rodents at appropriate housing temperatures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Neurodevelopmental disorders of inattention and disruptive behavior, such as Attention-Deficit/ Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD), are among the most common youth conditions worldwide with prevalence estimates at 7% for ADHD and 10% for ODD in Mexico. Left untreated, they contribute to a host of adverse consequences, costing our global society hundreds of billions of dollars each year. Investigating the effectiveness and implementation of feasible, flexible, sustainable, and scalable school clinician training and evidence-based treatment programs supported by clinical research capacity building efforts has the potential to combat the widespread impact of ADHD/ODD, as well as inform future studies of other evidence-based clinician training and intervention programs in real-world, high-need global contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL - PROJECT NARRATIVE  Kidney, urology, and hematology all represent areas in medicine with critical needs for additional outstanding investigators to fuel high impact discoveries and treatments in future years. Research training in these areas requires a dedicated community with diverse research expertise, committed mentors who are also outstanding scientists, and training in multiple facets of research conduct. This U2C/TL1 aims to support a network of investigators in San Diego to provide outstanding training and mentorship in kidney, urology, and hematology research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulatory T (Treg) cells are immune cells that mediate recovery from viral pneumonia by modulating the immune response and orchestrating the repair of lung injury. Therefore, understanding how Treg cells exert their protective effects is important for the development of new therapies that target this cell type. Our research seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms through which Treg cells metabolically adapt to the inflamed lung.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will determine the impact parent-child relationship quality, during the sensitive period of infancy and toddlerhood, on preschool neurocognitive development and subsequent transdiagnostic psychopathology during school age. Additionally, to address the dearth of research on the importance of fathers on children’s development, we will examine the unique contributions of both mothers and fathers in the development and maintenance of children’s psychopathology and its underlying neurocognitive mechanisms. This work has the potential to identify modifiable targets for prevention and intervention efforts in early childhood aimed at reducing executive dysfunction and the subsequent development of nearly all forms of psychopathology across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-menopausal women are twice as likely to develop knee osteoarthritis than men; yet there are currently no animal studies aimed at understanding how natural menopause propagates knee osteoarthritis and, thus, no specific treatments for post-menopausal people with knee osteoarthritis. This proposal interrogates the role of pathologic protein turnover in menopause-induced knee osteoarthritis and employs synthetic biology techniques to develop an estradiol-regulated genetic controls circuit. Completion of these studies will provide insight into the underlying mechanisms of menopause-induced knee osteoarthritis and provide the first steppingstone for gene- therapy treatments for this disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The research in this VA Merit will examine the effects of obesity and Post-COVID Conditions (PCC) on physical functioning, health-related quality of life, and adipose tissue inflammatory and cellular senescence profiles in older Veterans. Further, it will evaluate whether a weight loss intervention, including dietary modification and exercise, in obese Veterans with and without PCC will reduce systemic and adipose tissue inflammation and senescence and promote PCC recovery. This research is especially relevant to older Veterans as two-thirds of Veterans are overweight or obese, rendering excess adiposity a significant risk factor and a high- priority area related to COVID-19 prevention and care. This study also will explore potential mechanisms by which systemic and adipose tissue inflammation and senescence influences the pathophysiology of physical, mental, and social dysfunction in older Veterans recovering from COVID-19. Our findings could lead to novel lifestyle and pharmacologic strategies to optimize COVID-19 recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain-computer interfaces must enable robust and generalizable control of assistive devices in uncontrolled environments, such as the home. Through this proposal, we will study how the physical or cognitive state of a participant impact neural activity and system performance. In addition, we will characterize the extent to which experience- or training-induced motor learning can drive neural plasticity and improve BCI robustness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Great attention has been paid to the potential role of the external globus pallidus (GPe) in motor control and the aberrant GPe neuronal activity is closely associated with movement deficits in both PD patients and Parkinsonian animal models. Our preliminary results show that the activity of newly identified glutamatergic neurons in the GPe may contribute to PD-related behavioral dysfunction in dopamine-depleted mice. Thus, we will elucidate the anatomical and functional organization of GPe glutamatergic neurons to improve our understanding of GPe circuitry and its contribution to PD-related behavioral dysfunction in animal models for the progressive PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In numerous human diseases the insulating layer around nerves in the brain, called myelin, is damaged and must be efficiently cleared before tissue repair can occur. We have developed advanced methodologies for inducing, manipulating and observing myelin degeneration and repair in the live brain in real time. Using these tools this project will investigate how myelin debris are dynamically cleared by resident glial cells and the consequences of defective clearance on tissue maintenance and myelin repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy (SUDEP) is defined as the sudden, unexpected, and unexplained death of a person with epilepsy and accounts for between 8 and 17% of all epilepsy-related deaths. Increasing evidence supports breathing cessation as a primary cause of death following a seizure. Using a novel mouse model of SUDEP, we propose to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of breathing cessation during and after seizures, possibly creating new therapeutic avenues for SUDEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cranial trauma, tumor invasion, cerebrovascular disease, and brain surgeries all can cause defects to the dura mater. Xenogeneic grafts, when properly treated and handled, have the potential to preserve the overall architecture of the matrix and provide enhanced structural support. This study aims to answer the question “Do acellular xenogeneic dura grafts elicit a less deleterious immune response than naturally derived commercial grafts and maintain structural integrity over the long term for in vivo studies?”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this study is to develop and test the feasibility and preliminary impact of a robust physical activity program among individuals while incarcerated in jail. Based in Social Cognitive Theory and through focus groups and key informant interviews, we will identify theoretical constructs and attributes of physical activity among individuals incarcerated. From formative research, we will develop and evaluate the feasibility and preliminary evidence of impact (Social Cognitive Theory constructs, sleep quality, stress, anxiety symptoms, and depression symptoms) of a physical activity program among individuals incarcerated in jail using a pilot clustered randomized control trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe malaria kills hundreds of thousands of children across sub-Saharan Africa annually, and its biological basis is unknown. This study aims to identify the pathogenic malaria proteins responsible for severe disease in Zambian children and adults using cutting-edge sequencing and microarray technology. We will determine whether these pathogenic proteins are similar to those previously identified in Malian children, raising the possibility that common subsets of parasite variant surface antigens associated with severe malaria in children and adults across Africa could form the basis of a vaccine or therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Nervous system involvement has remained as one of the most important complications of chemotherapy despite development of novel and more effective anti-cancer therapies and the molecular mechanism by which many of the chemotherapy drugs cause axonal injury and result in peripheral neuropathies is poorly understood. Furthermore, there are no effective therapies that prevent or reverse axonal degeneration seen in chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN). This study is aimed at testing whether a key molecule called MAP4K4 plays an important role in neurotoxicity from chemotherapy and whether inhibiting this protein is a viable therapeutic target to prevent CIPN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Bacterial pathogens pose a serious threat to human health. Developing drugs to treat infections caused by pathogens that grow inside host cells is particularly challenging as this environment protects them from exposure to many antibiotics. The goal of this research is to define critical strategies employed by these pathogens to establish an infection to identify novel targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rural Americans have had poorer health profiles than their urban peers since the 1980s, and the gap has widened over time. This project will focus on rural-urban and within-rural disparities in Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD), which in 2020, affected approximately 11% of Americans 65 and older and 35% of those 85 and older. Analyses will 1) produce novel and robust population estimates of dementia prevalence in rural and urban America; and 2) characterize the types of rural places and people most affected by dementia in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genomics hold a great potential to improve human health and well-being, and assist in the preservation of the biological ecosystems that humanity depends upon. Reference genomic resources, and particularly reference genomes, are fundamental assets to perform and assist the analyses of most genomic data sets. With this proposal, we will provide a key set of efficient, interoperable, reproducible and extensible algorithms and tools to improve the quality of the reference genomes that are deposited in the public archives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychosocial distress is a common comorbidity associated with the glaucoma experience and left untreated can contribute to worse outcomes, including worse vision-related quality-of-life and disease severity, faster rates of visual field progression, and poor follow-up and medication adherence, and glaucoma comprehension. The work described in this proposal will introduce and validate an automated assessment and treatment screening program for distress in glaucoma, through innovative predictive modeling of existing healthcare and research database systems. The outcome of this project will shed light on the importance of recognizing distress in the course of glaucoma clinical care, and provide evidence to support new approaches and paradigms to assess and treat glaucoma-induced distress.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Preterm (PT) birth is associated with elevated risks for language impairments, but we know little about why and how PT-related individual differences in language acquisition emerge. The present proposal will examine infant-parent coordinated visual attention as a key mechanism underlying the developmental cascades from PT- induced alterations in basic attention functions and motor abilities to real-time word learning performance. The findings can improve the precision in predicting disruptions in language acquisition and help identify clinically useful predictors of PT-related language impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Sport-related repetitive head impacts (RHI), including soccer heading, are an increasingly recognized public health problem, which have been associated with structural and functional changes typical of brain injury, even in players without history of concussion. The results of our proposed study can expand knowledge by in vivo quantification of cerebral blood flow changes due to RHI and provide insight of into the effect modification by ethnicity, race, handedness, sex, socioeconomic information, and individual histories (occupational, educational, and medical). Our significant step toward a mechanistic understanding of RHI effects can lay a foundation for evidence-based determination of RHI risk among individuals and can facilitate future studies to target mechanisms for prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding how biological systems function – whether normally or in pathological conditions – is essential for maintaining and improving the public health. Researchers cannot improve current standards and practices of clinical care, or develop new treatment modalities, imaging methods, or pharmaceuticals and pharmaceutical targets, without that understanding. The research we will be able to conduct in a renovated core facility at Oakland University will support just such improvements, in areas ranging from vision to cardiovascular and neuroscience, biomedical imaging, DNA damage and repair, addiction, inflammation, developmental biology, and the effects of cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Background: From 2000 to 2019, opioid overdose deaths in the US increased by 255%; and as of 2023, 136 Americans die every day.[1] Naloxone has significantly decreased opioid mortality with increased usage as a front-line life-saving bridge to emergency help and hospitalization. Naloxone HCl Injection, USP (Naloxone) is a non-addictive opioid antagonist that can be given to any person to rapidly reverses overdose symptoms (i.e., respiratory, and central nervous system depression). Naloxone is readily available across all 50 states, often without a prescription, at relatively low cost, even subsidized in many cases through various non-profit and government entities. Community Need: The community (including those susceptible to overdose, family members, first responders, and passersby) are desperately looking for a solution that increases availability, is simple and intuitive to use, and has the needed effectiveness to save a life. I-Corp will allow for a meaningful interaction between Pirouette and that community (AIM I). Availability: When used, Naloxone reverses 93.5% of opioid overdoses. [2] However, Naloxone is not always on-hand when it is needed. Community saturation through widespread distribution and adoption could avert 21% of opioid overdose deaths.[3] The clear choice in increasing adoption of Naloxone is an auto-injector, but unfortunately, there are currently no OTC Naloxone auto-injectors (NAI) available and the single prescription NAI is only available to first responders (AIM III). Usability: A NIDA study illustrated that Naloxone is often administered by untrained bystanders under extreme stress - which studies show leads to accidents, missed doses and tragic consequences.[3] Existing solutions have usability drawbacks (e.g., failure to deliver full dose, needle stick injuries, etc.) that can lead to a general fear and anxiety around using the devices. Effectiveness: The emergence of synthetic opioids (e.g., fentanyl and carfentanyl), which comprise most of the non-regulated drug market, requires improved efficacy.[5]–[7] Intramuscular (IM) administration shows a marked improvement in efficacy (2X) over intranasal due to the absorption rate and half-life in the patient's system. IM administration also requires less frequent follow-up doses (which may also help with availability). The superiority of IM administration makes it ideal for more rural settings where the opioid epidemic is most prolific.[4] Pirouette’s Solution: Pirouette Medical is developing a novel, low-profile, disc shaped auto-injector that can be used to deliver Naloxone HCl Injection, USP intramuscularly safely and intuitively. Pirouette’s NAI, REZQGO, focuses on affordability, portability, and usability. The intuitive design allows individuals with limited or no training to easily administer an injection to themselves or others. REZQGO has controlled steps to administer a dose rapidly, while minimizing the risk of accidental injections, lacerations, and needle sticks. Pirouette’s NAI aims to reduce the stress and anxiety surrounding injections through a better device, at an affordable price. As part of the Phase I SBIR parent award, Pirouette is rigorously verifying the design and usability of non-GMP prototypes of REZQGO. Based on preliminary research, interview feedback, and FDA guidance, Pirouette is initially pursuing two dose strengths: 2mg/0.4mL and 10mg/0.4mL. The 2mg dose was chosen specifically for a Direct to OTC pathway per the FDA's Overdose Prevention Framework (Docket No. FDA-2022-N-2673). The 10mg dose was selected based on the relevant FDA Product Specific Guidance (PSG# 215457). I-Corp Benefits: Pirouette’s parent award originally proposed a 5mg dose, and we still believe there is an opportunity for a third dose strength in between the currently proposed 2mg (OTC) and 10mg (Rx) doses. Conversations with several Emergency Medical Service (EMS) personnel have confirmed this need for a more potent IM initial dose in the 4-5mg range. Pirouette intends to research product-market fit as part of the I Corps program for this subsequent user need and resulting product (AIM II). To that end, Pirouette selected a diverse team of professionals with experience in project management, emergency management, regulatory, new product introduction, and commercialization. Pirouette has submitted two Pre-IND meeting requests to the FDA, one for the 2mg dose (IND#169211), and one for the 10mg dose (IND# 169426). Pirouette anticipates the meetings to be completed by mid-January 2024. The feedback directly from the FDA will also help inform Pirouette’s research in the I-Corps program to select a third dose in the product lineup, giving users another option in their fight to save lives in the Opioid Public Health Emergency. I-Corps will assist Pirouette in market research, regulatory planning, pricing / reimbursement strategy, usability, and the commercialization / GMP implementation of the REZQGO product lineup.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite substantial progress in recent years in identifying neural correlates of auditory hallucinations in psychosis, unanswered questions regarding underlying mechanisms have hindered the development of targeted interventions for affected individuals who do not respond adequately to standard treatments. The proposed research will employ cutting-edge electroencephalography (EEG) methods to investigate potential contributions of auditory processing impairments and alterations in the influence of expectations based on prior knowledge to these symptoms with the aim of informing mechanism-based interventions. Given the significant unmet therapeutic need this work aims to address, the proposed study is consistent with the public health mission of the National Institute of Mental Health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Biobehavioral Basis and Outcomes of Cognitive Dysfunction in  Childhood-Systemic Lupus Erythematosus NARRATIVE Cognitive dysfunction is a common central manifestation in childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus (cSLE) that remains underdiagnosed and undertreated. Determining the aberrant biological processes and outcomes associated with cognitive dysfunction can improve the treatment and quality of life of patients with cSLE. The proposed work will utilize complementary neuroimaging techniques to characterize abnormal brain function and structure in children with cSLE compared to children with mood disorder (e.g., depression or anxiety) as well as healthy peers, and determine how neurobiological properties relate to cognitive ability and other clinical characteristics (e.g., neuropsychiatric symptoms and lupus disease activity).

PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with sickle cell disease (SCD) develop cognitive and other behavioral abnormalities, which are a major source of disability, including loss of job/unemployment and economic potential. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) Public health insurance programs are being implemented across the globe, putting substantial pressure on public finances, despite the fact that there is limited evidence on their causal impact in the long term. This study will address this knowledge gap by utilizing the rollout of Seguro Popular, a nationwide program that provides public health insurance to approximately half of Mexico’s population. By exploiting the panel nature of the Mexican Family Life Survey, the first large-scale, nationally representative survey that has successfully followed respondents across international borders, this project will merge detailed migration histories, rich individual and household health and economic survey questions, and program rollout information to identify and document the extent to which providing universal health insurance in a developing country can improve fetal development, support child health, promote wellness over the life course, and ultimately, reduce existing economic disparities through improved household finances, nutrition, and provision of public health resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Sensorineural hearing loss is a common disease with a prevalence of 20% in the United States, which can impede development of speech and language skills in children and cognitive functions in adults. Stereocilia of inner ear hair cells are organelles that function as biological mechanical switches essential for normal hearing and often degenerate in individuals with sensorineural hearing loss. Single-molecule functional analyses proposed in this study are experimental frameworks to elucidate the molecular dynamics in wild type stereocilia with the goal of identifying therapeutic targets for malfunctioning stereocilia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, epilepsy is highest in sub-Saharan Africa, and in Kenya, a vast majority of people with epilepsy do not receive appropriate treatment (epilepsy treatment gap). We will conduct the first cluster-randomized trial in western Kenya to assess the effectiveness of task sharing supported by the epilepsy medical records system in improving access to and retention in care of people with epilepsy and thus epilepsy care outcomes. This research will enhance epilepsy research and clinical capacity by implementing scalable and sustainable strategies to reduce the epilepsy treatment gap in low-resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Prostate cancer is the leading cancer diagnosis in men (not including skin cancer) and has high survival rates (98% at 5 years), resulting in an estimated 3.2M US men currently living with prostate cancer. However, data shows follow up among prostate cancer patients remains a significant challenge. This project will create a cloud- based clinical decision support system to automatically monitor, track, and optimally classify prostate cancer cases for triage by applying advanced algorithms to curated medical data.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Diversity Supplement to the Healthy Brain and Child Development (HBCD) study will examine the influence of transgenerational supplement development infant programming an career  experiencing discrimination on mental health during the peripartum period and determine the potential  influence of discrimination by examining offspring neurobehavioral development. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thrive Digital Health (TDH) is developing and testing a novel technology platform to enhance, standardize and scale the training of the Peer Recovery Supporter workforce. Peer Recovery Support Services are being increasingly implemented across the U.S. as a strategy to fill care gaps, and this platform will enable public and private organizations to efficiently and cost-effectively build their PRSS workforce, and support that workforce on an ongoing basis as they serve individuals recovering from alcohol and other substance use disorders. ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: The proposed study focuses on using multi-modal assessments (assessed through eye- tracking, pupil dilation, and resting-state heart rate variability) to identify depression, a psychiatric condition characterized by chronically low mood, in persons with aphasia. Results will contribute to new evidence regarding the validity, reliability and reproducibility of using these measures to accurately assess depression in persons with aphasia. An accurate depression diagnosis in persons with aphasia can lead to better management of symptoms which can positively impact linguistic, cognitive, and functional outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a malignant primary brain cancer which carries a dismal prognosis. STAT3 has been shown to be a very attractive therapeutic target for GBM; albeit, small molecule inhibitors of STAT3 signaling are ineffective, as they exhibit very poor blood brain barrier permeability. Our interdisciplinary team will develop and evaluate a novel and scalable bi-compartmental nanoparticle delivery system that allows controlled co-release of STAT3 siRNA and the chemotherapeutic agent, paclitaxel. This work may result in a new treatment modality for GBM, a tumor type, for which no effective treatments exist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The coordinated firing of millions of neurons in the human brain gives rise to the diverse set of experiences, emotions, thoughts, and sensations that make up the human condition. Despite the central importance of neuronal physiology to human health and disease, our understanding of this complex field remains incomplete due to a lack of tools that can reliably report on membrane potential. This proposed research will develop and apply new optical tools to study neuronal membrane potential in cells and in circuits.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Axolotl salamanders are powerful experimental models for exploring a variety of important biomedical questions, yet they require specialized aquatic facilities and equipment for housing to enable rigorous and reproducible research. This proposal will support a shared-use aquatics facility for axolotl used for biomedically-relevant research, including research directed at understanding natural vertebrate limb regeneration. The proposed equipment will directly enable more efficient and reproducible husbandry workflows to raise axolotls for experimentation and for establishment of genome-edited and transgenic lines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trials for the treatment of psychiatric and substance use disorders can be difficult, time-consuming, and expensive to conduct, and partially as a consequence, have sample sizes that may be underpowered for: 1) detecting moderately sized average treatment effects (ATEs) that may nonetheless be important for health at the population level, and 2) learning optimal individualized treatment rules (i.e., rules that match treatments to individuals based on demographic and clinical characteristics that optimize outcomes of interest), which are the cornerstone of personalized medicine. Data fusion is a relatively new and increasingly popular domain of data science that combines data from multiple studies to improve statistical power and answer questions that cannot be addressed by a single study alone. Our overall objective is to develop methods that harness follow-up and other post-exposure measurements as potential proxies for outcomes that are systematically missing by study to deliver more precise estimates of causal treatment effects and facilitating the learning of treatment rules that maximize benefits and reduce harms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dental caries is a preventable disease, however, it still affects large numbers of people globally and in the US. Data from the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 2011-2016 cycle found 1 in 4 adults ages 20-64 years had untreated tooth decay. The purpose of this study is to examine whether teeth that were treated with silver diamine fluoride to arrest a carious lesion required subsequent caries-related extraction, root canal therapy or direct/indirect restoration during the 1-5-year follow-up period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our objective for this research is to determine the efficacy and safety of cilostazol (a novel blood thinner) added to standard therapy compared with standard of care therapies in reducing recurrent strokes, heart attacks and cardiac deaths among recent Ghanaian ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack survivors over 24 months. Participants in this trial will be enrolled from 12 hospitals including primary, district/regional, and tertiary levels across 6 regions (states) in Ghana to broadly capture patient and clinician experiences with the cilostazol and enhance the generalization of study findings. We also seek to develop an implementation strategy using a consultative, multi-stake holder engagement for routine integration and policy adoption of cilostazol as a safe, cost-effective, approach for post-stroke cardiovascular risk reduction in a resource-limited setting while building clinical trial research capacity in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative We propose to expand on IDEA 1 of the parent R35 grant: Use of a multipronged proteomic and genomic approach to define unique and common MYC-driven programs and pathways. Our previous data indicates that experimental inactivation of MYC induces an anti-tumor antibody response. We propose to mechanistically investigate whether MYC mediates its effects on B-cell antibody responses by altering B-cell specific MHC II antigen processing and presentation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The field of substance use research lacks racial and ethnic diversity, and few systematic efforts exist to engage undergraduate students in substance use-related research or coursework. This project will engage undergraduates from underrepresented populations in a coordinated program including didactic coursework, intensively mentored research experiences, and professional development activities related to substance use research and careers substance use-related fields. The goal is to broaden the diversity of the next generation of researchers in the field of substance use studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The refinement of gross motor skills, such as locomotion, during development is conserved across vertebrate species. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the functional and molecular mechanisms underlying the dopaminergic-mediated refinement of spinal locomotor activity using an established vertebrate model system (larval zebrafish). Since the dopaminergic and motor systems are highly conserved across vertebrates, we expect these findings to translate to other animals, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stimulant use disorders and overdose deaths are surging nationwide, and evidence indicates that psychedelics (5-HT2A agonists), such as psilocybin, reduce stimulant use and increase abstinence to a greater degree than psychotherapy alone. We propose to utilize novel selective 5-HT2A tool compounds with full, partial, and biased agonism to investigate the effects on attenuation of methamphetamine self-administration, neuroplasticity, and amotivation. The goal of this proposal is to identify 5-HT2A signaling mechanisms critical for treating drug misuse. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Learning the diﬀerence between safety and danger is critical to survival, yet learning and using safety signals is impaired in some psychiatric conditions including posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Safety learning requires plasticity within the insular cortex and the proposed work investigates the nature of safety and danger signal coding in neurons of an anatomically deﬁned amygdala-insula-prefrontal circuit hypothesized to be necessary for learning and using safety signals to regulate fear. Functional and structural insular cortex abnormalities are reported in individuals with PTSD and other psychiatric conditions and the resulting data will inform pathophysiological mechanisms and new avenues for treatment development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: NARRATIVE Hao-Fountain syndrome is a newly identified rare pediatric neurodevelopmental disorder caused by deletions and mutations of the USP7 gene. The patients suffer from global developmental delays, behavioral abnormalities, autism, and variably impaired intellectual development with speech delay. There is currently no cure for this disorder which places a significant burden on both children and parents; therefore, we propose to develop and validate a new human-based model of the Hao-Fountain syndrome that is essential for understanding the molecular mechanisms of the disease, and the discovery of potential treatments for it in the future.

PHR: Project Narrative Stroke can cause permanent learning, memory, and motor deficits. Adult neural stem cells have the capacity to home to the brain injury and are thought to be an important part of the repair process after stroke. This proposal aims to gain a better understanding of processes that influence adult neural stem cells following stroke and to identify future strategies to increase brain repair following stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this project is to discover novel natural compounds with the potential to inhibit cathepsin L, thereby reducing dynorphin production and offering relief from chronic pain without the risk of addiction. This research has the potential to present a new approach to addressing chronic pain and addressing the opioid crisis. Moreover, it has the potential to pave the way for the creation of innovative pain treatment alternatives that hold significant value for the healthcare sector in Jordan, especially in a context where the availability of options is extremely limited, hence, addressing unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite progress in the development of population-specific innovations and culturally-tailored interventions, disparities in access, receipt, and quality of health care delivery persist for populations that have historically been underserved, underrepresented, and marginalized in dissemination and implementation (D&I) research. This is partially due to a lack of harmonization and standardization among health equity language, data elements, and methods. The goal of this research is to develop and validate a taxonomy using stakeholder engagement and machine learning that will serve to prioritize the needs of those impacted by health disparities and inequities, articulate culturally-relevant and population-specific determinants known to influence implementation, and heighten researchers’ ability to assess which health equity issues are being addressed in D&I research and efforts.

PHR: Project Narrative The Pediatric Early Phase Clinical Trials Network (PEP-CTN) is a consortium whose mission is to identify and develop effective new agents and treatment strategies for children and adolescents with cancer, through rational and efficient clinical and laboratory research. PEP-CTN clinical trials will incorporate correlative genomics, biology, pharmacology, imaging studies, and patient reported outcomes to help further the understanding of the disposition and action of new treatments for children with cancer. Ultimately, PEP-CTN aims to develop innovative pediatric cancer therapies which are more effective and less toxic. Project Narrative Page 22

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is one of the leading causes of cancer related deaths in the United States, with limited options for therapy. Our proposed research will investigate how cancer cells use the nuclear cytoplasmic trafficking pathway to promote cellular growth and metastasis. This proposal will advance our understanding of the mechanisms that contribute to PDAC development and progression and identify potential therapeutic targets.
